I was driving people in on the casual carpool this morning and I  
noticed they built a really tall skyscraper right next to the Bay  
Bridge.  Shucks, it kind of screws up my view of the hills but I guess  
someone needed the office space, or assumed someone would need it.  I  
remember I used to ride in with this lady who would talk about how  
maybe even 30 or 40 years ago, there were all kinds of coffee roasters  
downtown under the bridge, and you'd drive in and smell fresh coffee  
everywhere.  Anyone ever meet this lady?  Older black lady, can't  
really remember much else.

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <995621.50071.qm@web32412.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] The RIAA Wants $1.5 million per ripped CD

Well its not quite that simple, but they are seeking to increase the statutory damages they can receive through legislation known as the PRO-IP act.  Ever download a file from a P2P network?  If this legislation passes, doing that could ruin your life.  

So write your congress person and senator and tell them you oppose PRO-IP.

Not that it will help much since most of them are on the RIAA's payroll, e.g. Barbara Boxer, but I guess its worth a shot anyway.

Learn more about  PRO-IP here: http://www.publicknowledge.org/node/1368 

And here: http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20080129-statutory-damages-not-high-enough.html

Regards,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The RIAA Wants $1.5 million per ripped CD

Well, they've sued thousands already under the existing laws...

This is just an attempt to change the economics of that campaign to be more in their favor.  Since litigation is the new recording industry revenue model, they need to improve the profit margins.  Under the existing laws, they can only get a few hundred thousand from the average file sharer and given that they lose some cases this isn't quite covering their legal costs.  

See http://recordingindustryvspeople.blogspot.com/

Best,

Peter

>

everyone else who participated in the thread do the same.

go and seek us out sum new life and kill it" Enterprise warship.  But  
this JJ Abrams sure knows how to tug on the heartstrings of a space nut.


cya,
john

> Well its not quite that simple, but they are seeking to increase the
> statutory damages they can receive through legislation known as the PRO-IP
> act.  Ever download a file from a P2P network?  If this legislation passes,
> doing that could ruin your life.
>
> So write your congress person and senator and tell them you oppose PRO-IP.
>
> Not that it will help much since most of them are on the RIAA's payroll,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Don't drive in rain with Cruise Control on

i've found the best way to avoid hydroplaning is when your car starts to 
drift, don't stomp on the brake. just take your feet off the pedals and 
let the weight of your vehicle make contact with the pavement again. 
this usually increases the friction again and your car just coasts 
through the puddles with ease. i don't know how many times i've seen 
people in front of me spin out in front of me because people think they 
should just jam on the brakes. i find this is also helpful in racing 
games too. `;)

sean.

Phillip Mispagel wrote:
> A coworker of mine sent the below out, I figure it's worth passing along:
>  
> How many people know about this?
>  
> A person had an accident and totaled her car. It was raining, though not excessively, when her car suddenly began to hydro-plane and literally flew through the air. She was not seriously injured but very stunned at the sudden occurrence!
>  
> When she explained to the highway patrolman what had happened he told her something that every driver should know? Never drive in the rain with your cruise control on. She thought she was being cautious by setting the cruise control and maintaining a safe consistent speed in the rain. But the highway patrolman told her that if the cruise control is on when your car begins to hydro-plane and your tires lose contact with the pavement, your car will accelerate to a higher rate of speed, making you take off like an airplane. She told the patrolman that was exactly what had occurred.
>  
> The patrolman said this warning should be listed on the driver\'s seat sun-visor. Never use the cruise Control when the pavement is wet or icy, along with the airbag warning.
>  
> If you send this to 15 people and only one of them doesnt know about this, then it was all worth it. You might have saved a life.
>  
> Note: some vehicles (like the Toyota sienna Limited xle) will not allow you to set the cruise Control when the windshield wipers are on.
>  
>
>
>
>
>

Alright folks, it's on!

It's shaping up to be a big night...there's a definite buzz in the air and
almost everyone I've talked to is coming out!

Here are a couple things you need to know:

1 - Fuck this rain! The Endup will have out heatlamps and two big tents on
the patio to keep you warm and dry.  That's right, hang out outside on the
patio, chat, smoke, do yo' thang, whatever. DRY. :)

2 - We are excited to announce the addition of a special surprise guest to
the bill!  Joining us will be none other that KOMPAKT's Tobias Thomas, all
the way from Cologne, Germany.  He'll be playing right after Donnacha, so
stick around for some of that pretty Cologne techno to take you into the
morning hours.

So, enough chatter.... let's do this!




Saturday, February 2nd, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Dublin, Ireland in an
exclusive North American appearance:

DONNACHA COSTELLO
*2 hour extended live pa*
(minimise . kompakt . force inc . mille plateaux)


"Well...that's enough. Fuck it." To anyone paying attention, those
words will instantly bring to mind one of the most unique and
memorable techno tracks of last year. The man behind it is Dublin's
Donnacha Costello, who has been producing for over a decade but
really came into the international spotlight in 2004 with the release
of his acclaimed "Colorseries", a monthly sequence of 10 color-
coded EP's created using entirely analog gear and released on his
own Minimise label. Influenced by minimal pioneers like Mike Ink,
Plastikman, and Basic Channel, Donnacha creates warm, dubby
techno that intoxicates the mind as it compels the body to move.
After witnessing his stirring live PA at the 2006 DEMF, we knew we
needed to bring him out to SF, but in the nearly two years since,
he's been nowhere near these parts. Tired of waiting, this month
we've finally decided to say "fuck it" ourselves and fly him over for
an exclusive North American appearance you definitely won't want
to miss.


plus special SURPRISE guest from Cologne, Germany:

TOBIAS THOMAS  (kompakt)


and the [KONTROL] residents:

==> SAMMY D
classic . utensil . dirtybird . magnificent 7

==> CRAIG KUNA
platform . esdjco

==> ALLAND BYALLO
nightlight music . auralism . leibe*detail

==> NIKOLA BAYTALA
s.w.a.t . robsoul . junior boys own

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

February flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32FB.jpg

February flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32BB.jpg

February poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K32/K32P.jpg

____________________________________________________


DONNACHA COSTELLO is many things to many people.

In the past he has been: Child, Brother, Pianist, Teenager, Guitarist,
Student, Techno Musician, Philosopher, Expatriate, Label Owner, Audio
Engineer, Bereaved, Ambient Musician, Visual Artist, Techno Musician,
University Lecturer, Composer for Film, Experimental Musician, Techno
Musician, Husband.

He has been releasing records since 1996 and his talent has long been
recognized by those in the know including Johnny Marr (Ex-Smiths) and Richie
Hawtin. The list of DJs who support his work reads like a Who's Who of
techno, many of whom have licensed his work for their mix CDs, most recently
including Ricardo Villalobos, Luciano, Magda, Tiefschwarz and Josh Wink. As
a live performer, and more recently as a DJ, Costello regularly performs
around the globe from Europe to the U.S. to Japan and runs his renowned
'MINIMISE' record label from his hometown of Dublin.


____________________________________________________


About Donnacha's recently re-issued "Colorseries":

The Colorseries was a series of ten records released in rapid succession by
Donnacha Costello in 2004 and marked the breakthrough point in his career.
The collection is special in that these records were produced solely with
analog equipment, without a computer in sight. The hand crafted coherence of
the music made and speed of the release process marked the series almost as
a stream of consciousness, with each color embodying a different chapter,
mood and season, with all elements inextricably linked to one another in far
more than just name.

Throughout 2004, the Colorseries consistently appeared in the charts of big
name DJs and eventually appeared in end of year top ten lists in many
publications including The Wire and The New York Times.  In the intervening
years, Donnacha has scored a number of hit releases, including last year's
unstoppable "6.6", and has broadened his fan base considerably. The
Colorseries CD will therefore appeal to those who were not around for the
original releases, those who have discovered Donnacha's work through artist
mixes or through witnessing one of his famed live appearances.  Minimise is
proud to present these tracks on CD for the first time, offering the
full-spectrum sound-rainbow for your listening pleasure. Colorseries
influences include: Farley Jackmaster Funk, Steve Silk Hurley, Inner City,
808 State, Plastikman, F.U.S.E., Aphex Twin, The Black Dog, Lobe, LFO,
Maurizio, Basic Channel, Model 500, Baby Ford, Mike Ink, The Modernist,
Studio One, Thomas Brinkmann.

See you on the dancefloor!

You make it seem like not too many people know that. How did those people
get their licenses? Slamming the brakes when hydroplaning is comparable to
slamming the brakes when a tire goes flat. Is it not common sense anymore to
not slam the brakes when traction is lost?

On Feb 2, 2008 6:48 PM, Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:

> i've found the best way to avoid hydroplaning is when your car starts to
> drift, don't stomp on the brake. just take your feet off the pedals and
> let the weight of your vehicle make contact with the pavement again.
> this usually increases the friction again and your car just coasts
> through the puddles with ease. i don't know how many times i've seen
> people in front of me spin out in front of me because people think they
> should just jam on the brakes.

Heh, at least it's not that bad here in the bay. In socal, chaos ensues on
the roads and highways during any rainfall. When it rains: the geniuses down
there liken to driving ~80 mph on the highway, while making sudden
lane-changes and making stops that I'd hardly consider gradual.

While driving on the 880 the Friday before last, my jaw hit the floor when I
got on the freeway and noticed the traffic flowing at ~50 mph. Not to
mention, the drivers up here are far more friendly than down south.

The RIAA is ridiculous. They've been known for wanting exorbitant  fees for their damages and most of their cases have been dismissed by the courts for being utter bullshit. Good luck LOL

- D.


On Feb 1, 2008 3:03 PM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

Well its not quite that simple, but they are seeking to increase the statutory damages they can receive through legislation known as the PRO-IP act.  Ever download a file from a P2P network?  If this legislation passes, doing that could ruin your life.

So write your congress person and senator and tell them you oppose PRO-IP.

Not that it will help much since most of them are on the RIAA's payroll, e.g. Barbara Boxer, but I guess its worth a shot anyway.

Learn more about  PRO-IP here: http://www.publicknowledge.org/node/1368

And here: http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20080129-statutory-damages-not-high-enough.html

Regards,

Peter

> > drift, don't stomp on the brake. just take your feet off the pedals and
> > let the weight of your vehicle make contact with the pavement again.
> > this usually increases the friction again and your car just coasts
> > through the puddles with ease. i don't know how many times i've seen
> > people in front of me spin out in front of me because people think they
> > should just jam on the brakes.

in litigation I bill people everyday for hours and time spent working on an=
y given case I am assigned. My portion of the tasks and duties is far less =
than attorney fees but much cheaper.=20
=20

uch money the law works very different for you and instead of thinking I am=
 going to take someone to court people should consider Alternative Dispute =
Resolution (i.e., mediation, arbitration, etc.).

ll still have to PAY his taxes in the end. It would be meaningless to throw=

hat he eventually will have to do.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Don't drive in rain with Cruise Control on

Ha!  Try Florida... where half the population is on death's door in  
the first place, and 55 truly IS a maximum speed for most of them.   
"Forty-five, stay alive" is the motto in huge swaths of the place.

As for New York, who in their right mind would WANT to drive there in  
the first place?!?!?  I can think of more productive ways to aggravate  
myself to the extent that driving there would send me to.  And when in  
the name of Cuthulu's butthole is it even possible to get UP to 55 in  
New York???  Many years ago, I took a couple of redeye flights into  
Newark.  And even in the godawful early hours of the morning, when no  
one who hasn't been up all night partying should be awake, I don't  
think I the cab taking me into New York ever broke 45!


cya,
john

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] WR: My yuMMy Saturday :n)

So in the afternoon... had a small gathering w/ some Familia in OaktoWn &
lololmao... it was so Dope!!  Love y'all :)

Then i dunno... so like the lil gathering didn't take that long & stuff,
so after kickin' it for a while i guess... well... I mean... it was way
mondo early & stuff, so i just headed to the City & figured I'd find some
mayhem to get into before the club started.

So in short (I'll like mondo try), I sat & spoke to a Scientologist for
about 45 minutes about my life & he told me ways to understand what I'm
going through & that i can visualize & make happen & he gave me a
personality test w/ a free $100 meeting/ session.

After that, walked around SF Center for a bit, but no bueno 'cause i
didn't know why i was wondering some place i had no monrey to burn... so i
thought about food & walked to McD's to use my McD's card... no bueno
either 'cause only had 78 cents on my card, so i ended up @ DonutWorld &
hd a donut while i chilled out there & called My Mona in AZ & well... we
talked 'til my Dad's cell phone was low on battery... so like i managed to
kill like close to an hour & 1/2 of like dodling around Market, which
wasn't bad... but it was hard tryin to come up w/ ideas, so i just headed
to Anu & figured why not...

So i went to Anu & chilled w/ Paul, the semi-new bartender/ barback dude &
it was chillin' with him!!!  He was all like doin' the bartender flares
tricks & he told me heeella funny stories & it was just a good time
chillin' with him 'til the Still Doin' It Started :)

So by 9AM.. Kuze got there & starts spinning like this trippy kinda deep
tribal proggy house.. them closer to 10 he got into some Dopelike almost
atmo jungle :)  DJ Ric got on next & continued the chill Jungle stuff then
got kinda ummmm i wanna say tech steppy kinda stuff... ummm... the DJ M
went on & did his lil laid back jungle set...

OK... then STUNNA went on & played out the rest of the night.. he started
out well.. kinda chill, was all like dubby & stuff, then after that.. it
was aaaall over... ok... Hello 2Day... he went hard like after the 1st
hour, then kept that goin' on for a while, kinda went Raga, but not too
much, then like ok.. in the middle of this set, he busted out this like
atmo-ish kinda spacey breakcore stuff & from there, he went strait on into
fuckin' GHETTOTECH!!!  Yeah... he went there, i was on the floor yellin'
my ass of & dancin' up a fuckikn' storm 'cause the ghettotech scared
people off the floor which meant more room for me to get my groovy on & i
took full advanteage of it.. & i mean.. he kept that up for a long
while!!!! Hello 2Day Fuckin' YUMMMMM!!!!!  He went back to hard jungle
after that to fin & kinda went Anthemy-ish.. lol.. his last track was a
Soldja Boy rmx & LoL.. it was just Dope!!!  LoL!!!

I mean.. it was Dope... like i mean... Stunna & I been like these mondo
online Homies for a cuple of years now & I've never seen him spin out here
& dunno why i'd miss it when he'd be here... but yeah... finally!!!  LoL..
we had like alot to talk about & it was just Ill chillin' w/ him!!! 
See... like he does heeeeeeella radio shows too on the net... & I told him
I would listen to him for a whoel week 'cause I wanted to save the
yummy!!!  Yeah.. my plan worked 'cause i was up in the Crazy fuckin'
maddness he busted out @ SDI!!!  Dope Dope!!!

The whole night was pretty sick... alota Jungle Familia came out & some
old skool faces made appearences too!!!  YAAAY!!!  So Dope!!!  It was a
good vibe... totally fuckin' good!!!  The dancefloor was pretty bumping
from like 11:30 on ;)  Yeah man.. i'm still like hella afterglowin' from
such a Groovy night!!!

Luckily... my Homie Ryan, who barely goes out, was there lastnight 'cause
he's a big Stunna fan:)  So after the club, he gave me a ride home, which,
'cause of my slight case of motion sick & still fuckin' kinda drunk,  was
totally just no beuno... he drives reeeeally well like, ya know when
someone just drives bad & it either freaks you out or you just get sick? 
Well.. i was kinda both & ooh man.. i swear, if i puked wheni got home,
probably woulda been so much better... oh well!

But I woke today still like hella afterglowin' from lastnight!!  So YUm!! :)

Hope y'all had a Groovy weekend too :)
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

votes.

=92t grant blanket immunity to huge corporations that sold out Americans=92=

ers: San Francisco: (415) 393-0707Los Angeles: (310) 914-7300San Diego: (61=

ule of law. Please vote NO on the current Senate Intelligence Committee spy=
ing bill, and keep telecom immunity out of any bill that comes up for a vot=
e.=20
Please reject any bill that allows for the warrantless surveillance or =93b=
ulk collection=94 of Americans=92 phone calls and emails.
When you are finished, log your call here.

 congressional switchboards, flooded the Capitol in a sea of email and buri=
ed lawmakers in a mountain of petitions.After all the twists and turns in t=
his debate, we are finally down to the wire. Every lobbyist, lawyer and org=
anizer at the ACLU is determined to win this fight, whether we have to do i=
t in Congress or in the Courts. But right now it is absolutely essential th=
at the voice of freedom be heard throughout the halls of Congress.=20
Please call Senator Feinstein right now.

iretapping program was first exposed by the New York Times. Together, we wi=
ll bring the government=92s surveillance programs in line with the Constitu=
tion and the rule of law.

gislation.
Thank you for standing with us.
Sincerely, Caroline Fredrickson, DirectorACLU Washington Legislative Office

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: 1200's with signature = $2500


Is this for real??? Sheiiiiiitt must be hard times

http://sfbay.craigslist.org/sfc/msg/562022347.html

Tecnics 1200 (pair) with my own autograph $2500

Hi, and thanks to all you rituos brothers for reading
my post. Yes, it is true, I am selling my DJ gear as I
need the cash. First up is a set of turntables (1200s)
played on by myself and with my own genuine autograph.
I will autograph them again in front of you and sign a
photo of you and me together if you buy them. I am
sure you know who I am - I am DJ Mars of San
Francisco!!!!!!! 
Now that I have your attention, I realise that the
price is high but what you are paying for is prestige.
I was a big trance DJ and still am but I don't play
much as the scene has gone down. People used to love
me and you can ask all the candy ravers. Times are bad
now so I must make money where I can and what better
than to offer a piece of me to you if you are an
admirer or just like me. 
The price is firm and I may also throw in a pair of
needles to sweeten the deal. 
FIRST COME FIRST SERVED!!!!!!!!! 
Cash only, sorry. 
Peace

>> sure you know who I am - I am DJ Mars of San
>> Francisco!!!!!!!
>> Now that I have your attention, I realise that the
>> price is high but what you are paying for is prestige.
>> I was a big trance DJ and still am but I don't play
>> much as the scene has gone down. People used to love
>> me and you can ask all the candy ravers. Times are bad
>> now so I must make money where I can and what better
>> than to offer a piece of me to you if you are an
>> admirer or just like me.
>> The price is firm and I may also throw in a pair of
>> needles to sweeten the deal.
>> FIRST COME FIRST SERVED!!!!!!!!!
>> Cash only, sorry.
>> Peace
>>
>>

I find this entirely believeable -

for those of you who were not around - Frequency 8 was originally 
launched on SFRaves -

the first regular trance party in the bay area - it happened every 2 
weeks - outdoors
for under $5 from April to October of 1996 - Frequency 8 was originally Mars,
MystrE and myself - I know the "Ego of Mars" - but this craigslist ad 
is a bit much -
even for him

> >need the cash. First up is a set of turntables (1200s)
> >played on by myself and with my own genuine autograph.
> >I will autograph them again in front of you and sign a
> >photo of you and me together if you buy them. I am
> >sure you know who I am - I am DJ Mars of San
> >Francisco!!!!!!!
> >Now that I have your attention, I realise that the
> >price is high but what you are paying for is prestige.
> >I was a big trance DJ and still am but I don't play
> >much as the scene has gone down. People used to love
> >me and you can ask all the candy ravers. Times are bad
> >now so I must make money where I can and what better
> >than to offer a piece of me to you if you are an
> >admirer or just like me.
> >The price is firm and I may also throw in a pair of
> >needles to sweeten the deal.

I have a serious question, and not trying to start a flame war.  I did go to
a few F8 parties circa 1997, but never when to any of their outdoor stuff.
How did you guys get away with charging money, when collectives like Wicked
+ other full moon sound systems (including SFR) did them for free?

At 03:08 PM 2/4/2008, Ben Haus wrote:
>I have a serious question, and not trying to start a flame war.  I 
>did go to a few F8 parties circa 1997, but never when to any of 
>their outdoor stuff.  How did you guys get away with charging money, 
>when collectives like Wicked + other full moon sound systems 
>(including SFR) did them for free?


we never felt that we were "getting away" with charging money -
the fact of the matter was that it cost us a couple of hundred dollars
to put these events on - from equipment and generator rental to
firewood for the bonfires to being able to buy the latest "cyber-trance"
imports - those German records were expensive - this was BEFORE
the F8 record store became a reality -

I would explain this to people on SFRaves each time I posted
the date and time of our next event - we would tell people we
were "hoping" for 3 or 5 dollars from each person who came -
and people never disappointed us - SOMETIMES we even had
enough extra money to go out to breakfast afterwards -  people
were GREAT about helping us move all of the equipment both before
and after the parties - it was one wonderful summer . . .  


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> > >I will autograph them again in front of you and sign a
> > >photo of you and me together if you buy them. I am
> > >sure you know who I am - I am DJ Mars of San
> > >Francisco!!!!!!!
> > >Now that I have your attention, I realise that the
> > >price is high but what you are paying for is prestige.
> > >I was a big trance DJ and still am but I don't play
> > >much as the scene has gone down. People used to love
> > >me and you can ask all the candy ravers. Times are bad
> > >now so I must make money where I can and what better
> > >than to offer a piece of me to you if you are an
> > >admirer or just like me.
> > >The price is firm and I may also throw in a pair of
> > >needles to sweeten the deal.
> > >FIRST COME FIRST SERVED!!!!!!!!!
> > >Cash only, sorry.
> > >Peace
> > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: 1200's with signature = $2500

yo last time i saw MARS was in line at an expensive supermarket in marin 
county when i worked at the tower in marin 2 years ago. who was it that 
said in the rave-umentary, 'Intellect,' "never drink your own kool 
aide?" -oh yeah,  it was Mars. i don't think its so much as hard times 
as much as he cannot afford his rock'n'roll lifestyle anymore and 
turntabes have no meaning to trance djs who don't to tricks on them... 
other than tricknology. <sorry trance is an easy target>

i don't want to be a hater, mars was a good guy. i just think he 
underestimated the lifespan of his genre.. who knows, maybe techno will 
be passe' (sp?) tomorrow? if that were to happen, i'd be selling all my 
shit too.. or looking for a viable alternative.

good cop/bad cop statement provided by
sean
DEFsf.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: 1200's with signature = $2500

I think it's at least fair to post that the CL post has been 
rebutted as a hoax:

--------

QUOTE(Jeff Rappaport @ Feb 5 2008, 12:17 AM)
My name is Jeff Rappaport and I'm Mars' partner in the F8gear 
website. I've just confirmed with him that the craigslist ad is 
a complete hoax and has since been flagged for removal. I know 
as a friend he truly loves vinyl and it's his preference when 
playing. Despite hard times in the vinyl market he still puts 
out records for the Diehards out there and was very surprised 
that people on Bayraves actually believed this ad to be true.

With this said, it will be a great year as Mars & Mystre have 
reunited and are currently working on a new album as well as 
touring again -playing CD's and RECORDS :)

F-8th in '08!

-------

um...okay!

-terry

terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Tonal: Midnight Blue - Tonal's 1 Year Anniversary!

One year ago we set out to put a new mark on the San Francisco scene with a
series of color themed parties by the name of Tonal that would feature our
favorite DJs from across the world.  After enlisting the help and input of
many of our friends and family, we decided to kick things off with what
turned into an insane underground featuring Q-Burns Abstract Message.  With
double the turnout we planned for and so many people dressed up in that
party's theme of Electric Blue, we knew we were on to something.

A full year later, looking back at what has been an epic run of events, we
decided it was time to bring back the blue theme for our One Year
Anniversary!  After a year that featured Justin Long and Shamrock Green,
Miles Maeda and Fire Engine Red, Matt e Starr and Pimpin' Purple, Troydon
and Poppin' Pink, Jay Tripwire and Groovin' Gold, Jeno and Fade to Black,
and finally Diz and Clockwork Orange, it's time for Midnight Blue with DJ
Fame!

Saturday, February 23rd

Rock It Science & Prismatic present

Tonal: Midnight Blue

Featuring:

DJ Fame (New York - Dubsided, Potty Mouth)

Tonal is very excited to welcome one of the most cutting edge DJ/producers
to emerge in recent years!  The only US artist with an EP on Dubsided, the
UK label which pioneered the fidget house sound, DJ Fame is coming live from
New York to tear our party to shreds!  From guest sets in every corner of
the globe, to his 4 year residency at New York's premier underground venue,
Sullivan Room, Fame has brought the more jackin' sounds of tech house and
electro to crowds of thousands across the world. A veteran with over a
decade on the decks, Fame's energetic performances showcase serious
technical ability combined with intense cuts, crazy loops, and other
turntablist tricks to bring a truly unique sound to the dance floor.

Plus:

Justin Martin (dirtybird, buzzin' fly)

Alland Byallo (kontrol, nightlight)

Leonard (tocadisco)

Andrew Phelan & Origami (prismatic, drop, amenti)

Eric Sharp (rock it science)

Jimmy B (green gorilla lounge, rxfx)

Rouzbeh (back2basics)

Bo (back2Basics, deep blue)

DK Watts & Lance Leber (short bus Kids, bounce house)

Native Intelligence (rock it science, sugar lounge)

Frankie Jr. (touch recordings, trusoul)

Kuze (nitewise)

Visuals by Viberation
Sound by Slide & Spin

10PM - Late
$10 before 11, $15 before 1, $20 after
For special discount and info text "prismatic" to 67463

Free mix CD for dressing up in Midnight Blue
SF location, for directions:
888-482-9281, 415-412-0406
www.prismatictracks.com



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

and Juan Atkins envisioned , but it is what it is,,,ain't it! ill keep 
bangin vinyl till its no more ,Cd's i can live with but downloads "i 
ain't down for the load" mofoes look like there checking there

--0-904791108-1202235667=:14213
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

That's a *really* big maybe.  In fact, I prefer the sound of digital.  It's clean and the definition of the highs helps break through crappy sound systems.

It's also not dependent on a pristine record and needles to sound good.  If you're listening to just records it may not be very obvious, but if you go from playing a well mastered digital track to an old record, it sounds like muddy crap.

-Phillip

Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote: I dunno....WAV's and 320kbps mp3's sound real damn close to me...

	charset="UTF-8"

X-Priority: 3 (Normal)

X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook CWS, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0)
In-Reply-To: <57af7cfc0802051026i1e945afam278b658e054299a9@mail.gmail.com>
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.3138
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

"well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers !=3D artists (and =
vice versa), good example of that would be:

http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.

I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel =
audio will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high =
quality mp3s will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it =
is an analog impression with all the richness of the music for what we =
can and cannot hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can =
hear define your creative process, that definiation will probably evolve =
over time.

If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the =
richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even =
with evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the =
playback equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on =
my 1200s sounds better than the same CD.

Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal =
collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best =
form of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology =
cheapen the creative and artistic experience.

I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop =
or would he stick with his paints?

My $0.02,
-Smith

-----Original Message-----
From: Wojtek [mailto:wojtek.t.k@gmail.com]
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2008 10:26 AM
To: phillip@viberation.com
Cc: Marco; J.C.; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist


On Feb 5, 2008 10:21 AM, Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> =
wrote:
> That's a *really* big maybe.  In fact, I prefer the sound of digital.  =
It's clean and the definition of the highs helps break through crappy =
sound systems.
>
> It's also not dependent on a pristine record and needles to sound =
good.  If you're listening to just records it may not be very obvious, =
but if you go from playing a well mastered digital track to an old =
record, it sounds like muddy crap.


Very true--it doesn't matter if the music is sh!t, as long as it
sounds clean and well-engineered...





>
> -Phillip
>
> Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote: I dunno....WAV's and 320kbps =
mp3's sound real damn close to me...

>

From sfraves-return-144669-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Feb 05 19:54:43 2008

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

Vinyl = petroleum. Petroleum = finite resource and major source of 
pollution.

Sacrifice the minimal amount of sound quality you may or may not gain w/ 
analog to do something better for the world. Go digital.

This isn't something that comes down to being more artisitc...this is 
something that is just plain irresponsible at this point, and it's not 
utterly neccessary for life.


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Ryan Smith" <sf_smith@comcast.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2008 11:34 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist


"well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and vice 
versa), good example of that would be:

http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.

I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio 
will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s 
will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog 
impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot 
hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your 
creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.

If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the 
richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even with 
evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback 
equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s 
sounds better than the same CD.

Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal 
collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best form 
of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology cheapen 
the creative and artistic experience.

I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or 
would he stick with his paints?

My $0.02,
-Smith

the world) or similar...I'm all for that. Despite what vinyl is made of =
(which is currently bad, yes I agree), the format is still the best of =
form of audio period. All these new digital formats, where did new =
analog formats go? Come on innvoation!

From sfraves-return-144672-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Feb 05 20:18:43 2008
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-144672-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61181 invoked by uid 1103); 5 Feb 2008 20:18:42 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61162 invoked from network); 5 Feb 2008 20:18:41 -0000
Date: Tue, 5 Feb 2008 12:18:35 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
cc: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY110-DAV6D4D28B09692D8F612967852C0@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0802051023110.5591@atari>
References: <20080205093536.W291@kzsu.stanford.edu> <BAY110-DAV6D4D28B09692D8F612967852C0@phx.gbl>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist


On Tue, 5 Feb 2008, Marco wrote:
-&e->Oddly, I find sifting through digi-dowloads online to be fairly similar to
-&e->crate digging - only I never have to wait for an open deck to listen to my
-&e->track on!!!
-&e->
-&e->Some call it "purist"...I call it "stubborn".
-&e->
-&e->With stuff like Serato out, there's no good reason for griping about
-&e->digi-tracks.

Laptops on stage fucking suck (which is ironic cause I play one in one of 
the live setups I use... the only one I can travel with really, whoops).

Figure out another way.

If you're gonna take away the skill and flash and fun factor of the parlor 
trick that is mixing on two primitive playback tools and a small mixer, do 
something new with it.  Seeing a laptop and a mess of cables just so 
people can play vinyl just like a DJ, but with music they just copied or 
maybe shopped... Derrick has it right, if someone figures out a way to 
make it look like they are busting ass and aren't possibly checking their 
email, I'm all for it.  Hasn't happened yet.

Everybody was telling me "oh, you'll change your mind when you see Magda".  
WRONG, she fucking blew goats and the setup was skipping (because Serrato 
needs accurate phase and frequency information it is *more* prone to 
skipping than a normal vinyl record).  Boring tunes, timid mixing, no real 
stage persona, and again, that blue glow on the face and obsession with an 
application none of us can see.

Honestly, I LOVE vinyl, but I think prefer some of the new Denon 
djworkstation/cd players to the vinyl+pc systems out there (at least htey 
get rid of the blue glow/might be checking email thing).  It's not digital 
vs. analog, that battle (hopefully) was declared a truce when a sampler 
would never be a 303, and vice versa... it's the problem with someone 
squinting at a computer trying to rock me, but I can't get over the fact 
that they just look like another hack trying to check in a build before 
midnight.

A part of DJing is what I'll call "performance viability".  With vinyl you 
can see them cueing, looking at the needle, digging in the crate, seeing 
whether they pick their records front to back, or actually shop stuff 
right there based on feel.  You just don't get a lot of that with laptop 
based systems.  With Serrato, they pick up the needle and put it back at 
the beginning... same record.  Only difference is they are picking a new 
piece of material in the computer.

Saying it's the same is saying the Antiques Roadshow is just like the 
Antique Replica Roadshow.  It looks the same, but it's different in a ton 
of very real ways.  The democratization of music is great, it's also a 
curse.  When you bought a pressed 12", someone loved it enough to put down 
several hundred dollars to get it mastered and pressed.  Usually a label.  
A distributor had to love that label enough to pick it up.  A store had to 
want that release in stock.  Names meant more, labels meant more, and 
nobody was putting out crap only a mother could love.

If you made it this far, you're sick.  But let me qualify the above by 
saying that I worked on the development of one of the first vinyl 
controller systems (MsPinky), was there when we demoed it for Naut Human 
and Q-Bert and always thought it was a fun quirky thing... that it's full 
potential would be realized by people like visuals artists controlling 
video playback, and that it wouldn't be a substitute for vinyl DJing, 
which is it's own unique skillset and still evokes a certain feeling that 
someone obsessing on tracklists on a laptop screen while still futzing 
with this dinasauric control media will never attain.

            *andy needs to stop writing run on sentences*

I'd herald this digital download age if it were bringing a lot of amazing 
music, but I'm hearing *less* good stuff in downloadland than I was 
hearing in my fave couple bins at the neighborhood shop circa 1998 on a 
week to week basis.  Some crusty DJs are holding on to vinyl cause that's 
the last time the system really worked for them, and to be honest, I don't 
blame em.  I think of the most amazing moments I've ever witnessed as a 
fan of both dance music and the artform of technical DJing, and almost 
none of them would carry over well to the newer setups.  Beat juggling is 
cheap when you've got loop points built into the UI.  Same for reverses.  
Doubly so because you can flip it in your copy and just play it through.  
Triply so because you could prerecord your most difficult "mix" tricks 
into the digital stuff you're playing back.

People have forgotten that DJing is fun, it's simple, it's something 
anybody can understand, but few truly master.  You show up to some house 
party with a box full of 12 inches and hose the place down with style, 
funk, class and talent...  the same decks the kid before you was playing 
on are now on fire with no change in the technology, just what you played 
and how you play it.  A person can easily understand how the record plays, 
where it's coming from, how the mix works, and generally what is going on 
with vinyl.  But working with such a simple honest little setup, you can 
wreck people's brains when you start doing stuff that is outside the norm.  
It's worth looking at when you see someone really good.  Dig, slap that 
shit on, make a tune out of the new track and the track that's already 
playing, get outta there, rinse, repeat.  Just a simple mixer, and two 
turntables... on these simple tools millions became whack, thousands 
became houseparty heroes, and a few became stars that people line up to 
see like the best bands.

The cuepoints, the drop down lists, the search terms and subdirectories 
pitchlock and effects and pre-playback pitch adjustments don't make it 
better.  They just make it easier.

Are we better off than we were then?  Not really, judging from when I go 
out lately.  Breaks is in a rut, techno is in a rut, house is in a rut, 
the best times I've had lately are stinky ass basement parties with some 
big dude dropping dub and dancehall 45s, often not even beatmatching.  
The average DJ has more tracks to choose from, is often a better technical 
DJ starting out, but can't drive a room full of people to frenzy cause 
they don't understand hypnosis, vibe, groove, energy, tension and flash.  
The tracks don't even allow it, almost every record coming out is either 
just plain not dance music, or so formulaic in it's short phrasing and 
canned length builds that it's frustrating on the dance floor cause you 
never let go of your sense of time passing.  Locked in time/space, locked 
in genres, locked in cliques, just locked... frustrating when you step on 
that dancefloor to be freed.

I don't want to wonder if they are using 128kbps mp3s or lossless or FS or 
Serrato, after a good set I want to know what they put in my drink or why 
I didn't think of that or why am I all sweaty and why is the sun coming up 
or wonder how I could possibly follow a DJ like that myself.

DJing was never about "good enough", it's the only artform where the best 
recordings of the best music in the world are open to you without having 
to understand how they were made or buying up a room full of gear... it 
should be AMAZING.  Bring it or stay home.  I guess the technology 
shouldn't matter, but I haven't been convinced.

andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

-----Original Message-----

Sacrifice the minimal amount of sound quality you may or may not gain w/

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Ryan Smith" <sf_smith@comcast.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2008 11:34 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist


"well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and vice
versa), good example of that would be:

http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.

I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio
will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s
will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog
impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot
hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your
creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.

If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the
richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even with
evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback
equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s
sounds better than the same CD.

Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best form
of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology cheapen
the creative and artistic experience.

I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or
would he stick with his paints?

My $0.02,
-Smith

X-YMail-OSG: 1JUzlEcVM1lHmBpkL5s_Kxtnasm_FPa0Ttry2fq3rn_TQA3u9EbD_VGyHkrwJD7KraTJ48QYWDwga2mJA6BUDtjCDpFw4eosFqDf4.EzU_v8r9Dz4jcuU.f9sHQOdsU-
X-Mailer: YahooMailRC/818.31 YahooMailWebService/0.7.162
Date: Tue, 5 Feb 2008 12:30:50 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Ryan Smith <sf_smith@comcast.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <813326.72573.qm@web60317.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

Vinyl, while it does have its perks (great transient response, fun sound from all the RIAA curve processing and such), isn't the "best form of audio, period", not by a long shot.  Wide-format analog tape probably still holds that title (with good equipment), with high-sample rate digital perhaps a very close second.

Weirdly enough, especially if you're talking about recently pressed vinyl (IE:stuff pressed since 93 or so), most vinyl pressing plants receive their masters from clients as CDs- regular old, ho-hum-sounding CDs.  When pressed to take another format (even something as banal as 24/96k wav), they balk- many of them never got past 1/4" or 1/2" tape and CDs in terms of source tech.  Some folks did bring in masters on tape, but that's gotten much less common since the mid-90s, and most prosumer tape machines sounded terrible, so only something from a big studio or mastering guy would be an improvement over CD.

So, the format definitely does do something nice to audio, but considering most plants make you digitize/bit reduce/src your masters, all that "great sounding vinyl" we're used to buying these days comes from fairly vanilla source material, so it retains no more "data" than it's fed.  I's a credit to the great vinyl cutting engineers of the world that they can manage to wrangle in a little more vibe through processing and hitting the cutting head hard.

Now those olllld records, sometimes even cut straight to vinyl master (no tape, no digital recording, just plug the mixer into the vinyl cutter and go) are another story- they really do have great fidelity.  No better, so to speak, than wide-format tape or high-res digital, but they certainly have their own flavor, and that inimitable transient response.  They're easy to listen to.

Vinyl's got a couple of funky limitations that definitely keep it from edging near the "best format" crown. Records get worse sounding over the course of the each side- the inner songs always sound worse than the outer because there's just more inches to record to per revolution on the outside than in.  Also, a record's length governs how loudly it can be cut (and thus, how good or bad signal-to-noise and overall quality will be.)  A lot of great, long records sound terrible on vinyl because they had to be cut much quieter.  This is why the 12" single can sound so good- there's a huge amount of real estate available for just a few songs.

..and of course, a little dust on your hard drive won't make your wavs pop, crackle, or skip ;)

Anyway, audio geek hat off! hehe
-GC

[snip]

> Honestly, I LOVE vinyl, but I think prefer some of the new Denon
> djworkstation/cd players to the vinyl+pc systems out there (at least htey
> get rid of the blue glow/might be checking email thing).  It's not digital
> vs. analog, that battle (hopefully) was declared a truce when a sampler
> would never be a 303, and vice versa... it's the problem with someone
> squinting at a computer trying to rock me, but I can't get over the fact
> that they just look like another hack trying to check in a build before
> midnight.

LOL.  Geek talk!

[snip]

> Saying it's the same is saying the Antiques Roadshow is just like the
> Antique Replica Roadshow.  It looks the same, but it's different in a ton
> of very real ways.  The democratization of music is great, it's also a
> curse.  When you bought a pressed 12", someone loved it enough to put down
> several hundred dollars to get it mastered and pressed.  Usually a label.
> A distributor had to love that label enough to pick it up.  A store had to
> want that release in stock.  Names meant more, labels meant more, and
> nobody was putting out crap only a mother could love.

If you have the patience to weed through the crap, this gives more 
artists a chance for exposure that they wouldn't have had otherwise. 
(And still, most probably shouldn't have that exposure, so the above 
mentioned "curse" is highly valid.)

>
> If you made it this far, you're sick.  But let me qualify the above by

I'm sick.

[snip]

> I'd herald this digital download age if it were bringing a lot of amazing
> music, but I'm hearing *less* good stuff in downloadland than I was
> hearing in my fave couple bins at the neighborhood shop circa 1998 on a
> week to week basis.  Some crusty DJs are holding on to vinyl cause that's
> the last time the system really worked for them, and to be honest, I don't
> blame em.  I think of the most amazing moments I've ever witnessed as a
> fan of both dance music and the artform of technical DJing, and almost
> none of them would carry over well to the newer setups.  Beat juggling is
> cheap when you've got loop points built into the UI.  Same for reverses.
> Doubly so because you can flip it in your copy and just play it through.
> Triply so because you could prerecord your most difficult "mix" tricks
> into the digital stuff you're playing back.

Ding ding ding. ;)

>
> People have forgotten that DJing is fun, it's simple, it's something
> anybody can understand, but few truly master.  You show up to some house
> party with a box full of 12 inches and hose the place down with style,
> funk, class and talent...  the same decks the kid before you was playing
> on are now on fire with no change in the technology, just what you played
> and how you play it.  A person can easily understand how the record plays,
> where it's coming from, how the mix works, and generally what is going on
> with vinyl.  But working with such a simple honest little setup, you can
> wreck people's brains when you start doing stuff that is outside the norm.
> It's worth looking at when you see someone really good.  Dig, slap that
> shit on, make a tune out of the new track and the track that's already
> playing, get outta there, rinse, repeat.  Just a simple mixer, and two
> turntables... on these simple tools millions became whack, thousands
> became houseparty heroes, and a few became stars that people line up to
> see like the best bands.
>
> The cuepoints, the drop down lists, the search terms and subdirectories
> pitchlock and effects and pre-playback pitch adjustments don't make it
> better.  They just make it easier.

That's been my experience.  Don't forget the nice waveform on the screen 
to further take away the use of the ear.

>
> Are we better off than we were then?  Not really, judging from when I go
> out lately.  Breaks is in a rut, techno is in a rut, house is in a rut,
> the best times I've had lately are stinky ass basement parties with some
> big dude dropping dub and dancehall 45s, often not even beatmatching.
> The average DJ has more tracks to choose from, is often a better technical
> DJ starting out, but can't drive a room full of people to frenzy cause
> they don't understand hypnosis, vibe, groove, energy, tension and flash.

That is the real key, one for which I bow down to Mr. AndyW for bringing 
it.

> The tracks don't even allow it, almost every record coming out is either
> just plain not dance music, or so formulaic in it's short phrasing and
> canned length builds that it's frustrating on the dance floor cause you
> never let go of your sense of time passing.  Locked in time/space, locked
> in genres, locked in cliques, just locked... frustrating when you step on
> that dancefloor to be freed.
>
> I don't want to wonder if they are using 128kbps mp3s or lossless or FS or
> Serrato, after a good set I want to know what they put in my drink or why
> I didn't think of that or why am I all sweaty and why is the sun coming up
> or wonder how I could possibly follow a DJ like that myself.
>
> DJing was never about "good enough", it's the only artform where the best
> recordings of the best music in the world are open to you without having
> to understand how they were made or buying up a room full of gear... it
> should be AMAZING.  Bring it or stay home.  I guess the technology
> shouldn't matter, but I haven't been convinced.
>
> andyw
>

Another one for the archives!  Thanks Andy!


-- 
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

*yawn*

Dinosaur.

I will wreck shop on Serato, and I have seen MANY more than competent DJ's 
using laptop based systems and rock it ten times harder then douchebags with 
decks and vinyl. It's all the skill of the DJ and has next to nothing to do 
with the format.

All this "I like it the old way" crap is exactly that, CRAP.

You like the past so much? Go live in it. Some of us are living in the here 
and now, and the here and now includes digital format and laptop based 
platforms. Build a bridge and get over it.

=)
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
To: "Marco" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2008 12:18 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist


>
> On Tue, 5 Feb 2008, Marco wrote:
> -&e->Oddly, I find sifting through digi-dowloads online to be fairly 
> similar to
> -&e->crate digging - only I never have to wait for an open deck to listen 
> to my
> -&e->track on!!!
> -&e->
> -&e->Some call it "purist"...I call it "stubborn".
> -&e->
> -&e->With stuff like Serato out, there's no good reason for griping about
> -&e->digi-tracks.
>
> Laptops on stage fucking suck (which is ironic cause I play one in one of
> the live setups I use... the only one I can travel with really, whoops).
>
> Figure out another way.
>
> If you're gonna take away the skill and flash and fun factor of the parlor
> trick that is mixing on two primitive playback tools and a small mixer, do
> something new with it.  Seeing a laptop and a mess of cables just so
> people can play vinyl just like a DJ, but with music they just copied or
> maybe shopped... Derrick has it right, if someone figures out a way to
> make it look like they are busting ass and aren't possibly checking their
> email, I'm all for it.  Hasn't happened yet.
>
> Everybody was telling me "oh, you'll change your mind when you see Magda".
> WRONG, she fucking blew goats and the setup was skipping (because Serrato
> needs accurate phase and frequency information it is *more* prone to
> skipping than a normal vinyl record).  Boring tunes, timid mixing, no real
> stage persona, and again, that blue glow on the face and obsession with an
> application none of us can see.
>
> Honestly, I LOVE vinyl, but I think prefer some of the new Denon
> djworkstation/cd players to the vinyl+pc systems out there (at least htey
> get rid of the blue glow/might be checking email thing).  It's not digital
> vs. analog, that battle (hopefully) was declared a truce when a sampler
> would never be a 303, and vice versa... it's the problem with someone
> squinting at a computer trying to rock me, but I can't get over the fact
> that they just look like another hack trying to check in a build before
> midnight.
>
> A part of DJing is what I'll call "performance viability".  With vinyl you
> can see them cueing, looking at the needle, digging in the crate, seeing
> whether they pick their records front to back, or actually shop stuff
> right there based on feel.  You just don't get a lot of that with laptop
> based systems.  With Serrato, they pick up the needle and put it back at
> the beginning... same record.  Only difference is they are picking a new
> piece of material in the computer.
>
> Saying it's the same is saying the Antiques Roadshow is just like the
> Antique Replica Roadshow.  It looks the same, but it's different in a ton
> of very real ways.  The democratization of music is great, it's also a
> curse.  When you bought a pressed 12", someone loved it enough to put down
> several hundred dollars to get it mastered and pressed.  Usually a label.
> A distributor had to love that label enough to pick it up.  A store had to
> want that release in stock.  Names meant more, labels meant more, and
> nobody was putting out crap only a mother could love.
>
> If you made it this far, you're sick.  But let me qualify the above by
> saying that I worked on the development of one of the first vinyl
> controller systems (MsPinky), was there when we demoed it for Naut Human
> and Q-Bert and always thought it was a fun quirky thing... that it's full
> potential would be realized by people like visuals artists controlling
> video playback, and that it wouldn't be a substitute for vinyl DJing,
> which is it's own unique skillset and still evokes a certain feeling that
> someone obsessing on tracklists on a laptop screen while still futzing
> with this dinasauric control media will never attain.
>
>            *andy needs to stop writing run on sentences*
>
> I'd herald this digital download age if it were bringing a lot of amazing
> music, but I'm hearing *less* good stuff in downloadland than I was
> hearing in my fave couple bins at the neighborhood shop circa 1998 on a
> week to week basis.  Some crusty DJs are holding on to vinyl cause that's
> the last time the system really worked for them, and to be honest, I don't
> blame em.  I think of the most amazing moments I've ever witnessed as a
> fan of both dance music and the artform of technical DJing, and almost
> none of them would carry over well to the newer setups.  Beat juggling is
> cheap when you've got loop points built into the UI.  Same for reverses.
> Doubly so because you can flip it in your copy and just play it through.
> Triply so because you could prerecord your most difficult "mix" tricks
> into the digital stuff you're playing back.
>
> People have forgotten that DJing is fun, it's simple, it's something
> anybody can understand, but few truly master.  You show up to some house
> party with a box full of 12 inches and hose the place down with style,
> funk, class and talent...  the same decks the kid before you was playing
> on are now on fire with no change in the technology, just what you played
> and how you play it.  A person can easily understand how the record plays,
> where it's coming from, how the mix works, and generally what is going on
> with vinyl.  But working with such a simple honest little setup, you can
> wreck people's brains when you start doing stuff that is outside the norm.
> It's worth looking at when you see someone really good.  Dig, slap that
> shit on, make a tune out of the new track and the track that's already
> playing, get outta there, rinse, repeat.  Just a simple mixer, and two
> turntables... on these simple tools millions became whack, thousands
> became houseparty heroes, and a few became stars that people line up to
> see like the best bands.
>
> The cuepoints, the drop down lists, the search terms and subdirectories
> pitchlock and effects and pre-playback pitch adjustments don't make it
> better.  They just make it easier.
>
> Are we better off than we were then?  Not really, judging from when I go
> out lately.  Breaks is in a rut, techno is in a rut, house is in a rut,
> the best times I've had lately are stinky ass basement parties with some
> big dude dropping dub and dancehall 45s, often not even beatmatching.
> The average DJ has more tracks to choose from, is often a better technical
> DJ starting out, but can't drive a room full of people to frenzy cause
> they don't understand hypnosis, vibe, groove, energy, tension and flash.
> The tracks don't even allow it, almost every record coming out is either
> just plain not dance music, or so formulaic in it's short phrasing and
> canned length builds that it's frustrating on the dance floor cause you
> never let go of your sense of time passing.  Locked in time/space, locked
> in genres, locked in cliques, just locked... frustrating when you step on
> that dancefloor to be freed.
>
> I don't want to wonder if they are using 128kbps mp3s or lossless or FS or
> Serrato, after a good set I want to know what they put in my drink or why
> I didn't think of that or why am I all sweaty and why is the sun coming up
> or wonder how I could possibly follow a DJ like that myself.
>
> DJing was never about "good enough", it's the only artform where the best
> recordings of the best music in the world are open to you without having
> to understand how they were made or buying up a room full of gear... it
> should be AMAZING.  Bring it or stay home.  I guess the technology
> shouldn't matter, but I haven't been convinced.
>
> andyw
>

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: 1200's with signature = $2500



On Tue, 5 Feb 2008, Sean Ocean wrote:
-&e->ok so,  i was right and wrong. mars is a good guy and he 'never drank his
-&e->own kool aide'. and i should have known he would have never sold his
-&e->ttables.. i have always heard that the F8 people have been sticklers for
-&e->uber clean vinyl, never even touching the records other than at their
-&e->sides. although when i hear scratchy records it makes my heart all warm and
-&e->fuzzy inside for some reason. (my records are all marked up with notes,
-&e->fingerprints and 'sort quick' wax).
-&e->
-&e->sorry to anyone who may have taken offense to my comments. i was gullable.
-&e->no hatin F8. although i still think trance is limited.. i won't take that
-&e->back.`;P
-&e->
-&e->feelin like a jackass,
-&e->sean.

Ugh.

When JBot, Li and I played at KDVS for a Harmony feature, they were 
suprised that we wanted decks set up.  Mars & Mystere had just played "on 
air" the week before using just one DAT player.

It's not hate to call people on what they are.  F8 had some integrity, 
they threw some good parties early on, they followed a dream, I used to 
stop by their shop regularly when they still carried stuff I might buy 
(their heavy diet of trance and nrg had a nice side effect of getting them 
some unique european techno distributors), but he's no saint and not 
exactly the most technical DJ I've ever seen.  M&M in their prime were 
blowing more calories cheerleading and faking ecstatic responses than 
sweating new orders to play their tracks in.  They were making $1500+ 
playing the same 8-9 records in a set while the average life cycle of a 
raver dropped from a few years to months, partially due to the one 
dimensional diet of the same tunes and same pharmaceutical regimen.

I think Niels said it best when he referred to their music as teutonic 
buck dancing music devoid of any soul.  Or something like that.  Same drum 
builds, no swing, no funk, same hoover and juno crud, all the time.  What 
I can't take away from him is that he was leading the charge on trance and 
nrg in the area... he and a handful of others changed the game for every 
record store owner, party attendee and dj in town whether they liked it or 
not... but was it a good thing?

andyw

----- Original Message ----
From: J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

What he said. :)

On 5 February 2008, Ryan Smith wrote:

> "well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and vice versa), good example of that would be:
>
> http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.
>
> I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.
>
> If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even with evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s sounds better than the same CD.
>
> Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best form of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology cheapen the creative and artistic experience.
>
> I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or would he stick with his paints?
>
> My $0.02,
> -Smith
>


--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: 1200's with signature = $2500


On Mon, 4 Feb 2008, Ben Haus wrote:
-&e->I have a serious question, and not trying to start a flame war.  I 
-&e->did go to a few F8 parties circa 1997, but never when to any of their 
-&e->outdoor stuff. How did you guys get away with charging money, when 
-&e->collectives like Wicked + other full moon sound systems (including 
-&e->SFR) did them for free?

The party might have been SFR, but those speakers were often mine.  And I 
really didn't mind, just would wear thermals if it was cold, proper 
northern cali style.

As far as the freebie outdoor thing, if it don't go permits, you don't 
charge period.  And I used to do sound for beach renegades free if the 
promoters were responsible and the space was costless/unpermitted.  
Charging for outdoor locations that NONE of us are allowed to be on is 
bullshit.  But lots of people tried it.  Best approach was to take em to a 
free one and let them know about SF's community and the ethic of sharing 
and DIY rather than the ethic of fleecing and bleeding "customers" and 
CYA.  Make your money at the bar, at the warehouse, when it's your ass 
taking the risks and doing the decorating.  And then take that money and 
blow it on free parties that couldn't happen anywhere else in the world 
outside.

And that stuff about records not being free?  If you wouldn't have bought 
the records anyway (without a party paying you back for them), STOP DJING 
NOW.  You pay for them, you own them, what the hell kinda shit is that?  
An outdoor party can be cheaper to throw than going to a club, getting a 
buzz and catching a cab home.  Call up your buddy with the genny, sucker 
some closet scientist into playing first if they bring their decks, tell 
your closest buddies to bring a couple blacklights and whatever goofy 
Amercian DJ shit they have in the closet and it's ON.  Good vibes all 
around, all the people who brought shit take care of everybody else's 
shit, it's the way it was meant to be.

"Baby, you gotta pay to get in my car cause these mad spinnaz didn't pay 
for themselves."

*boggle*

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________

------=_Part_16374_25421770.1202248280355
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

"Names meant more, labels meant more, and nobody was putting out crap only a
mother could love."

Imma have to call bullshit on that. I've waded through just as much complete
crap looking for vinyl to buy as I have looking for mp3's.

Also, as far as rocking out with a serato/laptop setup. . . It's called
turning the laptop away from you while you play. Pretty much means using it
only to switch tracks, which makes the mixing a bit more difficult since
there's no reference for phrasing. Finally, in my experience, Serato will
skip a LOT less than vinyl will.

On Feb 5, 2008 12:31 PM, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:

> On 5 February 2008, AndyW wrote:
>
> [snip]
>
> > Honestly, I LOVE vinyl, but I think prefer some of the new Denon
> > djworkstation/cd players to the vinyl+pc systems out there (at least
> htey
> > get rid of the blue glow/might be checking email thing).  It's not
> digital
> > vs. analog, that battle (hopefully) was declared a truce when a sampler
> > would never be a 303, and vice versa... it's the problem with someone
> > squinting at a computer trying to rock me, but I can't get over the fact
> > that they just look like another hack trying to check in a build before
> > midnight.
>
> LOL.  Geek talk!
>
> [snip]
>
> > Saying it's the same is saying the Antiques Roadshow is just like the
> > Antique Replica Roadshow.  It looks the same, but it's different in a
> ton
> > of very real ways.  The democratization of music is great, it's also a
> > curse.  When you bought a pressed 12", someone loved it enough to put
> down
> > several hundred dollars to get it mastered and pressed.  Usually a
> label.
> > A distributor had to love that label enough to pick it up.  A store had
> to
> > want that release in stock.  Names meant more, labels meant more, and
> > nobody was putting out crap only a mother could love.
>
> If you have the patience to weed through the crap, this gives more
> artists a chance for exposure that they wouldn't have had otherwise.
> (And still, most probably shouldn't have that exposure, so the above
> mentioned "curse" is highly valid.)
>
> >
> > If you made it this far, you're sick.  But let me qualify the above by
>
> I'm sick.
>
> [snip]
>
> > I'd herald this digital download age if it were bringing a lot of
> amazing
> > music, but I'm hearing *less* good stuff in downloadland than I was
> > hearing in my fave couple bins at the neighborhood shop circa 1998 on a
> > week to week basis.  Some crusty DJs are holding on to vinyl cause
> that's
> > the last time the system really worked for them, and to be honest, I
> don't
> > blame em.  I think of the most amazing moments I've ever witnessed as a
> > fan of both dance music and the artform of technical DJing, and almost
> > none of them would carry over well to the newer setups.  Beat juggling
> is
> > cheap when you've got loop points built into the UI.  Same for reverses.
> > Doubly so because you can flip it in your copy and just play it through.
> > Triply so because you could prerecord your most difficult "mix" tricks
> > into the digital stuff you're playing back.
>
> Ding ding ding. ;)
>
> >
> > People have forgotten that DJing is fun, it's simple, it's something
> > anybody can understand, but few truly master.  You show up to some house
> > party with a box full of 12 inches and hose the place down with style,
> > funk, class and talent...  the same decks the kid before you was playing
> > on are now on fire with no change in the technology, just what you
> played
> > and how you play it.  A person can easily understand how the record
> plays,
> > where it's coming from, how the mix works, and generally what is going
> on
> > with vinyl.  But working with such a simple honest little setup, you can
> > wreck people's brains when you start doing stuff that is outside the
> norm.
> > It's worth looking at when you see someone really good.  Dig, slap that
> > shit on, make a tune out of the new track and the track that's already
> > playing, get outta there, rinse, repeat.  Just a simple mixer, and two
> > turntables... on these simple tools millions became whack, thousands
> > became houseparty heroes, and a few became stars that people line up to
> > see like the best bands.
> >
> > The cuepoints, the drop down lists, the search terms and subdirectories
> > pitchlock and effects and pre-playback pitch adjustments don't make it
> > better.  They just make it easier.
>
> That's been my experience.  Don't forget the nice waveform on the screen
> to further take away the use of the ear.
>
> >
> > Are we better off than we were then?  Not really, judging from when I go
> > out lately.  Breaks is in a rut, techno is in a rut, house is in a rut,
> > the best times I've had lately are stinky ass basement parties with some
> > big dude dropping dub and dancehall 45s, often not even beatmatching.
> > The average DJ has more tracks to choose from, is often a better
> technical
> > DJ starting out, but can't drive a room full of people to frenzy cause
> > they don't understand hypnosis, vibe, groove, energy, tension and flash.
>
> That is the real key, one for which I bow down to Mr. AndyW for bringing
> it.
>
> > The tracks don't even allow it, almost every record coming out is either
> > just plain not dance music, or so formulaic in it's short phrasing and
> > canned length builds that it's frustrating on the dance floor cause you
> > never let go of your sense of time passing.  Locked in time/space,
> locked
> > in genres, locked in cliques, just locked... frustrating when you step
> on
> > that dancefloor to be freed.
> >
> > I don't want to wonder if they are using 128kbps mp3s or lossless or FS
> or
> > Serrato, after a good set I want to know what they put in my drink or
> why
> > I didn't think of that or why am I all sweaty and why is the sun coming
> up
> > or wonder how I could possibly follow a DJ like that myself.
> >
> > DJing was never about "good enough", it's the only artform where the
> best
> > recordings of the best music in the world are open to you without having
> > to understand how they were made or buying up a room full of gear... it
> > should be AMAZING.  Bring it or stay home.  I guess the technology
> > shouldn't matter, but I haven't been convinced.
> >
> > andyw
> >
>
> Another one for the archives!  Thanks Andy!
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: new downtempo mix at 6th Floor Sessions

Another two weeks, another podcast.  i'm proud to present kitchen sync
- and awesome downtempo mix from a good friend of mine - hawker. his
description of the tasty audio treat you're about to consume:

"A genre bending down tempo romp composed with Albelton Live, 'Go
Ahead, Kitchen Sync' was created to showcase several styles of
downtempo grooves, maintaining a chunky, breaky beat throughout. My
first mix in a few years, I spent some time playing with quick mixes
in vocal heavy tracks, as well as building a progression of mood
through the mix."

You can grab it at
http://zombie-j.com

or subscribe to the podcast on itunes.
http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewPodcast?id=266250961

6th Floor Session is a biweekly-ish podcast with mixes and tracks fro
zombie-j and his peeps.  Style is usually dubstep / breaks /
downtempo, but if its good, i'll post it.  The music is always new and
always exclusive.

-- 
jason
6th Floor Sessions Podcast
http://zombie-j.com
aim deceptajason

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

On 5 February 2008, pinkko wrote:

> "Names meant more, labels meant more, and nobody was putting out crap only a
> mother could love."
>
> Imma have to call bullshit on that. I've waded through just as much complete
> crap looking for vinyl to buy as I have looking for mp3's.

Ah, vinyl hunting.  I love the fact that checking out the groove on a 
slab-o-vinyl can tell you a lot about the composition of a track.  Use 
this the next time you're in a store without a listening station.

But, back on topic.  I think the issue is the cost barrier difference 
between the two.  It definitely COSTS more to release a track on vinyl. 
Thus the LOVE and DEVOTION toward that track that someone releasing it 
must have (as Andy stated.)

>
> Also, as far as rocking out with a serato/laptop setup. . . It's called
> turning the laptop away from you while you play. Pretty much means using it

I'll buy that.  How often do folks do this though?  Can't say I've seen 
a one. :)  Sounds like you need to get out here to SF Pinkko and show SF 
how it's done!

> only to switch tracks, which makes the mixing a bit more difficult since
> there's no reference for phrasing. Finally, in my experience, Serato will

The reference for phrasing is what you hear, no?  Sure, you can't SEE 
the beginning of a breakdown coming up, or a major sound change coming 
up, but...

> skip a LOT less than vinyl will.
>

[SNIP]

> On 5 February 2008, Ryan Smith wrote:
>
>> "well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and 
>> vice versa), good example of that would be:
>>
>> http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.
>>
>> I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio 
>> will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s 
>> will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog 
>> impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot 
>> hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your 
>> creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.
>>
>> If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the 
>> richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even 
>> with evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback 
>> equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s 
>> sounds better than the same CD.
>>
>> Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal 
>> collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best 
>> form of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology 
>> cheapen the creative and artistic experience.
>>
>> I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or 
>> would he stick with his paints?
>>
>> My $0.02,
>> -Smith
>>
