Subject: [sfraves] Work it out, DJs!  Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

That's why I always power my laptop/Torq system with a specially rigged exercise bike while in the booth.  It serves many purposes.  

* Keeps me looking like I'm digging ditches up there so people know I'm working hard to make them dance

* Allows all of my sweet music to reach the house system totally carbon neutral- it's pedal power, baby!
* Keeps my heart rate up so I get a good hour of cardio in, and preemptively burn off the half-bottle of Fernet I'll be ingesting later
* Justifies my towering collection of 80s neon sweatbands

Get your spin up, Douche Jockeys!  ...and save the Earth!
-G

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

"You don't need that many damn visual references to mix. The vast majority
of
tracks out nowadays...and this goes back for a number of years, ALL have mix
points roughly at a minute to a minute and a half in - sometimes two, and
the same on the way out. Almost all tracks have VERY STANDARD mix points.
Records, digital, whatever, the vast majority of tunes out there have these
mix points."

Sure, but most vinyl djs (that I've seen, anyway) use the grooves on the
vinyl as a reference. The lighter areas are breaks and so on. Every dj worth
his salt knows how to read the grooves, you get used to it, and when that's
not there anymore you find yourself guessing at times. Hence mixing without
any visual reference whatsoever is (slightly) more difficult.

On Feb 5, 2008 2:38 PM, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:

> Ok, here's where I have to chime in...
>
> You don't need that many damn visual references to mix. The vast majority
> of
> tracks out nowadays...and this goes back for a number of years, ALL have
> mix
> points roughly at a minute to a minute and a half in - sometimes two, and
> the same on the way out. Almost all tracks have VERY STANDARD mix points.
> Records, digital, whatever, the vast majority of tunes out there have
> these
> mix points.
>
> Sadly, that is the one thing that digital made me notice that I *don't*
> like
> about it. Now that I know that, I can pretty much set mixes to a clock,
> especially if there's a time counter feature on the gear I am using.

A never before played record has better sound than a straight digital 
recording, if the sound was recorded in analog and pressed without 
conversion.

That said, I have tons of mp3's, and no records.  The small 
difference in richness isn't compelling to me.. but I do think the 
difference is there.

At 11:53 AM 2/5/2008, Marco wrote:
>Vinyl = petroleum. Petroleum = finite resource and major source of pollution.
>
>Sacrifice the minimal amount of sound quality you may or may not 
>gain w/ analog to do something better for the world. Go digital.
>
>This isn't something that comes down to being more artisitc...this 
>is something that is just plain irresponsible at this point, and 
>it's not utterly neccessary for life.
>
>
>----- Original Message ----- From: "Ryan Smith" <sf_smith@comcast.net>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Tuesday, February 05, 2008 11:34 AM
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist
>
>
>"well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists 
>(and vice versa), good example of that would be:
>
>http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.
>
>I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel 
>audio will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high 
>quality mp3s will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is 
>that it is an analog impression with all the richness of the music 
>for what we can and cannot hear. Dont let scientific definitions of 
>what humans can hear define your creative process, that definiation 
>will probably evolve over time.
>
>If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks 
>the richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, 
>even with evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and 
>the playback equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz 
>vinyl on my 1200s sounds better than the same CD.
>
>Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal 
>collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the 
>best form of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and 
>technology cheapen the creative and artistic experience.
>
>I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in 
>Photoshop or would he stick with his paints?
>
>My $0.02,
>-Smith
>

On 2/5/08, Ryan Smith <sf_smith@comcast.net> wrote:
>
> "well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and
> vice versa), good example of that would be:
>
> http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.
>
> I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio
> will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s
> will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog
> impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot
> hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your
> creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.
>
> If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the
> richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even with
> evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback
> equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s
> sounds better than the same CD.
>
> Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
> collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best form
> of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology cheapen
> the creative and artistic experience.
>
> I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or
> would he stick with his paints?
>
> My $0.02,
> -Smith
>

> > digital.  It's clean and the definition of the highs helps break through
> > crappy sound systems.
> > >
> > > It's also not dependent on a pristine record and needles to sound
> > good.  If you're listening to just records it may not be very obvious, but
> > if you go from playing a well mastered digital track to an old record, it
> > sounds like muddy crap.
> >
> >
> > Very true--it doesn't matter if the music is sh!t, as long as it
> > sounds clean and well-engineered...
> >

> >

On 2/5/08, Ryan Smith <sf_smith@comcast.net> wrote:
>
> "well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and
> vice versa), good example of that would be:
>
> http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my ass.
>
> I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel audio
> will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high quality mp3s
> will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an analog
> impression with all the richness of the music for what we can and cannot
> hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear define your
> creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over time.
>
> If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks the
> richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even with
> evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback
> equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s
> sounds better than the same CD.
>
> Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
> collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best form
> of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology cheapen
> the creative and artistic experience.
>
> I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop or
> would he stick with his paints?
>
> My $0.02,
> -Smith
>

It depends on whether Tiesto autographed the laptop I guess... LOL.

Anyhow...

Once upon a time it was about the party, not the DJ or the music delivery format...

So I ask you in addition:

How about going to a party where the DJ booth is hidden from view and the DJ is never seen by the crowd?

How about going to a party where the DJs' names are not released?

How about goingot a party where the focus was on the celebration and the people doing the celebrating?  

Of course one of them might also happen to be the DJ. ;)

Best,

Peter

> How about going to a party where the DJ booth is hidden from view and the
> DJ is never seen by the crowd?


That would bother me actually. I mean I understand the reason for it, but I
LOVE watching the DJ do his magic so to speak. It's part of the experience
for me and I like the DJ seeing me react to their music if I'm dancing my
ass off :P It's encouragement. I actually have been to a party like that,
but it was okay cuz the DJ was actually obscurred by a wall of speakes so
that compensated for it.

How about going to a party where the DJs' names are not released?


Like beforehand or what? Never released? Not released just beforehand would
be cool because it would be a suprise. Never released would be interesting.
Mystery DJs lol.

How about goingot a party where the focus was on the celebration and the
> people doing the celebrating?


I could dig that.

Of course one of them might also happen to be the DJ. ;)


Even better. Hehe. It would be interesting to throw a party with all these
characteristics you just named. Nice to make people "party outside of the
box" so to speak :)

- D.

> On 2/5/08, Delia <mskittiecat@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > YEAHHHHHH!!! *pumps fist in air* Analog is more forgiving :)
> >
> > - D.
> >
> >
> >  On 2/5/08, Ryan Smith <sf_smith@comcast.net> wrote:
> > >
> > > "well-engineered" is what worries me. For me engineers != artists (and
> > > vice versa), good example of that would be:
> > >
> > > http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my
> ass.
> > >
> > > I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel
> > > audio will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high
> quality
> > > mp3s will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an
> > > analog impression with all the richness of the music for what we can
> and
> > > cannot hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear
> define
> > > your creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over
> time.
> > >
> > > If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks
> the
> > > richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even
> with
> > > evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback
> > > equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my
> 1200s
> > > sounds better than the same CD.
> > >
> > > Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
> > > collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best
> form
> > > of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology
> cheapen
> > > the creative and artistic experience.
> > >
> > > I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop
> > > or would he stick with his paints?
> > >
> > > My $0.02,
> > > -Smith

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.915)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

Well,

I was really uncomfortable using Live at first. It seems like  
cheating, but once I figured out what it could do, no problems  
anymore. I still love vinyl, but I honestly don't have time to convert  
all my tunes. Live is weird, its more like live studio work than  
DJing. If you are just using a laptop, for sure it loses entertainment  
value. If you spend time setting it up so that you don't even have to  
touch the laptop, maybe not so much. I would have to say, though, that  
doing a good set on a laptop is not trivial. If you are doing it  
properly, putting the time into being an entertainer, and learning the  
craft (whether on decks or a laptop) means a lot more than format. IMHO.

STML

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Delia <mskittiecat@gmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

Of course I agree with all of these points.  

I've been to a few parties where I never even saw the DJ and had a great time.  But the DJ audience connection is important too.

At WMC 2000 and 2001 I went to so many parties with DJs I had never even heard of before.  Eye opening sometimes, shitty sometimes, but not usually boring.  I'm willing to take some chances if I know the people throwing the party or the venue or some people going or ...

Finally, how about going to a party where the DJ plays a Nintendo DS?

Check it: http://sanfrancisco.going.com/micromusicsf_launch

This Thursday night!

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Delia <mskittiecat@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, February 5, 2008 9:52:43 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

> How about going to a party where the DJ booth is hidden from view and the
> DJ is never seen by the crowd?


That would bother me actually. I mean I understand the reason for it, but I
LOVE watching the DJ do his magic so to speak. It's part of the experience
for me and I like the DJ seeing me react to their music if I'm dancing my
ass off :P It's encouragement. I actually have been to a party like that,
but it was okay cuz the DJ was actually obscurred by a wall of speakes so
that compensated for it.

How about going to a party where the DJs' names are not released?


Like beforehand or what? Never released? Not released just beforehand would
be cool because it would be a suprise. Never released would be interesting.
Mystery DJs lol.

How about goingot a party where the focus was on the celebration and the
> people doing the celebrating?


I could dig that.

Of course one of them might also happen to be the DJ. ;)


Even better. Hehe. It would be interesting to throw a party with all these
characteristics you just named. Nice to make people "party outside of the
box" so to speak :)

- D.

> > > http://smiph.net/~smith/metro.jpg  Making the city work together my
> ass.
> > >
> > > I mean what happens in 5 to 10 years? Super, HD or multiple channel
> > > audio will be the standard and all of a sudden these wavs or high
> quality
> > > mp3s will pale in comparison. Great thing about vinyl is that it is an
> > > analog impression with all the richness of the music for what we can
> and
> > > cannot hear. Dont let scientific definitions of what humans can hear
> define
> > > your creative process, that definiation will probably evolve over
> time.
> > >
> > > If we kept all the music in current standard formats it bottlenecks
> the
> > > richness of the song to that very specific sampling and bitrate, even
> with
> > > evolving audio technology. Vinyl has no bottle neck and the playback
> > > equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my
> 1200s
> > > sounds better than the same CD.
> > >
> > > Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
> > > collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best
> form
> > > of audio...stick with analog and dont let computers and technology
> cheapen
> > > the creative and artistic experience.
> > >
> > > I mean if DaVinci had a PC, would he create the Mona Lisa in Photoshop
> > > or would he stick with his paints?
> > >
> > > My $0.02,
> > > -Smith

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.915)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

Well,

I was really uncomfortable using Live at first. It seems like  
cheating, but once I figured out what it could do, no problems  
anymore. I still love vinyl, but I honestly don't have time to convert  
all my tunes. Live is weird, its more like live studio work than  
DJing. If you are just using a laptop, for sure it loses entertainment  
value. If you spend time setting it up so that you don't even have to  
touch the laptop, maybe not so much. I would have to say, though, that  
doing a good set on a laptop is not trivial. If you are doing it  
properly, putting the time into being an entertainer, and learning the  
craft (whether on decks or a laptop) means a lot more than format. IMHO.

STML

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

That sounds like the clubs in the 80s. I never knew who the DJ was, but I 
DID care about good music (although I didn't care about the particular 
format in which it was delivered).
In current times where "everyone's a DJ" and that equates to so many being 
shitty, I say, hell yeah, at playing at a party where the lineup is never 
released.
BUT, when it comes to putting all DJs outta view, I'm not sure what the 
purpose of having a DJ would be in that case...a real DJ anyway.  I mean, 
put an IPod in the corner and be done with it for christ's sake and see how 
much vibe it can create.  The point is, that even in today's jaded 
electronic subctulture, there remain DJs who actualy treat the whole thing 
as an artform and are recognized for just that.  Not everyone is a human 
jukebox... some DJs are ARTISTs and not only rely on their ability to 
program to a particular crowd, but also utilize the TOOLs of the trade to 
bring the whole experience to another level.  People don't need to see that, 
they can feel it!

Would you want to pay to see a band behind a curtain?  (Some DJs actually 
play with instrument accompaniment such as drummers etc).

There are shitty bands just like shitty DJs.  The best bands tend to attract 
the best crowds and the most respect.  The best DJs tend to attract the best 
crowds and the most respect.

oh now i've gone on a tangent...

but anyhow...

PLUR!

LOL

; )
d

>> > with

>> > equipment continues to improve. My father's 1950 jazz vinyl on my 1200s
>> > sounds better than the same CD.

>> > Go vinyl! Go tube amps! Digital is handy for on the go and personal
>> > collections, but if you are an artist and have a passion for the best 
>> > form

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <98068.65567.qm@web32407.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

No offense I hope dragnfly because really I am just asking these somewhat off the wall questions to see where the boundaries are.  I think many parties have become formulaic, inside the box, and I'm wondering about alternative ideas.  But what is ok for some people is too far for others.  I'm all for the dancer DJ conneciton BTW, but I'm less fond of the whole "stand around and watch the DJ mix" scene.  So DJ dancer connection yes, DJ as focus of attention and no dancing, no.  

I'm glad you like the idea of a "surprise" party though!  Probably the most realistic way is to have the DJs names secret until the party.  Keeping them secret even afterwards is interesting too though!  Anyway I hope somebody does some version of this idea  HINT HINT!

People that are vinyl purists are missing the boat IMO, use whatever technology works is my creed, and that is my point.  Using a laptop doesn't have to make the DJ disappear (i.e. become meaningless, just a human iPod as you put it) However it might. How can you tell if someone is playing live vs. a recording for example?  Some well known DJs have been accused of playing recordings from DAT; the DJ equivalent of lip synching.  With laptops, how would you ever know unless you monitored their screen or watched what they typed?

Today DJs are moving to laptops and hybrid systems, but what's next might be a lot like an iPod actually.  And if this comes to pass I predict that many of tomorrows laptop DJs will argue that there's no skill involved in playing on these devices.  They'll be "laptop purists"...

Peter

----- Original Message ----

That sounds like the clubs in the 80s. I never knew who the DJ was, but I 
DID care about good music (although I didn't care about the particular 
format in which it was delivered).
In current times where "everyone's a DJ" and that equates to so many being 
shitty, I say, hell yeah, at playing at a party where the lineup is never 
released.
BUT, when it comes to putting all DJs outta view, I'm not sure what the 
purpose of having a DJ would be in that case...a real DJ anyway.  I mean, 
put an IPod in the corner and be done with it for christ's sake and see how 
much vibe it can create.  The point is, that even in today's jaded 
electronic subctulture, there remain DJs who actualy treat the whole thing 
as an artform and are recognized for just that.  Not everyone is a human 
jukebox... some DJs are ARTISTs and not only rely on their ability to 
program to a particular crowd, but also utilize the TOOLs of the trade to 
bring the whole experience to another level.  People don't need to see that, 
they can feel it!

Would you want to pay to see a band behind a curtain?  (Some DJs actually 
play with instrument accompaniment such as drummers etc).

There are shitty bands just like shitty DJs.  The best bands tend to attract 
the best crowds and the most respect.  The best DJs tend to attract the best 
crowds and the most respect.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Derrick May is still a vinyl purist

I see it happen all the time- mainly hipster scene djs. Auto-beatmatching, not much in the way of mix tricks (of course).  No controller, maybe an audio interface if you're lucky.

Weirdly, it doesn't seem to faze any of the dancers at those parties- they love the music and dance their asses off..  

Would bore the piss out of me were I up there doing that- which is why I'm always playing with some precarious pile of controllers, to keep things fun and fluid (and fun to watch).

-G

not compensating, no, really).

people are hard to please these days), we think we've figured out how to
incorporate 2djsonecup.

Andrew is so excited about this prospect that he secretly booked us for
Midnight Blue.

Subject: [sfraves] records with loops

I just picked up this Serbian techno record by Marco Nastic and it has two loop tracks (creatively entitled loop 1 and loop 2) in addiiton to the regular old techno tracks on the record.  I was messing with these a bit last night and had a lot of fun mixing with these loop tracks.  Can anyone out there suggest some additional records with cool little loops like this?  I'm looking for actual vinyl records with loops, not just a colleciton of digital loops.  K, thnx.

Best,

Peter

PS I almost feel like a laptop DJ when I mix with these loops...w00t!  ;)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] records with loops

Woot!  Loops are fun.

If you see an NSC logo etched in the runout groove at the center of the 
record you might find a locked groove on it.  Legend has it that Ron 
Murphy, the man behind NSC, was who invented this concept in the dance 
music realm (on The Rings Of Saturn from Jeff Mills.)

He just passed away in January.
See http://www.soundenterprises.com/

On 6 February 2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> I just picked up this Serbian techno record by Marco Nastic and it has two loop tracks (creatively entitled loop 1 and loop 2) in addiiton to the regular old techno tracks on the record.  I was messing with these a bit last night and had a lot of fun mixing with these loop tracks.  Can anyone out there suggest some additional records with cool little loops like this?  I'm looking for actual vinyl records with loops, not just a colleciton of digital loops.  K, thnx.
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
> PS I almost feel like a laptop DJ when I mix with these loops...w00t!  ;)

Message-ID: <584475.32661.qm@web50008.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] records with loops

i've got a ton of records with infinite loops at the end.  i'll
dig around and find them for you:  most are techno.  one famous
one is josh wink's "don't laugh".

i also have one that plays with the groove in reverse (from the
center of the record --> the outside of the record).  this is a
fun one to leave for the next DJ if you don't like him/her.

i think i also have one that plays one groove in the correct
direction and right alongside it is another groove that plays
in reverse.  that's a real mind-twister for sure.

fyi, most (if not all) of my "DJ tools" records aren't infinite
loops, but are finite-timed tracks that are boring and
repetitive.  good for a transition, but i've found that i
haven't used them too often.

m

<SNIP>

> Today DJs are moving to laptops and hybrid systems,
> but what's next might be a lot like an iPod
> actually.  And if this comes to pass I predict that
> many of tomorrows laptop DJs will argue that there's
> no skill involved in playing on these devices.

the future is now! -- check out the Cortex Dmix-300:

http://www.cortex-pro.com/dmix_300.php

and the Dmix-600:

http://www.cortex-pro.com/dmix_600.php


I had the opportunity to play with the 600 at a trade
show recently (as I always carry around my iPod which
is filled with old R&B "rare groove" break sources)
and I was really amazed by it.  I was even able to
load the same song into the two "decks" and set
discrete cue points and beat-juggle and whatnot. 
Busting out the Peter Piper routine has never been
easier!  :D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] records with loops


DJ Swamp has a series of locked-groove records called
"Neverending Breakbeats"

The Speedy J album "Loudboxer" is a perennial favorite
made up of two records with 50 locked grooves per
side.  

You can usually find locked groove collections in the
Tools/Scratch/Battle section of your favorite rekkid
shop

Or just do a google or ebay search for "locked groove"
and you'll find stuff.

An interesting discussion of locked groove rekkids can
be found here:

http://www.kempa.com/blog/archives/000046.html

From: Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  dangrsmind@yahoo.com, the land of LALA <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <796135.53173.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
In-Reply-To: <796135.53173.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] records with loops

i <3 loop records!! i have a bunch of these. as uncle noah mentioned 
speedy j's loudboxer has a
ton of loops on the vinyl album set. he was really cool by letting
people access his loops and asking people to submit the tracks they made
with them to him via e-mail. molecular put out a record entirely of
loops as well as ars larson, frankie bones and jim hopkins did some dj
tools in the early incarnations of their careers, bones with bonesbreaks
and hopkins with the early twitch releases. if you listen to bonesbreaks
11 you can distinctly hear where the electroliners 'loose caboose' came
from. also vestax put out a record entirely made of synthesizer tones..
wicked fun.
     loops records are especially fun if: you know what you want to do
with them (a set plan really helps), have more than one copy and you
have 4 turntables plus FX. for example, you can make a 4 track mix based
entirely off of loops. get 4 of the same loop record, keep it on quartz
lock... set up the ambient bit and the hard beat mix, the breakdown, the
second half of the hard main beat, or a loop with a good head note to
tell you where the start of the loop is by ear and voila, oontz oontz
oontz. -count it by 2 and you have a solid beat if you change it up the
second bar..

    it helps to have 2 djs doing it too with 2 mixers because it can get
pretty hectic. also changing the tracks in time is problematic.. the key
is to do as much as you can with the limited amount of time and to
change shit up every bar/other bar and keep in time as much as possible
with counting. if you have a pair of cd players in coordination with
this set up plus a PV grabber/floor sampler it can be really awesome.

i think loop records would save vinyl if more people put them out but
they are quite possibly a fun novelty especially when cd players,
ableton and traktor can do this without batting an eyelash. but seeing
djs sweat and trying to keep things on beat is really fun and exciting
to watch. so if its fun, i'd probably go with that.

peace love and techno!
sean.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

I'm looking for actual vinyl records with loops, not just a colleciton of digital loops.  K, thnx.
>

from. also vestax put out a record entirely made of synthesizer tones..
wicked fun.
    loops records are especially fun if: you know what you want to do
with them (a set plan really helps), have more than one copy and you
have 4 turntables plus FX. for example, you can make a 4 track mix based
entirely off of loops. get 4 of the same loop record, keep it on quartz
lock... set up the ambient bit and the hard beat mix, the breakdown, the
second half of the hard main beat, or a loop with a good head note to
tell you where the start of the loop is by ear and voila, oontz oontz
oontz. -count it by 2 and you have a solid beat if you change it up the
second bar..

    it helps to have 2 djs doing it too with 2 mixers because it can get
pretty hectic. also changing the tracks in time is problematic.. the key
is to do as much as you can with the limited amount of time and to
change shit up every bar/other bar and keep in time as much as possible
with counting. if you have a pair of cd players in coordination with
this set up plus a PV grabber/floor sampler it can be really awesome.

i think loop records would save vinyl if more people put them out but
they are quite possibly a fun novelty especially when cd players,
ableton and traktor can do this without batting an eyelash. but seeing
djs sweat and trying to keep things on beat is really fun and exciting
to watch. so if its fun, i'd probably go with that.

peace love and techno!
sean.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> I just picked up this Serbian techno record by Marco Nastic and it has two loop tracks (creatively entitled loop 1 and loop 2) in addiiton to the regular old techno tracks on the record.  I was messing with these a bit last night and had a lot of fun mixing with these loop tracks.  Can anyone out there suggest some additional records with cool little loops like this?  I'm looking for actual vinyl records with loops, not just a colleciton of digital loops.  K, thnx.

----- Original Message ----
From: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>
To: electrofunk138@hotmail.com; dangrsmind@yahoo.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Wednesday, February 6, 2008 11:07:44 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] records with loops

i've got a ton of records with infinite loops at the end.  i'll
dig around and find them for you:  most are techno.  one famous
one is josh wink's "don't laugh".

i also have one that plays with the groove in reverse (from the
center of the record --> the outside of the record).  this is a
fun one to leave for the next DJ if you don't like him/her.

i think i also have one that plays one groove in the correct
direction and right alongside it is another groove that plays
in reverse.  that's a real mind-twister for sure.

fyi, most (if not all) of my "DJ tools" records aren't infinite
loops, but are finite-timed tracks that are boring and
repetitive.  good for a transition, but i've found that i
haven't used them too often.

m

----- Original Message ----
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Wednesday, February 6, 2008 11:16:34 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] records with loops


DJ Swamp has a series of locked-groove records called
"Neverending Breakbeats"

The Speedy J album "Loudboxer" is a perennial favorite
made up of two records with 50 locked grooves per
side.  

You can usually find locked groove collections in the
Tools/Scratch/Battle section of your favorite rekkid
shop

Or just do a google or ebay search for "locked groove"
and you'll find stuff.

An interesting discussion of locked groove rekkids can
be found here:

http://www.kempa.com/blog/archives/000046.html

Seinfeld episode 166, production code 910 "The Strike"

http://www.sonypictures.com/tv/shows/seinfeld/episode_guide/?sl=episode&ep=910

Seinfeld ever.  We celebrate Festivus at my office
each year.

with Sheep on Drugs and Hip House. STML has had a long career in the DJ 
scene from Capetown to London as a DJ and collaborator in the acid 
techno scene there.  Currently STML is a key member of DEF and with him

of the defsf.com site. word.

FnF parties, Harmony parties, DEF parties and, dare i say it, even

bastions of techno in the bay area and kept it real. This friday we're 
looking forward to a Dj set by one of the people that continues to 
remain synonymous with techno in the bay area, Andy W! (applause)

"I'd have to disagree with you in part, the country was founded on the
principles of freedom and liberty . . . "

Well, for everyone but the slaves.

Read some history guy. You cannot say that a country where only white people
were free was founded on the principles of freedom and liberty.

Well, I mean, you can say that, but you'd be wrong.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Slavery is mentioned (implied, really) twice in the Constitution, one  
was modified by the 14th amendment and the other had a time limit set  
on it to the year 1808, letting someone in the future to argue over  
it.  So really, for all intents and purposes, implied once.

What does that have to do with the Bill of Rights and the rest of the  
Constitution, which was clearly written with many levels of checks  
and balances and the Tenth amendment, which clearly states that all  
powers not enumerated to the government reside in the people?

------=_Part_31080_2283755.1202431323121
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It has to do with who 'the people' are. Guaranteeing freedom to white people
and allowing everyone else to be murdered/enslaved/raped/whatever, isn't
really basing anything in the country on freedom and liberty so much as
paying lip service to the ideas so that people like you will buy into that
'America is the greatest country in the world' bullshit. Let me give you
some advice. America is no more the greatest country in the world than my
cock is the biggest cock in the world. Divorce yourself from that idea, and
it's pretty plain to see that freedom and liberty have no more meaning here
than they do anywhere else.

You can believe whatever you want, but the fact of the matter is that the US
as a nation was built on the backs of oppressed peoples everywhere. At best
you could say that this country was founded on the ideas of freedom and
liberty for white people. But that's not really saying a whole lot, is it?
Was the Roman Republic a free nation? Sure. If you weren't a plebiscite, or
a slave, it was free as hell. It's the same thing here. If you're not poor
and brown, sure, America is a free ass country. Otherwise, not so much.

Do you really think American slavery ended with the Emancipation
Proclamation? It didn't, it was just made less obvious. Don't even get me
started on the genocide of the Indigenous Peoples that allowed for enough
white people even to be here to start a country in the first place.

The US is a decent place to live (well, some parts, anyway), but don't go
around acting like (or thinking) that it's special, or different from any
other country in the world. It's not, it was founded by flawed people with
flawed ideas and continues to be run by flawed people with flawed ideas.
Just like every other fucking place on earth.

On Feb 7, 2008 4:02 PM, Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:

> Slavery is mentioned (implied, really) twice in the Constitution, one
> was modified by the 14th amendment and the other had a time limit set
> on it to the year 1808, letting someone in the future to argue over
> it.  So really, for all intents and purposes, implied once.
>
> What does that have to do with the Bill of Rights and the rest of the
> Constitution, which was clearly written with many levels of checks
> and balances and the Tenth amendment, which clearly states that all
> powers not enumerated to the government reside in the people?
>
>
> On Feb 7, 2008, at 1:13 PM, pinkko wrote:
>
> > "I'd have to disagree with you in part, the country was founded on the
> > principles of freedom and liberty . . . "
> >
> > Well, for everyone but the slaves.
> >
> > Read some history guy. You cannot say that a country where only
> > white people
> > were free was founded on the principles of freedom and liberty.
> >
> > Well, I mean, you can say that, but you'd be wrong.
> >
> > On Feb 7, 2008 11:55 AM, Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:
> >
> >> I'd have to disagree with you in part, the country was founded on the
> >> principles of freedom and liberty, but has over and over been
> >> hijacked by those who hate it and seek to destroy all freedom and
> >> liberty.  That doesn't mean we just give up and let them win.
> >>
> >>
> >> On Feb 7, 2008, at 9:49 AM, pinkko wrote:
> >>
> >>> This country has been about a lot of things, but freedom was never
> >>> one of
> >>> them.
> >>>
> >>> On Feb 7, 2008 10:33 AM, Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:
> >>>
> >>>> --
> >>>>
> >>>> The guy takes a risk, let him go to the clinic. What about freedom?

> >>>>
> >>>> - Pat Buchanan

FWIW, I already knew about these devices...I was talking about doing a performance from a unit the size of an iPod not plugging the iPod into something that lets you mix.  But these actually already exist too.   I'm on the waiting list for one of them, the Pacemaker, so I wrote that somewhat tongue in cheek.  I'm not sure I'm going to actually order one however, but here's the scoop in case you or anyone else hasn't seen this little gadget:

http://www.pacemaker.net

Best,

Peter

Here's one:
http://sanfrancisco.tribe.net/event/a0aca3f5-bb64-493f-9dd1-0d026ec2566c

Date & Time: 2008-02-09 9:00 PM
Location: The Connecticut Yankee


We're baa-ack! Hair of the Dog, the most rockingest bar on the playa,
takes over the Connecticut Yankee in SF for another evening of dancing
and merry-making on Saturday, Feb. 9.

The evening will feature live music from HOTD house bands (FWIW: I'm in 
both Curly and the Reverberators):

Gomer Hendrix
The Reverberators
Curly
And the first live performance of Larry: The Musical

Performances start around 10pm. Come out early if you want a good 
dinner. The Yankee serves up some great grub.

Come on out and support local live music and the camp that has been 
bringing live music to the playa since 2000!

We hope to see you there


Posted by: Billy D

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

I found this quote last night sifting through news links.  This  
touches on a whole range of opinions that are not discussed in the  
government training camps (schools and universities).

--

Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation is a dubious document that has  
been widely touted as having "freed the slaves." It didn't. It was  
aimed at the slaves in Confederate territory where Lincoln had no  
legal authority. Slaves in both states and territory controlled by Mr.  
Lincoln's dictatorial regime remained firmly in bondage until the 13th  
Amendment freed them, several months after Mr. Lincoln's demise. Even  
Lincoln, himself, admitted the proclamation was a war measure and  
probably would not have passed any sort of constitutional muster. So  
who did it really free? No one, that's who. It was never intended to  
"free" anyone. It was excellent propaganda and that was it. Period!

- Al Benson, Jr.

Message-ID: <701418.72300.qm@web32414.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

Neil needs to go to a rave.

I don't know if one song can end a war, and I'm not sure where that idea ever came from, but that does not equate to music having no effect in the world. 

I think he's getting old (we all do) and tired.  And maybe also a bit discouraged.  I think he's looking mainly at rock and roll culture which has clearly been overtaken by corporations and is ruled by greed heads that will turn even the most purely political song into a sell out if they see a way to make a buck.  See the endless stream of BlankAid concerts that are really more about business as usual (seeling records, promoting bands) than they are about aiding anyone.

I think it is quite hard to observe and measure progress when things change slowly.  And it is discouraging sometimes to realize just how slowly things change.

But that doesn't mean that progress isn't happening, or that things can't get better, or that music has no effect on politics.

Best,

Peter

Historical perspective/context -

After the murder of 4 students at Kent State University by the National Guard
at the height of the Vietnam War - Neil wrote a song called "Ohio" - 
which was recorded
and released within DAYS of the murders - it was an instant # 1 
across the board hit -
some of the chorus of the song has the lyrics "We can change the 
world - rearrange the world"
which is what I am sure he was referring to in his comments - music 
has not had the kind
of impact that single did - in a very very long time.

Subject: [sfraves] .::BSP Dirty Techno night On Radio Integrated::.

Tonight on Radio Integrated:

DJ STML aka Sean's Techno Music Library DEF(defsf.com)

Sean (not me) hails originally from South Africa and originally started 
out as a punk rock musician who got turned on to acid house early on 
with Sheep on Drugs and Hip House. STML has had a long career in the DJ 
scene from Capetown to London as a DJ and collaborator in the acid 
techno scene there.  Currently STML is a key member of DEF and with him 
on board we expect to see great things come about in the coming versions 
of the defsf.com site. word.

and the mentalist hard techno pounding of Andy W aka Mutor Soundsystem, 
Dobox records, Resource records

Andy W has been there and back and held up his end of the techno scene 
for more than a decade. Known for his sets at the Cloudfactory parties, 
FnF parties, Harmony parties, DEF parties and, dare i say it, even 
Skills parties when they were playing techno, Andy has been one of the 
bastions of techno in the bay area and kept it real. This friday we're 
looking forward to a Dj set by one of the people that continues to 
remain synonymous with techno in the bay area, Andy W! (applause)

Last minute Add! Thomas B Basswaves, FnF will be  dropping by with his 
newest original material, you heard it here first.


Tune in at http://www.zer01.net:1200/
Every Friday from 9pm - 1AM PST

Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com

next week 2.15.:
its fukinn awesome techno night with the sounds of

DJ Alex Windsor

If anybody's ever seen Alex in action you know what a great talent he 
has for the wheels of steel and a great sense of flow and mastery he has 
for them. Originally from London, UK, Alex has been instrumental in the 
San Francisco Techno (with a capital T) scene here since 1992 as a 
partner in the Gaia Mantra Record store in SF and as a promoter and 
resident of MAD mondays.. for those of you who don't know, MAD used to 
be where it was at for Techno in SF from 95-97 Giving voice to the early 
SF minimal techno scene and showcasing techno that would probably had 
been not heard anywhere else in the city at the time. Alex's skills have 
taken him all across the globe, from the US to Japan, and the UK. He has 
played alongside the likes of Aphex Twin, the Shamen, Orbital, Carl 
Craig, Richie hawtin, Moby, Mr.C, Juan Atkins, Mark Broom, & Dave Clarke 
to name a few.... He's Dj'd at parties here in SF by crews with such 
infamously dope names names as FnF, Harmony, Area 51, Tribal Future, 
Gateway, Brass Tax , Future &  more undergrounds than my short term 
memory loss can muster.
Dj Perla
    Perla has appeared on Radio Integrated before and totally has rocked 
it with his own live material.. Perla originally hails from southern 
spain where he helped promote his Dance Usted parties or, 'Dance Please' 
As bulletproof and flawless as his original tracks are, his selection 
skills are equally unbeatable. we are pleased to welcome Perla back this 
time for a special dj set of his pick of tracks that have been 
influencing him and shaping his current sound to date.  ... `;)

subscribe to def announce for your techno fix!
def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com


 
TECHN<3!

sean ocean

X-YMail-OSG: khct2ngVM1kreU6mpvtUBwq_c5w6oK.ir7IgRMxSLhVIoSmWeqWvHv_btTKEPuYYL7FTuQEAxB3w63i8Zu0DiQPctHBO9XoS0YQGgqN_uySlq_lGONTZ2wf5Ag--
X-Mailer: YahooMailRC/818.31 YahooMailWebService/0.7.162
Date: Fri, 8 Feb 2008 20:36:45 -0800 (PST)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>,
  "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>, SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <468734.831.qm@web32403.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

I know the song...

I was alive then actually tho I was a little kid.  

There were many factors that led to the end of the Vietnam War, and the conflict with the counter culture, and youth culture more generally, at home as exemplified in *Ohio* was only one of them.  And the Song *Ohio* was only one of many anti-war, anti-establishment, and anti-government songs of that era.  True *Ohio* came out just days after the shootings at Kent State, an event which turned many who were previously on the fence against the government at the time.  I am sure that many felt that *Ohio* perfectly captured the emotion and zetgeist of that moment.  However to attribute this to the song rather than the events is revisionist at best.  Certainly the song didn't end the Vietnam War single handedly by any reasonable assessment.  So I don't get the surprise or dismay that there isn't such a "war ending song" today.  

Best,

Peter

Subject: [sfraves] Tonight on Radio Integrated : Andy W, Thomas B, DJ STML : 2.08.08

------=_Part_2475_28519859.1202533620352
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's that happy time of the week again... Time for another edition of Radio
Integrated!

Right now (9pm Pacific Standard Time) DJ Disconnect is playing a little warm
up set before our first guest, Thomas B, arrives. We'll also have some music
from Andy W and DJ STML, so stay tuned!  More info below, read on....

Tune in at http://www.zer01.net:1200/
Every Friday from 9pm - 1AM PST

Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
* * * * * * * * * *

Tonight on Radio Integrated::: Friday, February 8th, 2008:::...

DJ STML aka Sean's Techno Music Library DEF(defsf.com)

Sean STML hails from South Africa and originally started
out as a punk rock musician who got turned on to acid house early on
with Sheep on Drugs and Hip House. STML has had a long career in the DJ
scene from Capetown to London as a DJ and collaborator in the acid
techno scene.  Currently STML is a key member of DEF and with him
on board we expect to see great things come about in the coming versions
of the defsf.com site. word.


Andy W has been there and back and held up his end of the techno scene
for more than a decade. Known for his sets at the Cloudfactory parties,
FnF parties, Harmony parties, DEF parties and, dare I say it, even
Skills parties when they were playing techno, Andy has been one of the
bastions of techno in the bay area and kept it real. This friday we're
looking forward to a DJ set by one of the people that continues to
remain synonymous with techno in the bay area, Andy W! (applause)

*Last minute Add! Thomas B (Basswaves, FnF) will be  dropping by with a live
set of his
newest original material, you heard it here first.


Tune in at http://www.zer01.net:1200/
Every Friday from 9pm - 1AM PST

Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
* * * * * * * * * *

next week 2.15.:
its fukinn awesome techno night with the sounds of

DJ Alex Windsor

If anybody's ever seen Alex in action you know what a talent he
has for the wheels of steel and a great sense of flow and mastery he has
for them. Originally from London, UK, Alex has been instrumental in the
San Francisco Techno (with a capital T) scene here since 1992 as a
partner in the Gaia Mantra Record store in SF and as a promoter and
resident of MAD mondays.. for those of you who don't know, MAD used to
be where it was at for Techno in SF from 95-97 Giving voice to the early
SF minimal techno scene and showcasing techno that would probably had
been not heard anywhere else in the city at the time. Alex's skills have
taken him all across the globe, from the US to Japan, and the UK. He has
played alongside the likes of Aphex Twin, the Shamen, Orbital, Carl
Craig, Richie Hawtin, Moby, Mr.C, Juan Atkins, Mark Broom, & Dave Clarke
to name a few.... He's DJed at parties here in SF by crews with such
infamously dope names names as FnF, Harmony, Area 51, Tribal Future,
Gateway, Brass Tax , Future &  more undergrounds than my short term
memory loss can muster.

DJ Perla

   Perla has appeared on Radio Integrated before and totally has rocked
it with his own live material.. Perla originally hails from Southern
Spain where he helped promote his Dance Usted parties or, 'Dance Please.'
As bulletproof and flawless as his original tracks are, his selection
skills are equally unbeatable. We are pleased to welcome Perla back this
time for a special DJset of his pick of tracks that have been
influencing him and shaping his current sound to date.  ... `;)

subscribe to def announce for your techno fix!
def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com

http://www.zer01.net:1200/

radiointegrated@gmail.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

--------------010302090100030804030807
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

When my GF's childhood gymnastic tutors in Portola Valley retired to 
move to Hawaii, Neil, being a plugged in local, showed up for the 
ceremony. I made a point of not interacting in the parking lot after, 
but I did note that he tools around in Woodside in a pretty funky circa 
1970s Woody station wagon. And maybe music can't stop wars, but judging 
by what I saw at the annual Bridge School Concerts at Shoreline, it can 
be a positive force for good, so I'm thinking Neil said all that because 
he's getting older and crankier.

His "Freedom" album, (which you may be most familiar with from Michael 
Moore's Fahrenheit 9/!! credit roll), along with Big Audio Dynamite, (my 
musical introduction to that thing called 'teh rave' from across the 
pond), helped keep my sanity during my last 2 years in the USMC.

I was in Dayton in mid 1979 helping organize a local cannabis smoke-in 
with what was left of the Yippies, and even though I was too young at 
the time to appreciate the gravity of what happened there I can report 
today that less than a decade out the wounds of Kent State were very 
fresh among the activists there, and Ohio was played more than once 
during my stay there, and for them it was a bit more than just a song 
playing on the radio.

As far as music being co-opted by politicians goes, you'd be hard 
pressed to to do better than to find Rudy Ghouliani using The Clash's 
"Rudy Can't Fail" as his campaign's version of "Hail To The Chief" every 
time he entered a room.

Unless, of course, you've got Governor Iron Mike Huckabee playing bass 
on one of the greatest anti-war anthems of the 1960s.

Creedence Clearwater's, (btw, not a Southern bunch of hick shit-kicker 
rockers, but an El Cerrito, (birthplace of 420), CA, band. Go figure. 
You can look it up),:

"Fortunate Son".

http://video.aol.com/video-detail/capitol-offense-fortunate-son/2230602459

You can't make this shit up.

That, and its a pretty good cover, to boot.

.
.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> I know the song...
>
> I was alive then actually tho I was a little kid.  
>
> There were many factors that led to the end of the Vietnam War, and the conflict with the counter culture, and youth culture more generally, at home as exemplified in *Ohio* was only one of them.  And the Song *Ohio* was only one of many anti-war, anti-establishment, and anti-government songs of that era.  True *Ohio* came out just days after the shootings at Kent State, an event which turned many who were previously on the fence against the government at the time.  I am sure that many felt that *Ohio* perfectly captured the emotion and zetgeist of that moment.  However to attribute this to the song rather than the events is revisionist at best.  Certainly the song didn't end the Vietnam War single handedly by any reasonable assessment.  So I don't get the surprise or dismay that there isn't such a "war ending song" today.  
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>; SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Friday, February 8, 2008 4:56:25 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young
>
>
> Historical perspective/context -
>
> After the murder of 4 students at Kent State University by the National Guard
> at the height of the Vietnam War - Neil wrote a song called "Ohio" - 
> which was recorded
> and released within DAYS of the murders - it was an instant # 1 
> across the board hit -
> some of the chorus of the song has the lyrics "We can change the 
> world - rearrange the world"
> which is what I am sure he was referring to in his comments - music 
> has not had the kind
> of impact that single did - in a very very long time.
>
>
>
> At 04:44 PM 2/8/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>   
>> Neil needs to go to a rave.
>>
>> I don't know if one song can end a war, and I'm not sure where that 
>> idea ever came from, but that does not equate to music having no 
>> effect in the world.
>>
>> I think he's getting old (we all do) and tired.  And maybe also a 
>> bit discouraged.  I think he's looking mainly at rock and roll 
>> culture which has clearly been overtaken by corporations and is 
>> ruled by greed heads that will turn even the most purely political 
>> song into a sell out if they see a way to make a buck.  See the 
>> endless stream of BlankAid concerts that are really more about 
>> business as usual (seeling records, promoting bands) than they are 
>> about aiding anyone.
>>
>> I think it is quite hard to observe and measure progress when things 
>> change slowly.  And it is discouraging sometimes to realize just how 
>> slowly things change.
>>
>> But that doesn't mean that progress isn't happening, or that things 
>> can't get better, or that music has no effect on politics.
>>
>> Best,
>>
>> Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

Just saying it was the shootings that turned people against the government and galvanized the peace movement not the song.  The Russian revolution would have happened even if "The International" was never written I think.  (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationale ) But certainly a good song can encourage people or amplify an emotion and perhaps thereby contribute to a movement.  But I can't think of an example where a movement was started by a song alone.   Unless maybe it was The Macarena ;)

Intreresting story about Dayton...ever go to the Pine Club?  I went there many times when I did work at WPAFB.  Strong mixed drinks, a great steak, and cheesebread.  Midwest cuisine ats best!

And FWIW I grew up in north Berkeley not far from EC.  The Fantasy Records building was in Berkeley on Spruce I believe.  We used to stop and smoke on these sort of large open steps they have there sometimes when we walked home from parties sort of in homage.  This was during that same era, the late 70s, although in Berkeley at that time you heard more punk than Creedence.  But we still heard a lot of hippy rhetoric this being Berkeley and all.  Some of it turned out to be right!

But by this time it was more about White Punks On Dope than Peace & Love & taking care of nature.  It was "how far can you go?", not "where are you going?".

In my experience anyway...

Best,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
Cc: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>; SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, February 8, 2008 9:18:07 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

When my GF's childhood gymnastic tutors in Portola Valley retired to 
move to Hawaii, Neil, being a plugged in local, showed up for the 
ceremony. I made a point of not interacting in the parking lot after, 
but I did note that he tools around in Woodside in a pretty funky circa 
1970s Woody station wagon. And maybe music can't stop wars, but judging 
by what I saw at the annual Bridge School Concerts at Shoreline, it can 
be a positive force for good, so I'm thinking Neil said all that because 
he's getting older and crankier.

His "Freedom" album, (which you may be most familiar with from Michael 
Moore's Fahrenheit 9/!! credit roll), along with Big Audio Dynamite, (my 
musical introduction to that thing called 'teh rave' from across the 
pond), helped keep my sanity during my last 2 years in the USMC.

I was in Dayton in mid 1979 helping organize a local cannabis smoke-in 
with what was left of the Yippies, and even though I was too young at 
the time to appreciate the gravity of what happened there I can report 
today that less than a decade out the wounds of Kent State were very 
fresh among the activists there, and Ohio was played more than once 
during my stay there, and for them it was a bit more than just a song 
playing on the radio.

As far as music being co-opted by politicians goes, you'd be hard 
pressed to to do better than to find Rudy Ghouliani using The Clash's 
"Rudy Can't Fail" as his campaign's version of "Hail To The Chief" every 
time he entered a room.

Unless, of course, you've got Governor Iron Mike Huckabee playing bass 
on one of the greatest anti-war anthems of the 1960s.

Creedence Clearwater's, (btw, not a Southern bunch of hick shit-kicker 
rockers, but an El Cerrito, (birthplace of 420), CA, band. Go figure. 
You can look it up),:

"Fortunate Son".

http://video.aol.com/video-detail/capitol-offense-fortunate-son/2230602459

You can't make this shit up.

That, and its a pretty good cover, to boot.

.
.

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> I know the song...
>
> I was alive then actually tho I was a little kid.  
>
> There were many factors that led to the end of the Vietnam War, and the conflict with the counter culture, and youth culture more generally, at home as exemplified in *Ohio* was only one of them.  And the Song *Ohio* was only one of many anti-war, anti-establishment, and anti-government songs of that era.  True *Ohio* came out just days after the shootings at Kent State, an event which turned many who were previously on the fence against the government at the time.  I am sure that many felt that *Ohio* perfectly captured the emotion and zetgeist of that moment.  However to attribute this to the song rather than the events is revisionist at best.  Certainly the song didn't end the Vietnam War single handedly by any reasonable assessment.  So I don't get the surprise or dismay that there isn't such a "war ending song" today.  
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>; SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Friday, February 8, 2008 4:56:25 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young
>
>
> Historical perspective/context -
>
> After the murder of 4 students at Kent State University by the National Guard
> at the height of the Vietnam War - Neil wrote a song called "Ohio" - 
> which was recorded
> and released within DAYS of the murders - it was an instant # 1 
> across the board hit -
> some of the chorus of the song has the lyrics "We can change the 
> world - rearrange the world"
> which is what I am sure he was referring to in his comments - music 
> has not had the kind
> of impact that single did - in a very very long time.
>
>
>
> At 04:44 PM 2/8/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>  
>> Neil needs to go to a rave.
>>
>> I don't know if one song can end a war, and I'm not sure where that 
>> idea ever came from, but that does not equate to music having no 
>> effect in the world.
>>
>> I think he's getting old (we all do) and tired.  And maybe also a 
>> bit discouraged.  I think he's looking mainly at rock and roll 
>> culture which has clearly been overtaken by corporations and is 
>> ruled by greed heads that will turn even the most purely political 
>> song into a sell out if they see a way to make a buck.  See the 
>> endless stream of BlankAid concerts that are really more about 
>> business as usual (seeling records, promoting bands) than they are 
>> about aiding anyone.
>>
>> I think it is quite hard to observe and measure progress when things 
>> change slowly.  And it is discouraging sometimes to realize just how 
>> slowly things change.
>>
>> But that doesn't mean that progress isn't happening, or that things 
>> can't get better, or that music has no effect on politics.
>>
>> Best,
>>
>> Peter
>>
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

Neil Young just reissued "Live at Massey Hall, 1971":

http://www.amazon.com/Live-at-Massey-Hall-1971/dp/B000MTPANG

This was recorded less than a year after Kent State, and just before his 
classic "Harvest" album came out. The venue is his native Ontario, Canada, 
just Neil on guitar or piano. You can feel the love from the crowd. Highly 
recommended.

On 8 February 2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Just saying it was the shootings that turned people against the 
> government and galvanized the peace movement not the song.  The 
> Russian revolution would have happened even if "The International" was 
> never written I think.  (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationale ) 
> But certainly a good song can encourage people or amplify an emotion 
> and perhaps thereby contribute to a movement.  But I can't think of an 
> example where a movement was started by a song alone.  Unless maybe it 
> was The Macarena ;)

I participate in this week long bike ride across the state of Iowa every 
year.  And one year, during the height of the Macarena craze, I started 
to use the fact of hearnig that song a SECOND time to determine that I 
was in town too long.  The shortest stretch??? 30 MINUTES. Yikes!

But back to the impact a SONG had on ending the vietnam war; don't you 
suppose THE DRAFT might have had a bit higher impact??

From sfraves-return-144798-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Feb 09 16:44:29 2008

At 10:01 PM 2/8/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>Just saying it was the shootings that turned people against the 
>government and galvanized the peace movement not the song.  The 
>Russian revolution would have happened even if "The International" 
>was never written I 
>think.  (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationale ) But certainly 
>a good song can encourage people or amplify an emotion and perhaps 
>thereby contribute to a movement.  But I can't think of an example 
>where a movement was started by a song alone.   Unless maybe it was 
>The Macarena ;)
>
>Intreresting story about Dayton...ever go to the Pine Club?  I went 
>there many times when I did work at WPAFB.  Strong mixed drinks, a 
>great steak, and cheesebread.  Midwest cuisine ats best!
>
>And FWIW I grew up in north Berkeley not far from EC.  The Fantasy 
>Records building was in Berkeley on Spruce I believe.  We used to 
>stop and smoke on these sort of large open steps they have there 
>sometimes when we walked home from parties sort of in homage.  This 
>was during that same era, the late 70s, although in Berkeley at that 
>time you heard more punk than Creedence.  But we still heard a lot 
>of hippy rhetoric this being Berkeley and all.  Some of it turned 
>out to be right!
>
>But by this time it was more about White Punks On Dope than Peace & 
>Love & taking care of nature.  It was "how far can you go?", not 
>"where are you going?".
>
>In my experience anyway...
>
>Best,
>
>Peter
>
>----- Original Message ----
>From: Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
>To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
>Cc: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>; SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Friday, February 8, 2008 9:18:07 PM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young
>
>When my GF's childhood gymnastic tutors in Portola Valley retired to
>move to Hawaii, Neil, being a plugged in local, showed up for the
>ceremony. I made a point of not interacting in the parking lot after,
>but I did note that he tools around in Woodside in a pretty funky circa
>1970s Woody station wagon. And maybe music can't stop wars, but judging
>by what I saw at the annual Bridge School Concerts at Shoreline, it can
>be a positive force for good, so I'm thinking Neil said all that because
>he's getting older and crankier.
>
>His "Freedom" album, (which you may be most familiar with from Michael
>Moore's Fahrenheit 9/!! credit roll), along with Big Audio Dynamite, (my
>musical introduction to that thing called 'teh rave' from across the
>pond), helped keep my sanity during my last 2 years in the USMC.
>
>I was in Dayton in mid 1979 helping organize a local cannabis smoke-in
>with what was left of the Yippies, and even though I was too young at
>the time to appreciate the gravity of what happened there I can report
>today that less than a decade out the wounds of Kent State were very
>fresh among the activists there, and Ohio was played more than once
>during my stay there, and for them it was a bit more than just a song
>playing on the radio.
>
>As far as music being co-opted by politicians goes, you'd be hard
>pressed to to do better than to find Rudy Ghouliani using The Clash's
>"Rudy Can't Fail" as his campaign's version of "Hail To The Chief" every
>time he entered a room.
>
>Unless, of course, you've got Governor Iron Mike Huckabee playing bass
>on one of the greatest anti-war anthems of the 1960s.
>
>Creedence Clearwater's, (btw, not a Southern bunch of hick shit-kicker
>rockers, but an El Cerrito, (birthplace of 420), CA, band. Go figure.
>You can look it up),:
>
>"Fortunate Son".
>
>http://video.aol.com/video-detail/capitol-offense-fortunate-son/2230602459
>
>You can't make this shit up.
>
>That, and its a pretty good cover, to boot.
>
>.
>.
>
>dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> > I know the song...
> >
> > I was alive then actually tho I was a little kid.
> >
> > There were many factors that led to the end of the Vietnam War, 
> and the conflict with the counter culture, and youth culture more 
> generally, at home as exemplified in *Ohio* was only one of 
> them.  And the Song *Ohio* was only one of many anti-war, 
> anti-establishment, and anti-government songs of that era.  True 
> *Ohio* came out just days after the shootings at Kent State, an 
> event which turned many who were previously on the fence against 
> the government at the time.  I am sure that many felt that *Ohio* 
> perfectly captured the emotion and zetgeist of that 
> moment.  However to attribute this to the song rather than the 
> events is revisionist at best.  Certainly the song didn't end the 
> Vietnam War single handedly by any reasonable assessment.  So I 
> don't get the surprise or dismay that there isn't such a "war 
> ending song" today.
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Peter
> >
> >
> > ----- Original Message ----
> > From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>

> >
> >
> > Historical perspective/context -
> >
> > After the murder of 4 students at Kent State University by the 
> National Guard
> > at the height of the Vietnam War - Neil wrote a song called "Ohio" -
> > which was recorded
> > and released within DAYS of the murders - it was an instant # 1
> > across the board hit -
> > some of the chorus of the song has the lyrics "We can change the
> > world - rearrange the world"
> > which is what I am sure he was referring to in his comments - music
> > has not had the kind
> > of impact that single did - in a very very long time.
> >
> >
> >
> > At 04:44 PM 2/8/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> >
> >> Neil needs to go to a rave.
> >>
> >> I don't know if one song can end a war, and I'm not sure where that
> >> idea ever came from, but that does not equate to music having no
> >> effect in the world.
> >>
> >> I think he's getting old (we all do) and tired.  And maybe also a
> >> bit discouraged.  I think he's looking mainly at rock and roll
> >> culture which has clearly been overtaken by corporations and is
> >> ruled by greed heads that will turn even the most purely political
> >> song into a sell out if they see a way to make a buck.  See the
> >> endless stream of BlankAid concerts that are really more about
> >> business as usual (seeling records, promoting bands) than they are
> >> about aiding anyone.
> >>
> >> I think it is quite hard to observe and measure progress when things
> >> change slowly.  And it is discouraging sometimes to realize just how
> >> slowly things change.
> >>
> >> But that doesn't mean that progress isn't happening, or that things
> >> can't get better, or that music has no effect on politics.

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

Speaking as someone that had John Phillip Souza Marches rammed down his 
throat as a child, as well as got slapped around almost daily with our 
National Anthem, (a re-purposed British drinking song, written by one of 
my fellow alumns at the Neo-Con U. that Leo Strauss died at, the only 
other claim to fame my College has, besides the founder of Atlantic 
Records starting that company in his dorm room), France's Le Marseilles, 
and the aforementioned The Internationale, by my whack-job East German 
raised moms, I'd say that music an incredibly powerful force, and that 
the governments and corporations of the world are much more than aware 
of the fact of the power of that force than we seem to be, since not 
only do they use it to their advantage to manipulate people into buying 
their crap products and going off to die in their wars, but any time 
music comes along that they feel might be a threat to them they'll do 
their damndest to co-opt it (see: Hip-Hop/Rap), or drive it out of 
existence (see: The RAVE Act II).

What, did you really think it was the 'chill-rooms' that had these folks 
worried?

Actually, due to 'chill-rooms' being where people exercise their right 
to 'freely assemble', that's the thing they really don't like, because 
unlike in a Sports Arena where everyone is facing one way, and not 
communicating with each other, past root-root-rooting for the Home Team, 
people in 'chill-rooms' actually look each other in the eye and talk to 
one another. That wouldn't happen if there wasn't the music to bring 
them there, so our government went out of its way to nip that shit in 
the bud.

Did a bang-up job of it, too, since you're more likely today in the USA 
to hear EDM in a Stupid Ugly Vehicle TV commercial than to be able to 
find a decent renegade UG Party to go to tonight.

Can you say "Mission Accomplished"?
I know you can.

It's been said that good music comes from hard times, (see: Nirvana, 
Woody Guthrie, the 1960s, R&B, etc, etc), and being that we're not in a 
recession, but at the very start of an unacknowledged Second Great 
American Depression, I expect these musical arts to flower and come into 
full bloom very shortly.

But yh, if you want to have some rilly GREAT music, I say bring back Teh 
Military Draft and it'll make your head spin as to how great the toonage 
becomes overnight and how quickly people will lose interest in American 
Idol.

.
.
J.C. wrote:
> On 8 February 2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

>> contribute to a movement.  But I can't think of an example where a 
>> movement was started by a song alone.  Unless maybe it was The 
>> Macarena ;)
>
> I participate in this week long bike ride across the state of Iowa 
> every year.  And one year, during the height of the Macarena craze, I 
> started to use the fact of hearnig that song a SECOND time to 
> determine that I was in town too long.  The shortest stretch??? 30 
> MINUTES. Yikes!
>
> But back to the impact a SONG had on ending the vietnam war; don't you 
> suppose THE DRAFT might have had a bit higher impact??
>
> [SSNNIIPP]

Sarilion wrote:
> RAVE act was about as successful as the war on drugs.
> sarilion
.
.
I dunno, I'd say The War On Drugs has been mad successful when you 
consider the following....

750,000+ arrests a year for just marijuana alone, which keeps a lot of 
cops, judges, probation officers and prisons in fine feather, just to 
name a few entities that economically benefit from those arrests, a 
non-stop, multi-billion dollar a year, money-making, predatorial, Drug & 
Alcohol Re-Hab Industry, (that will *never* go out of business), that 
has an annual fail rate of 90%, but still manages to have new people 
coming in the door, each, and everyday, (See: Kirsten Dunst and every 
Drug Court Ordered "Client" for next 10 years), millions of dollars a 
month landing in 12 Step Recovery baskets, just in the USA alone, as 
well as Big Book and other ancilliary Recovery product sales, a price 
mark-up on the production and distribution costs of street drugs in the 
5,000% range, with marijuana retailing at very near up to $10K a pound 
for the Primo Shit, and a population that's so deluded by the barrage of 
media telling them that drugs are bad that they're never, never, ever 
going to see it another way.

What's really Teh Awesome is when the kids buy into this shit wholesale, 
(because they're too young to know any better and the cable TV got to 
them first), and snitch on Mommy & Daddy's pot smoking to the Police and 
The State gets to destroy that family:
http://www.druglibrary.org/schaffer/Library/dare4.htm

Don't you think that that kind of shit makes our Drug Warriors not only 
positively blush, but wet their pants with unbridled glee?

Try putting yourself in their shoes, for a spell, if you think different.

Now, it while it may be true that there are no recorded fatalities from 
marijuana use, there is at least one case on record where fear of arrest 
over a dime bag of pot killed a guy: 
http://edition.cnn.com/2003/US/Southwest/11/20/marijuana.death.ap/

And while we're at it, Civil Asset Forfeiture is nice work too, if you 
can get it.
http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v99.n1252.a01.html
Short version, be caught with one sapling growing in your home for 
personal use, say Goodbye, McMansion.

The attendant erosion of our Civil Rights was probably nothing more an 
unexpected bonus to these people.

With all that, I'd have to say that these War On Drugs guys are doing 
alright for themselves.

Ya know what I mean, Vern?

.
.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <998209.37750.qm@web32402.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Music cannot change the world, says Neil Young

Amazing just how fucked my memory of this location was...OK, its been about 30 years but after you corrected me I looked on the map and had a sort of strange experience of vertigo as my rusty mental map of Berkeley slowly creaked into proper alignment.  

And a strange memory came back to me of a party I went to on Parker back in 9th grade, and then kissing this girl on the steps of Fantasy.  I don't remember her name this morning, but I remember the kiss and the fact that she moved to Florida the next week and I never saw her again.

Best,

Peter

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: FISA and retroactive telecom immunity

>From another list, but I agree fully.

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Hey guys,

Sorry if this seems generic, but I feel very strongly about this
issue, and it's a tough one to sound-bite so I'm providing links
rather than explanations (again).

The Senate is voting again tomorrow (Tuesday Feb 12th) on whether to
pass the FISA reauthorization bill which includes retroactive immunity
for telecoms turning over information to the bush administration
without a warrant.  PLEASE CALL your senators and representatives to
tell them you DO NOT WANT THIS BILL PASSED WITH RETROACTIVE IMMUNITY
NO MATTER WHAT.

Below is a link to a bulleted list regarding what the bill does for
corporations and the Bush administration and why we MUST not allow our
representatives to pass this bill:

http://www.drummajorinstitute.org/library/article.php?ID=6680

Please spread this around, people need to know what their senators are
doing in their name!

Below is an article explaining more about FISA from Senator Russ
Feingold:

http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/1/17/104227/863/70/438259

You can find your senators contact information here:

http://www.senate.gov/general/contact_information/senators_cfm.cfm

Below are the phone numbers of the senators who have so far voted for
retroactive immunity on earlier versions of this bill, please call
them and (politely) urge them to respect the Constitution, the
judicial branch of government, and the separation of powers and do not
let this bill go through!

Bayh (202) 224-5623 phone, (202) 228-1377 fax
Byrd (202) 224-3954 phone, (202) 228-0002 fax
Carper (202) 224-2441 phone, (202) 228-2190 fax
Feinstein (202) 224-3841 phone, (202) 228-3954 fax

	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Breaking the Drug Taboo: Group of Traumatized Veterans Get  
Experimental Ecstasy Treatment
By Scott Thill, AlterNet
Posted on February 11, 2008, Printed on February 11, 2008
http://www.alternet.org/story/76576/

"We need to be positioning ourselves now to provide the assistance  
that our veterans need," said House Committee on Veterans' Affairs  
chairman Bob Filner (D-CA) during a hearing, called "Stopping  
Suicides: Examining the Mental Health Challenges Facing the Department  
of Veterans Affairs," held in December 2007. "Not only for those brave  
men and women who are returning home from Iraq and Afghanistan, but  
also for our veterans from previous conflicts. We cannot afford to put  
this issue off."

Filner's choice of words is instructive, as are his sentiments: With  
upwards of 25 million veterans in the United States, not counting  
those overseas in the morally murky theater of Iraq and Afghanistan  
who may return home sometime after the 2008 presidential election,  
that's a lot of assistance and funding needed to head off what he  
called a "rate of veteran suicide [that] has reached epidemic  
proportions," to the point that it has doubled the suicide rate of  
civilians. Safeguards already put into place have failed, for a  
variety of reasons, and given the severity of the mental and physical  
problems carried by returning soldiers, some daring out-of-the-box  
thinking is not only desperately needed, but required.

MORE: http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/76576/




apollo@speakeasy.org
