"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is  
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids  
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Hey guys,

Sorry if this seems generic, but I feel very strongly about this
issue, and it's a tough one to sound-bite so I'm providing links
rather than explanations (again).

The Senate is voting again tomorrow (Tuesday Feb 12th) on whether to
pass the FISA reauthorization bill which includes retroactive immunity
for telecoms turning over information to the bush administration
without a warrant.  PLEASE CALL your senators and representatives to
tell them you DO NOT WANT THIS BILL PASSED WITH RETROACTIVE IMMUNITY
NO MATTER WHAT.

Below is a link to a bulleted list regarding what the bill does for
corporations and the Bush administration and why we MUST not allow our
representatives to pass this bill:

http://www.drummajorinstitute.org/library/article.php?ID=6680

Please spread this around, people need to know what their senators are
doing in their name!

Below is an article explaining more about FISA from Senator Russ
Feingold:

http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/1/17/104227/863/70/438259

You can find your senators contact information here:

http://www.senate.gov/general/contact_information/senators_cfm.cfm

Below are the phone numbers of the senators who have so far voted for
retroactive immunity on earlier versions of this bill, please call
them and (politely) urge them to respect the Constitution, the
judicial branch of government, and the separation of powers and do not
let this bill go through!

Bayh (202) 224-5623 phone, (202) 228-1377 fax
Byrd (202) 224-3954 phone, (202) 228-0002 fax
Carper (202) 224-2441 phone, (202) 228-2190 fax
Feinstein (202) 224-3841 phone, (202) 228-3954 fax
Inouye (202) 224-3934 phone, (202) 224-6747 fax
Johnson (202) 224-5842 phone, (605) 341-2207 fax
Kohl (202) 224-5653 (202) 224-9787
Landrieu (202)224-5824 phone, (202) 224-9735 fax
Lincoln (202) 224-4843 phone, (202) 228-1371 fax
McCaskill (202) 224-6154 phone, (202) 228-6326 fax
Mikulski (202) 224-4654 phone,  (202) 224-8858 fax
Nelson (FL) (202) 224-5274 phone, (202) 228-2183 fax
Nelson (NE) (202) 224-6551 phone, (202) 228-0012 fax
Pryor (202) 224-2353 phone, (202) 228-0908 fax
Rockefeller, (202) 224-6472 phone, (202) 224-7665 fax
Salazar (202) 224-5852 phone, (202) 228-5036 fax
Stabenow (202) 224-4822 phone, (202) 228-0325 fax
Chambliss (202) 224-3521 phone, (202) 224-0103 fax

On Tue, 12 Feb 2008 00:36 +0000, Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote:
>
>
> Please tune in to KZSU by listening to 90.1 in the Bay Area or pointing
> your web browser to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu.
>
> If you're interested in guest appearing on any of our shows
> or having a mix featured contact us using our email addresses
> or: electronicadjs@kzsu.stanford.edu
>
> Big Love Show with Jack Wang - Mondays from 3PM-6PM PST
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
> This week Jack is proud to host DJ Zenith and Harry R.
> DJ Zenith, Stephanie Blair, was born in Washington, DC but grew up
> all over the world. Her childhood included places such as southeastern
> Virginia; Marquette, Michigan; Angeles City, Philippines; and Seoul
> and Taegu, Korea. Music was part of her life from an early age. Whether
> she
> was taking classical piano lessons; singing while her father played
> twelve string guitar in talent shows; singing in choirs; playing roles
> including lead in musicals; or playing tenor saxophone in symphonic
> bands; or DJing her college radio station; Stephanie grew up immersed
> in music. Stephanie became fascinated by the San Francisco dance scene
> in Washington, DC where she returned to after college. Stephanie finally
> moved to San Francisco in 2002. Stephanie's mixes are characterized by
> a dominant bass line. Fascinated by rhythms, many of her tracks also
> feature a heavy percussion element. Whether she's dropping acid tracks,
> tracks with beautiful female vocals, jazzy tracks, or even hip house
> tracks... she always serves it up with a large side of funk. Stephanie
> has played as close as Black Rock City and as far away as Paris. DJ
> Highlights this year for Stephanie include DJing with Green Gorilla
> Lounge at Burning Man and at Burning Man Camp Fundraisers, playing in
> her home town Washington, DC at the Dragon Fly Bar and finally playing
> in Paris, France at the Lizard Lounge. Stephanie is a resident Thursday
> nights at Sugar with Native Intellgence ( Sleevin Records ) and DJ Robb
> Crush ( Stompy ) as well as the Art & Music Sessions on Saturdays with
> Cez featuring art work by Danyol. Stephanie can also be found DJing
> around San Francisco and coming to a warehouse near you.
> More on DJ Zenith:
> http://www.djzenith.com/
> http://www.myspace.com/djzenith
>
> Henry R. claims to be an enigma. He's been part of the SF scene for
> several years. He and Zenith met when he hold his decks to her when
> he was upgrading. They've been working together on events over the
> past year now and he's happy to be here cuttin' it up for you.
>
> You can catch DJ Zenith and Henry R at Temple in San Francisco Friday
> Feb. 22nd. More infos:
> http://www.templesf.com/calendar
>
> The mix is going off now!! Lock it in!!!
>
> Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Mon Nite (Tues) from 12AM-3AM PST
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
> Holt will be mixing it up for you tonight. Insomniacs of the world
> untie as the beats move you into the morning!
>
> hsomusic.com
> myspace.com/hsomusic
>
> Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday from 9AM-12PM PST
> -------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
> J.C. will host DJ Frankie Jr. of Touch Recordings spinning live on
> Epiphany
> of Sound. More information about DJ Frankie can be found here:
> http://hsomusic.com/sh/D
> http://hsomusic.com/sh/9
>
> As always, we're excited to have DJ Frankie play here at KZSU.

Subject: [sfraves]  :: West Coast Techno last friday (29 Feb 2008) at Anu ::




Friday, 29 February 2008

RAY presents: 

F A K T I O N : because SF needs another techno cult
with special guests:

DJ Developer -- Modularz Sound Division [ Los Angeles|the world ] 
Endosine -- Drum Machine Museum [ San Francisco|Berlin ] // Live

 
Anu-Bar 
43 Sixth St., San Francisco, CA

DJ Developer is known throughout the US, Mexico and abroad for quick mixing
abilities and for leading LA's second wave of Techno.  In 2004 he shifted his
focus to production.  Now in 2008 he demonstrates his mastery of both: He
launched the label "Modularz Sound Division" with Detroit legend Fanon Flowers
(now living in Los Angeles) and is performing in public again, producing shows
under the Modularz name, featuring various talented artists from LA and
elsewhere.

Join us for this San Francisco appearance before Developer begins the European
leg of his tour in Spain and beyond.

Endosine: Literally translated, Endosine is the wave within. The modulating
force within all existence. Techno is everywhere, an element of the natural
and mechanized constructs around us. Connect to the wave within. Connect to
Endosine.

This will be Endosine's last US appearance before he flies off to Berlin for
an extended stay, working on production and advancing the standards of Techno
and Electronica.

10 PM to 2 AM
Cost: $5 
Official Site: http://www.faktionsf.com/

 
///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
 
Coming up: Faktion at Anu 
 
Friday, 28 March 2008:
Cesare Marchese - Essential Reload [ Italy|UK ] 
SAYAKA - BABD/Filter.SF [ Japan|San Francisco ]

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR- Feinstein vots agenst Sen. Dodds ....

I'm trying to find the Thomas Jefferson of today.
"How soon the labor of men would make a paradise of the whole earth, 
were it not for misgovernment, and a diversion of all his energies from 
their proper object -- the happiness of man, -- to the selfish interests 
of kings, nobles, and priests.  If we can prevent the government from 
wasting the labors of the people, under the pretense of taking care of 
them, they must become happy.  We who have gone before have performed an 
honest duty, by putting in the power of our successors a state of 
happiness which no nation ever before had within their choice."

"When I first entered on the stage of public life, I came to a 
resolution never to engage while in public office in any kind of 
enterprise for the improvement of my fortune, nor to wear any other 
character than that of a farmer.  I have never departed from it in a 
single instance.  Thus I have thought myself richer in contentment than 
I should have been with any increase of fortune."

"Never think of taking a book with you.  The object of walking is to 
relax the mind.  You should, therefore, not permit yourself even to 
think while you walk; but divert yourself by the objects surrounding 
you.  A little walk of an hour, in the morning, when you first arise, is 
advisable.  It shakes off sleep, and produces other good effects in the 
animal economy.  Rise at a fixed and early hour, and go to bed at a 
fixed and early hour also.  Sitting up late at night is injurious to the 
health, and not useful to the mind."

(Guess that one cuts out partying. :) )

"The exact truth should be told.  They will believe the good, if we 
candidly tell them the bad also.  Honesty promotes interest in the long 
run.  I can conscientiously decalre that as to myself, I wish that not 
only no act but no thought of mine should be unknown."

Read more quotes, arranged by topic, in a book (who's editor I 
interviewed on An Epiphany Of Sound) here:
http://www.joketribe.com/products/Thomas.Jefferson.Light.And.Liberty.php

I don't know how many, to just say this government no longer supports  
any of my needs, I'm not going to support or recognize this  
government.  I'm sort of indirectly quoting Mike Rivero, who does  
visuals for ABC's Lost and runs the website whatreallyhappened.com.   
I agree with him when he says he thinks this government is eventually  
going to just collapse on its own weight.  Look at Congress with 11%  
approval rating in some polls.

Anyway, I'm just putting 2 cents in, it's not like I was expecting  
anyone to jump out of their seats and drive down here so we can march

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Upsoming Evil Breaks events: V-Day & 2-22

This week Evil Breaks presents:
BASSDROP
Lovers Edition <3

After a HEARTy pillow fight at Justin Herman Plaza & a yummy dinner, then
spend the rest of your night on the dance floor:n)  This Valentines day,
Evil breaks invites you to come as you are, from the repressed and
remarkably dressed, to the super freaks and ultra chic.It's time to
unleash your wild side It's the Bassdrop: Lovers Edition!

We're doing it up right this year with an impressive line-up of dance
floor romeos and breakbeat heart-throbs to get those bodies moving. Expect
a bit of funk, a dash of tech, and a whole lotta bass. In addition we are
also featuring a special kissing booth for the lovers, themed Valentines
day drinks, and free chocolates throughout the night to keep you in the
mood.

The Fingermonsters
myspace.com/fingermonsters

Comprised of Andrew Phelan, Cubik, Origami, and Compulse, these men are no
strangers to the underground scene. Separately, they are well respected
for their individual skills, but together they form a Live PA goliath
designed to get that jello jigglin. This Bay Area foursome have been know
to cause mass confusion on the dance floor with their multiple drum
machines, knob fiddling, and general lap-top freakery. The Fingermonsters
are a four man militia whose mission is to breaks hearts, and incite
hysteria.


Mancub (Space Cowboys)


also featuring EB residents:
Aaron Jae (EB, space cowboys)
Bam (EB, Invibe.com)
M.O.D. (EB, Strategik)

Located at Shine 1337 Mission Street
FREEEE!
21+
------------------- - - - - - - - --------------------------
And next week:
Evil Breaks & False Profit present:
DIRTY

Friday, February 22nd, 2008
DNA Lounge (375 11th st.)

$10 presales available here:
(http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=36367&PGname=Evil%20Breaks)

$10 b4 11pm/$15 after that
10pm - 4am??
21+ w/ID


I know a bunch of people were expecting a show from us in January, but
instead of pushing forward with a show that just wasn't quite right, we
decided to move it to February. So here we are, coming at you with a show
that we KNOW will deliver. We're teaming up with False Profit for this
one, and along with the 2 UK headliners and a stellar local lineup, this
is really one you can't afford to miss.

AMB
(Chi-Recordings/Sinister/Money Shot/Audio Therapy/EQ) - UK

Based in London, but with roots in Hungarys Chi Recordings, Ambrus Deak
a.k.a. AMB, has been in music production, engineering, and label
management for over seven years.

Co-founder and a fundamental cog in Chi Recordings, he also appears on
Reacts 21st Century Breaks, Distinctives Y4K, EQ Recordings, and Dave
Saemans Audio Therapy. AMB was responsible for one of the most remarkable
breakbeat tracks of 2002, Romeo, which obtained second place on
Breakspoll, The International Breakbeat Awards, best single category in
2003. Support comes from Hybrid, Nick Warren, Roger Sanchez, James Zabiela
, Laurent Garnier, Elite Force, Chris Carter, Plump DJs, Terminalhead,
Meat Katie, Tayo, General Midi, Hyper, and many more. AMB is supported by
todays leading international provider of digital audio and MIDI
solutions, M-Audio. And when hes not making music or spinning records, he
puts on his mastering suit, or makes soundtracks for commercials, theatre
and the film industry.

As a DJ he has played in the USA, UK, France, Germany, Russia, Croatia,
Serbia, Hungary alongside The Chemical Brothers, Adam Freeland, Hybrid,
Chris Carter, Elite Force, General Midi, and a whole lot more.

Diverted
(Diverted Traffic/TCR/Sokolov Sounds/Mofo/ibreaks) - UK

DIVERTED are DJ/Producers and Label Owners Stephen Baxter and Lee
Richardson. They have produced a string of well received releases on
Sokolov Sounds, TCR and AIR which helped them find their grounding in the
breaks scene. This has also spurred the guys on to creating their album
which is being put together hand-in-hand with an exciting live show
involving vocalists, live instruments from the guys themselves and
contributions from other Djs and artists around them including Nine Lives
the Cat. Check out their myspace page for regular updates, videos, gig
schedule and news as this album takes shape.

The last year has taken them all around the world Djing their sound to the
masses. Particularly memorable nights have been at the infamous HUM
events, Drop Beats Not Bombs, Chew the Fat @ The End, Breakspoll @ Fabric,
Glade Festival and tours of Australia and Russia saw appreciation for the
boys outside the UK.

 Along with E.B. residents:
Carbon Community
(Sober Music/Bless Records/Moonshine/E.B.) - SF
Aaron Jae (E.B./Space Cowboys)
Bam (E.B./Invibe)
M.O.D. (E.B.)

False Profit upstairs:
Dr. Toast (FP)
Alxndr (Downlow/FP/Transported SF)
Obi-J (FP)
DJJD (FP)

Visuals by Dax
(Xenos Studios, Dax Presents)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Compression: Goldie: 2-21-2008

February 21st 2008
Compression

Goldie (Metalheadz, UK)
In his own words:
Hey you blokes. My name is Goldie, and I represent that pure raw UK drum
and bass sound. My main goals in life include: making sick drum and bass
tracks that come off as crazy dance floor monsters (regardless if they all
sound the same), clipping mixers untill those red lights light up to the
top, destroying high end sound systems around the world, making peopls
eardrums explode, and trying to accomplish putting on all my gold
accessories in under 30 minutes time.

Goldie is an English electronic music artist, disc jockey, and actor. As a
musician he works mainly within the jungle and drum n bass genres, and has
helped to promote these styles globally. By 1991, Goldie had become
fascinated by the British breakbeat music scene; and his girlfriend, DJ
Kemistry, introduced him to the pioneering jungle/drum'n'bass producers
Dennis 'Dego' McFarlane and Mark 'Marc Mac' Clair, known as 4hero.  His
first globally released album, Timeless, followed in 1995. Timeless shot
straight into the charts at number seven, which was a first for a drum 'n'
bass record.  In 2002, Goldie said that he had been working for three
years on a film called Sine Tempus, described as a coming-of-age story of
a young paintbrush artist, and in 2006 announced its soundtrack as his new
album. As of 2008, album and film have not been released yet.  Goldie is
also known for his work as the leader of the Rufige Kru. This group has no
fixed members; it has included some of most well-known drum and bass
producers such as Technical Itch, Heist, Teebee, Cujo, Agzilla Da Ice, Doc
Scott and Rob Playford.

WITH SUPPORT FROM:
2Cents
4 Real
the Colonel MC

FEBRUARY 21, 2008
DOORS OPEN AT 10PM
$10 before 11pm, No Guestlist!

TEMPLE
55 Natoma (between Mission and Howard, between 1st and 2nd)

There's been rumors circulating around that the Quote of the Day will  
be moving to the DCRaves list while there is remodeling going on in  
the SFRaves list.  I am not sure why I am spreading these rumors, but  
I would say that is a completely silly notion.  The Quote of the Day  
belongs on SFR and nowhere else.  I might be open minded to a one-off,  
of course, but that's just what it is - a one-off.  Have a nice day.   
fog out

--

Once a government resorts to terror against its own population to get  
what it wants, it must keep using terror against its own population to  
get what it wants. A government that terrorizes its own people can  
never stop. If such a government ever lets the fear subside and  
rational thought return to the populace, that government is finished.

- Michael Rivero

 The Big Tent: (the warehouse)
 Dragn'fly ( DJ4NORML/Strategik/DJDRAGNFLY.COM-Sacramento, CA)

 Julio Midnite (Want It)
 Not To Be Missed:
 bouncy boxing ring

 popcorn machine
 cotton candy
 face painting

 and more TBA!
 Party goes from 10pm - 4am
 Carnival attire encouraged
 BYOB, but there will be a few kegs of beer
 $10 Suggested Donation
 Come one, come all!

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is  
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids  
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] BSP::2.15.8 another night of sucka free techno on radio integrated
 2.15.8::PSB

this week 2.15.:
its SUCKA FREE techno night with the sounds of:

->DJ Alex Windsor

If anybody's ever seen Alex in action you know what a great talent he 
has for the wheels of steel and a great sense of flow and mastery he has 
for them. Originally from London, UK, Alex has been instrumental in the 
San Francisco Techno (with a capital T) scene here since 1992 as a 
partner in the Gaia Mantra Record store in SF and as a promoter and 
resident of MAD mondays.. for those of you who don't know, MAD used to 
be where it was at for Techno in SF from 95-97 Giving voice to the early 
SF minimal techno scene and showcasing techno that would probably had 
been not heard anywhere else in the city at the time. Alex's skills have 
taken him all across the globe, from the US to Japan, and the UK. He has 
played alongside the likes of Aphex Twin, the Shamen, Orbital, Carl 
Craig, Richie hawtin, Moby, Mr.C, Juan Atkins, Mark Broom, & Dave Clarke 
to name a few.... He's Dj'd at parties here in SF by crews with such 
infamously dope names names as FnF, Harmony, Area 51, Tribal Future, 
Gateway, Brass Tax , Future &  more undergrounds than my short term 
memory loss can muster.

->Dj Perla
http://www.myspace.com/perladanceusted

   Perla has appeared on Radio Integrated before and totally has rocked 
it with his own live material.. Perla originally hails from southern 
spain where he helped promote his Dance Usted parties or, 'Dance Please' 
As bulletproof and flawless as his original tracks are, his selection 
skills are equally unbeatable. we are pleased to welcome Perla back this 
time for a special mixed set of his pick of tracks that have been 
influencing him and shaping his current sound to date.  Perla will be 
pumping up the set with an all ableton set, but as he says " Just 
playing songs in a computer like a DJ mixing with records is something 
like, you know, too lazy?  -and it all seems like no big deal.. Like we 
say in Spain, that's like killing flies with a cannon! So I want to mix 
a lot of songs, like with really quick mixing and also add some of my 
stuff, percusive loops, synth lines etc...."   i can't wait. `;)


Tune in at
http://radio.defsf.com or
http://www.zer01.net:1200/

Every Friday from 9pm - 1AM PST

Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com



subscribe to def announce for your techno fix!
def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com

coming in the following weeks..

2.22.8 ILL-Ectro night featuring Djs Indigo and Sheztek note:'doing the 
robot' is forbidden.. unless you're calling it locking and poppin' then 
its ok.

2.29.8 Leap year techno live at Faktion SF with DJ Developer from LA and 
Endosine (live p.a.) BTW..the drinks at the club are better than the 
screwdrivers you make at home.

3.7.8 keeping it real with Caltrop and Clairity. never heard a bad 
record dropped from either of 'em & this night should be no exception. 
every set i've heard from either of these two has been well thought out 
and well seasoned with intelligent groovin' techno tracks.

techno is taking over!

sean ocean

defsf.com
http://www.myspace.com/defsf

forward this message to EVERYONE.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  BAM at Funkonnection this Saturday

--Apple-Mail-1--826522565
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

  	 415-626-7001
www.mighty119.com
Afrika Bambaataa and Allgood Funk Alliance and Neighbor headline huge =20=

=93Funkonnection=94
Nufunk monthly welcomes luminaries as well as local heroes Ren, Motion =20=

Potion, Tal M Klein, Malarkey and Chauncey B

WHAT: =93Funkonnection=94 the Nufunk monthly
WHEN: Saturday, February 16, 2008. 10pm-4am
WHERE: Mighty | 119 Utah St San Francisco CA | 415.626.7001
WHO: Afrika Bambaataa =96 (=93the godfather of Hip Hop Culture and =
Creator =20
of the Electro-Funk sound=94 =96Zulu Nation, NYC) Allgood Funk Alliance =20=

(Funk Weapons-DC www.funkweapons.com) DJ Neighbor (Homebreakin Records-=20=

Calgary www.myspace.com/homebreakin) Motion Potion =
(www.myspace.com/motionpotion)=20
, Tal M Klein (www.talmklein.com) Malarkey (www.myspace.com/=20
djmalarkey), Chauncey B (Funkin Shit Up =96 Dalva)
D=C9COR & FUN: Free fried chicken served at doors. SF Funk Festival =
D=E9cor.
COSTUME: Rubber chickens, outrageous lapels, paisley panties, =20
ridiculous wigs, ya know, FUNK!
GENERAL INFO: www.sunsetpromotions.net
TICKETS: $16 advance at www.sunsettickets.com and $15 advance at =
www.going.com=20
  $20 at the door
PRESS INFO: Robert Kowal | rob@sunsetpromotions.net | 415.971.4527

DETAILS: The Funk is coming back and Uncle Jam wants YOU! After a =20
spectacular kickoff party on January 18, Funkonnection returns to San =20=

Francisco on February16 with a massive lineup featuring the Godfather =20=

of Hip Hop Culture, Afrika Bambaataa, DC nufunk hero Allgood Funk =20
Alliance and Calgary future-disco maven Neighbor. Local heroes include =20=

Ren the Vinyl Archaeologist (True Skool), Chauncey B (Dalva) and =20
residents Motion Potion, Tal M Klein and Malarkey. With Bambaataa =20
making his first-ever appearance at Mighty at this already buzzed-=20
about party, tickets are sure to go fast.

Arika Bambaataa, whose name literally translates to =93affectionate =20
leader=94 is one of the three main originators of break-beat deejaying, =20=

and is respectfully known as the =93Godfather=94 of Hip Hop culture as =20=

well as the Father of the Electro Funk Sound. He was the first to coin =20=

the term =93Hip Hop=94, encompassing the elements of music, graffiti, =20=

dance and knowledge, thereby identifying Hip Hop as a unique culture =20
unto itself. After his 1982 hit sensation, =93Planet Rock=94 , Bambaataa =
=20
organized the first international Hip Hop tour of B-Boys, Graffiti =20
Artists, DJs and Emcees, providing the world with a glimpse of the =20
cultural revolution called Hip Hop. He has consistently made records =20
nationally and internationally, and has helped to define the cutting =20
edge of music throughout from rap, through electro, to house and =20
electronic breaks.

Allgood Funk Alliance has been churning out newschool funk with an =20
oldschool sound for years now. With some of the most coveted limited-=20
release breaks records on the planet emerging from their Washington DC-=20=

based Funk Weapons label, AGFA has emerged as a leader in the struggle =20=

to make dance music relevant to folks who like the live sound. AGFA =20
makes funk that sounds like=85 well=85 funk. DJ Neighbor is a rising =
star =20
from Calgary=92s surprisingly explosive nufunk scene. With a sound that =20=

modernizes classic disco and electro, his releases on the =20
=93Homebreakin=94 label have garnered him acclaim throughout the world. =20=

Recent hits like =93Bro Chant=94 and =93Man Juice=94 have only =
solidified his =20
reputation as one of the most exciting new producers in the nufunk =20
world.

ABOUT FUNKONNECTION: Some of the greasiest characters in the Bay Area =20=

have joined forces to change all that. Motion Potion, (he of the =20
legendary Nickie=92s =93Whatdafunk=94 parties and SF Funk Festival), Tal =
M =20
Klein (the nufunk producer whose Plastic Starfish album follows 4 =20
killer recent funk Eps) and Malarkey (who single-handledly revitalized =20=

the North Bay funk scene with his =93Juke Joynt=94 parties) have made a =20=

solemn pledge to the memory of James Brown to help his legacy live on.

Funkonnection will feature the artists working to bring the oldschool =20=

sounds of the ONE to the dance-floor with modern production. This =20
=93nufunk=94 universe is expanding by the day with artists from Europe =20=

(Kraak & Smaak, Dr Rubberfunk, Torpedo Boyz, Bonobo), South America =20
(Quantic), Canada (Smalltown Djs, Wicked Lester, Neighbor) and the =20
States (Fort Knox Five, Allgood Funk Alliance, Nikodemus, Ursula 1000) =20=

joining forces to rescue the funk from dollar-bin obscurity. Now the =20
Bay Area, one of the funk=92s seminal birthplaces will have its own =20
monthly chance to celebrate this fusion of the old and the new at =20
everyone=92s favorite funky dance-club, Mighty. And so you know we=92re =20=

serious, Funkonnection comes complete with the SF Funk Festival d=E9cor =20=

and free fried chicken served at show-time..



Apollo
apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid =20
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for =20=

your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're =20
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of =20=

empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another =20
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and =20
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  -=20=

Fritz Williams

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone, =20
but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

Tomorrow (Thur.) morning from 9a-noon I'll be hosting DJ Frankie Jr. for 
a return appearance on KZSU radio, and his first appearance on An 
Epiphany Of Sound.  Be guaranteed that he'll be bringing you his version 
of the San Francisco Sound.  And it will be a full 3 hours of the San 
Francisco Sound.

You can get a preview of his style here:
http://waxdj.com/djs/3612/
And you can find out more about him here:
http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=2475938

An Epiphany Of Sound is on from 9a-noon Pacific Time and you can listen 
in over the air at 90.1 FM as well as online at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Hope to have you listening!


-- 
San Francisco Bay Guardian's Readers Choice Award Winner: Best Radio DJ:
http://www.sfbg.com/promo/pollpositions.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

the better of the two but Dragonfly has good atmosphere, tasty food
and fair prices.

serves French style and crepes.

idk know about "on par" but its solid place.  You won't be complaining.

marco, IMO there's too many great places to recommend just one, you really need to narrow it down by cuisine or something.

In the Mission a lot of people are talking about Range, http://www.rangesf.com/, but I wouldn't call it affordable.  I also like Dosa http://www.dosasf.com/ but again not cheap.

On the cheap, I like Puerto Allegre and Pakwan.

Weird Fish is somewhere in the middle and not bad either: http://www.weirdfishsf.com/

Subject: [sfraves] DJ Shadow & Cut Chemist: The Hard Sell (last night)

--0-1509464318-1203010157=:16500
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Where to start? 

Their set was ENTIRELY composed of ORIGINAL 45's. Only gear were some guitar foot pedals for looping, and some outboard FX.

Their set started off with some straight-up, LIVE, from-scratch, HOUSE MUSIC. 

Holy sh!T! They mixed everything in from 'Rock Around The Clock' to things I've never heard before. Towards the end they strapped on some portable decks & mixers and scratched in guitar samples over a metal loop. 

Kid Koala also played a dope opening set, lot of stuff off the new CD. Anybody else make it out? What a night.

BTW, sup yall!

peace

chuck
--0-1509464318-1203010157=:16500--

Received: (qmail 5185 invoked from network); 14 Feb 2008 17:47:24 -0000
Date: Thu, 14 Feb 2008 12:47:23 -0500
From: Ravi Pina <ravi@cow.org>
To: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>, SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20080214174723.GW48995@neu.cow.org>
References: <834139.16500.qm@web60812.mail.yahoo.com> <BAY110-DAV200F7B4CBE5F8A8C5774E185250@phx.gbl>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <BAY110-DAV200F7B4CBE5F8A8C5774E185250@phx.gbl>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.3i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ Shadow & Cut Chemist: The Hard Sell (last night)

It was over here[1] and was an absolutely amazing
show.  Koala's set felt way too short even for an
opener.  I've seen him a few other times and his
shows are a lot of fun.

The Shadow/Chemist sets were beyond original it is
difficult to know where to begin.  It was nice they
had a introduction "tutorial" of what exactly they
were going to be doing.  I was sitting in the balcony
and overheard a few people trying to explain what
they were going to be seeing to their friends.  Some
were right and others were... at the wrong show.

One technique that is amazing is where they fabricated
a off-center 45 turntable which created one of a kind
sounds from played 45s.

Some parts of the set weren't my favorite, but I'd
like to attribute it to my post surgical (Monday)
Vicodin haze I was in all day.

-r


[1] http://www.ticketmaster.com/venue/229653

Yeah, can't forget the off-center 45, and trippy, off-center, rotating visuals to go with. The 45's invading the City was a pretty badass clip too.

That little invisible circle on the wall in my office is still spinning! Off center!!!



Ravi Pina <ravi@cow.org> wrote: It was over here[1] and was an absolutely amazing
show.  Koala's set felt way too short even for an
opener.  I've seen him a few other times and his
shows are a lot of fun.

The Shadow/Chemist sets were beyond original it is
difficult to know where to begin.  It was nice they
had a introduction "tutorial" of what exactly they
were going to be doing.  I was sitting in the balcony
and overheard a few people trying to explain what
they were going to be seeing to their friends.  Some
were right and others were... at the wrong show.

One technique that is amazing is where they fabricated
a off-center 45 turntable which created one of a kind
sounds from played 45s.

Some parts of the set weren't my favorite, but I'd
like to attribute it to my post surgical (Monday)
Vicodin haze I was in all day.

-r


[1] http://www.ticketmaster.com/venue/229653

Range is California cuisine I guess, Dosa is South Indian.

Weird Fish, is uh, Fish. 

All of these could be done around $50 or less depending on your level of hunger and thirst.  Range is hot right now, so it might be hard to get a table.  Dosa fills up, but you can walk in if you go early.  Never had to wait at Weird Fish.

Peter

X-YMail-OSG: oWLe6OYVM1kWxkheWmz.461gag9bPEHg8hv4AeFwOcGrWIGbXD9Tn0eUYjeh6SCPHzHWMMA29wwmksg__RqlHO4gcoavY6QCHGg98YL38gD3fSaClXb_QKxze5IzyopRaf7uC4PbfcvguA--

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.

FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban warfare training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in Urban Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual reality training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known report on the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the time.  

We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest facility in the world, see http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342

But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some things that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally see the guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's Toledo training plan without ever considering the political fall out.  Not sure this event says much about impending marital law therefore.  

IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training guys that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for live fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going to institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just starting with Toledo...;)

Read the bit in this article about the problems in teaching and training MOUT:  http://www.military.com/NewContent/0,13190,NI_1104_Urban-P1,00.html

Best,

Peter

(and if you can't make the correlation yourself, you aren't thinking hard enough)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

I mean, I know it seems like a stretch at 1st - but when you factor in how a 
shitload of our Constitutional rights are being hacked away bit-by-bit, and 
you see more and more US missions/wars in Urban centers (Bosnia, Iraq, 
Serbia, etc.), then you see US attempting drills within our own cities 
rather than at training facilities...it smacks of impending ickiness.

I am quite sure the US has got to have some sort of contingency plans for 
"what if" scenarios like civil war, class war, race war, etc. - all of which 
would most likely take place primarily in urban centers.

I know they are finally starting to look at the rise of gang member 
enrollment in US military - although not doing much about it - and finding 
that urban gangs are sending members to be trained by the military for more 
effectiveness in their illicit activities.

Food for thought at the very least....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

My bigger concern, instead of uneducated gang-bangers enlisting in the 
Army, is the infiltration of Evangelical Fundies in places like the Air 
Force Academy. http://tinyurl.com/2vnscr

Look at how much damage 10 engineering students did with just 4 hijacked 
commercial passenger planes, and then consider what could happen if a 
whole Chain of Command that controlled Stealth Bombers, loaded with 
*live nukes* got it into their heads that they were on a "Mission From God."

That could get real messy, right quick.

Not that the rise of the Evangelicals in the ranks of the Army isn't a 
problem as well, this just hit the wires today:
http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hj_WduJSd-7xIcenAGMSPeoCsImQ

.

From sfraves-return-144904-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Feb 14 21:16:33 2008

>>> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.
>>>
>>> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban 
>>> warfare training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations 
>>> in Urban Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual 
>>> reality training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known 
>>> report on the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation 
>>> at the time.
>>>
>>> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several 
>>> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare 
>>> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not 
>>> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban 
>>> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest 
>>> facility in the world, see 
>>> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>>>
>>> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some 
>>> things that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally 
>>> see the guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's 
>>> Toledo training plan without ever considering the political fall out. 
>>> Not sure this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>>>
>>> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training 
>>> guys that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for 
>>> live fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that 
>>> the planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises 
>>> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men 
>>> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going 
>>> to institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every 
>>> other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just 
>>> starting with Toledo...;)
>>>
>>> Read the bit in this article about the problems in teaching and training 
>>> MOUT: 
>>> http://www.military.com/NewContent/0,13190,NI_1104_Urban-P1,00.html
>>>
>>> Best,
>>>

----- Original Message ----
From: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, February 14, 2008 12:57:47 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

I mean, I know it seems like a stretch at 1st - but when you factor in how a 
shitload of our Constitutional rights are being hacked away bit-by-bit, and 
you see more and more US missions/wars in Urban centers (Bosnia, Iraq, 
Serbia, etc.), then you see US attempting drills within our own cities 
rather than at training facilities...it smacks of impending ickiness.

I am quite sure the US has got to have some sort of contingency plans for 
"what if" scenarios like civil war, class war, race war, etc. - all of which 
would most likely take place primarily in urban centers.

I know they are finally starting to look at the rise of gang member 
enrollment in US military - although not doing much about it - and finding 
that urban gangs are sending members to be trained by the military for more 
effectiveness in their illicit activities.

Food for thought at the very least....


----- Original Message ----- 
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: "Marco" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; "sf raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, February 14, 2008 12:41 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!


> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.
>
> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban warfare 
> training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in Urban 
> Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual reality 
> training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known report on 
> the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the time.
>
> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several 
> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare 
> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not 
> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban 
> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest 
> facility in the world, see 
> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>
> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some things 
> that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally see the 
> guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's Toledo 
> training plan without ever considering the political fall out.  Not sure 
> this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>
> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training guys 
> that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for live 
> fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the 
> planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises 
> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men 
> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going to 
> institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every 
> other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just 
> starting with Toledo...;)
>
> Read the bit in this article about the problems in teaching and training 
> MOUT:  http://www.military.com/NewContent/0,13190,NI_1104_Urban-P1,00.html
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, February 14, 2008 11:55:43 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!
>
> http://www.infowars.net/articles/february2008/140208Toledo.htm
>
> Gee...1st Iraq (which is mostly urban based warfare), now our own military 
> trying to run training INSIDE of US cities?
>
> I'm not typically the conspiracy theory type - but if this doesn't reek of 
> impending martial law, I don't know what does.
>
> (and if you can't make the correlation yourself, you aren't thinking hard

To: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <240970.74374.qm@web32404.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

The Army is absolutely training for future urban warfare scenarios and has been for some time.  Same with the Marines and other units.  That doesn't prove they are planning to deploy in the US.  FWIW this sort of training has been going on for over 20 years and has developed to include live fire training, virtual reality, and computer game simulations.

Remember our armed forces in Iraq are having trouble subduing a population of less than 30 million people.  America has 300 million people and it is huge.  You are going to need a large force, at least 1 million well armed soldiers IMO, to control the US populace.   Show me some evidence of large scale deployments around the country and I'll start believing in the martial law thing.  

Until then I'll have to say I still beleive this is just a badly planned training exercise.

Best,

Peter

>> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.

>> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban 
>> warfare
>> training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in Urban
>> Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual reality
>> training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known report on
>> the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the 
>> time.
>>
>> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several
>> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare
>> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not
>> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban
>> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest
>> facility in the world, see
>> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>>
>> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some 
>> things
>> that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally see the
>> guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's Toledo
>> training plan without ever considering the political fall out.  Not sure
>> this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>>
>> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training 
>> guys
>> that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for live
>> fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the
>> planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises
>> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men
>> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going to
>> institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every
>> other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just
>> starting with Toledo...;)
>>
>> Read the bit in this article about the problems in teaching and training
>> MOUT:

Marco wrote:
> Well, I am not saying martial law will happen tomorrow or anything, 
> but it stands to reason that our military may be training for 
> potential urban warfare scenarios in the future.
>
> Piss off enough of your citizens and it's not exactly a far stretch to 
> imagine they might wanna revolt.
.
In Russia, about 100 years ago, under the Czars, the ppl endured 
taxation rates of 90% before they revolted.

Here in the USA, when you add everything up, rent, gas, groceries, 
child-care, taxes, etc, etc we're maybe at the 55 to 65% range, so we've 
got a ways to go yet, but even if we get there there's that Magic Hi-Def 
TV Set Top Box and 50 inch screen that can convince most people that 
that peeing on their heads is only a soft and gentle summer rain, so I 
don't think we'll be seeing any sort of uprising from the General 
Populace any time soon.

The metric is is that you need one soldier on the ground for every 40 
ppl to keep the population in check, which means that for Iraq we needed 
about 600,000 soldiers to do the job right and, thanks to Donny 
Rumsfeld, we went in with less than half that force.

Which is why, Surge in Baghdad not-withstanding, it's always going to be 
whack-a-mole over there.

For a country the size of the USA you'll need a force of about 7.5 
million to lock the place down, which sounds like a major reach, but 
hey, if things get far enough along, how hard would it be to Federalize 
our Municipal Police Forces?

Not that anybody in Authority is thinking along those lines: 
http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pdffiles/ksil178.pdf

Or we can just go the route China did in the 1960s and create our own 
Red Guard of 17 year olds.

Shouldn't be too hard to find volunteers, I'm sure any street kid with a 
'Stop Snitchin' T-shirt would sign right the fuck up.

You are going to need a large force, at least 1 million well armed soldiers IMO, to control the US populace. >>> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.
>>>
>>> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban 
>>> warfare
>>> training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in Urban
>>> Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual reality
>>> training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known report on
>>> the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the 
>>> time.
>>>
>>> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several
>>> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare
>>> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not
>>> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban
>>> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest
>>> facility in the world, see
>>> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>>>
>>> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some 
>>> things
>>> that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally see the
>>> guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's Toledo
>>> training plan without ever considering the political fall out.  Not sure
>>> this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>>>
>>> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training 
>>> guys
>>> that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for live
>>> fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the
>>> planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises
>>> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men
>>> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going to
>>> institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every
>>> other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just
>>> starting with Toledo...;)
>>>
>>> Read the bit in this article about the problems in teaching and training
>>> MOUT: 
>>> http://www.military.com/NewContent/0,13190,NI_1104_Urban-P1,00.html
>>>
>>> Best,
>>>
>>> Peter
>>>
>>>
>>> ----- Original Message ----
>>> From: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

------=_Part_3251_29837980.1203027720961
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

something people on this list need to remember: "*Congress shall make no law
respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise
thereof*"

Stop acting like religion is somehow a worse choice than atheism, both are
equally in the realm of faith and outside the realm of physical proof.  For
people who think they're progressive and forward thinking and liberal damn
some of you are intolerant, and not only that but you give yourself excuses
for your intolerance.  Nyc, the vast majority of even fundamentalist
Christians would be insulted by the insinuation that they are any less
rational than you (since to them, nuking the world in God's name would be an
act of insanity), and I as a non-fundamentalist, pacifist Christian along
with them.

As to allegations of religious intolerance at Air Force: on the basis of my
own two and a half years at the Naval Academy (and yes, I know it's a
different place and Air Force always seems to have more problems than
everyone else but it's still a military academy), I don't doubt that some
cadets were unfairly prevented the opportunity to practice their religion.
My personal experience suggests that the reason isn't intentional
discrimination but rather over-zealous caution in preventing abuse of the
system by non-religious cadets to gain extra privileges (which is a common
enough problem to warrant caution).  If your religious request is legitimate
but gets denied it takes about 20 minutes to go to your battalion chaplain,
who outranks the person who denied you by light years, and get the decision
reversed.  However, if there is real systemic discrimination, then it is
utterly inappropriate and needs to be punished and removed.

On 2/14/08, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>

> stands to reason that our military may be training for potential urban
> warfare scenarios in the future.

> Piss off enough of your citizens and it's not exactly a far stretch to
> imagine they might wanna revolt.

  ----- Original Message -----=20

  something people on this list need to remember: "Congress shall make =
no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free =
exercise thereof"

  Stop acting like religion is somehow a worse choice than atheism, both =
are equally in the realm of faith and outside the realm of physical =
proof.  For people who think they're progressive and forward thinking =
and liberal damn some of you are intolerant, and not only that but you =
give yourself excuses for your intolerance.  Nyc, the vast majority of =
even fundamentalist Christians would be insulted by the insinuation that =
they are any less rational than you (since to them, nuking the world in =
God's name would be an act of insanity), and I as a non-fundamentalist, =
pacifist Christian along with them.

  As to allegations of religious intolerance at Air Force: on the basis =
of my own two and a half years at the Naval Academy (and yes, I know =
it's a different place and Air Force always seems to have more problems =
than everyone else but it's still a military academy), I don't doubt =
that some cadets were unfairly prevented the opportunity to practice =
their religion.  My personal experience suggests that the reason isn't =
intentional discrimination but rather over-zealous caution in preventing =
abuse of the system by non-religious cadets to gain extra privileges =
(which is a common enough problem to warrant caution).  If your =
religious request is legitimate but gets denied it takes about 20 =
minutes to go to your battalion chaplain, who outranks the person who =
denied you by light years, and get the decision reversed.  However, if =
there is real systemic discrimination, then it is utterly inappropriate =
and needs to be punished and removed. =20

The metric is is that you need one soldier on the ground for every 40 
ppl to keep the population in check, which means that for Iraq we needed 
about 600,000 soldiers to do the job right and, thanks to Donny 
Rumsfeld, we went in with less than half that force.

Which is why, Surge in Baghdad not-withstanding, it's always going to be 
whack-a-mole over there.

For a country the size of the USA you'll need a force of about 7.5 
million to lock the place down, which sounds like a major reach, but 
hey, if things get far enough along, how hard would it be to Federalize 
our Municipal Police Forces?

Not that anybody in Authority is thinking along those lines: 
http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pdffiles/ksil178.pdf

Or we can just go the route China did in the 1960s and create our own 
Red Guard of 17 year olds.

'Stop Snitchin' T-shirt would sign right the fuck up.

>>> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.
>>>
>>> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban 
>>> warfare
>>> training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in Urban
>>> Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual reality
>>> training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known report on
>>> the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the 
>>> time.
>>>
>>> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with several
>>> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban warfare
>>> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these are not
>>> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an urban
>>> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest
>>> facility in the world, see
>>> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>>>
>>> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some 
>>> things
>>> that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally see the
>>> guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's Toledo
>>> training plan without ever considering the political fall out.  Not sure
>>> this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>>>
>>> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous training 
>>> guys
>>> that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building for live
>>> fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the
>>> planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises
>>> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not enough men
>>> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were going to
>>> institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in every
>>> other city in the US right?  And don't try to tell me they're just
>>> starting with Toledo...;)

information to sort out what you think is correct and what is  
hogwash.  That's why discussion is so important, too!

> Nyc, the vast majority of even fundamentalist Christians would be

> you (since to them, nuking the world in God's name would be an act

>
>   As to allegations of religious intolerance at Air Force: on the  
> basis of my own two and a half years at the Naval Academy (and yes,  
> I know it's a different place and Air Force always seems to have  
> more problems than everyone else but it's still a military  
> academy), I don't doubt that some cadets were unfairly prevented  
> the opportunity to practice their religion.  My personal experience  
> suggests that the reason isn't intentional discrimination but  
> rather over-zealous caution in preventing abuse of the system by  
> non-religious cadets to gain extra privileges (which is a common  
> enough problem to warrant caution).  If your religious request is  
> legitimate but gets denied it takes about 20 minutes to go to your  
> battalion chaplain, who outranks the person who denied you by light  
> years, and get the decision reversed.  However, if there is real  
> systemic discrimination, then it is utterly inappropriate and needs  
> to be punished and removed.
>

>>> Hmm. I think you've been snookered by the conspiracy theory press.
>>>
>>> FWIW I used to work for the guys in the US Army in charge of urban
>>> warfare
>>> training and I still know a few things about Mobile Operations in  
>>> Urban
>>> Terrain aka MOUT.  My company developed a concept for a virtual  
>>> reality
>>> training simulator in the mid-nineties and I wrote a well known  
>>> report on
>>> the applicaiton of virtual reality to training and simulation at the
>>> time.
>>>
>>> We also got to spend a week at Ft. Benning Georgia training with  
>>> several
>>> different groups.  While its true that they have their own urban  
>>> warfare
>>> training ranges, i.e. the McKenna range at Fort Benning, these  
>>> are not
>>> really realistic environments in many ways.  The Marines have an  
>>> urban
>>> combat center at Twentynine Palms that is supposed to be the largest
>>> facility in the world, see
>>> http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/913342
>>>
>>> But these facilities are all known to the forces and there are some
>>> things
>>> that the ranges can't and don't simulate.  Frankly I can totally  
>>> see the
>>> guys I used to work with cooking up something like the Marine's  
>>> Toledo
>>> training plan without ever considering the political fall out.   
>>> Not sure
>>> this event says much about impending marital law therefore.
>>>
>>> IMO, this story is 99.9% likely just due to some overzealous  
>>> training
>>> guys
>>> that had a "brilliant" idea to use an abandoned office building  
>>> for live
>>> fire training and almost got away with it.  You did realize that the
>>> planned exercise was for a small unit to conduct live fire exercises
>>> inside one abandoned office building in Toledo right?  So not  
>>> enough men
>>> to take and control a city were even involved.  Plus if you were  
>>> going to
>>> institute martial law you'd want to do a "training exercise" in  
>>> every

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: next step - MARTIAL LAW!

I'm not arguing for universal ID, but actually if you want to prevent identity theft strong universal biometric ID documents would be one way to do it.  

You can't steal an identity if you can't produce false identity documents such as driver's licenses.  

Full disclosure: my employer makes products for the prevention of identity theft and identity fraud

People interested in issues of privacy and reputation should read this book: http://docs.law.gwu.edu/facweb/dsolove/Future-of-Reputation/index.htm

Its a very important book IMO and it will change some of your views about privacy on the Internet. 

As usual YMMV

Best,

Peter

"Detox: Day 7"

Perhaps someone out there feels my pain!?!?!

I would have to believe cigarettes are like crack. I read the reason they're so addictive is because they can work as a stimulant OR a depressant. That kind of makes sense to me because I smoked in the morning to help me wake up, and took smoke "breaks" to chill when I'm busy on something. 

In the morning? After a shag? After a meal? At the club? During a long phone call? When I'm bored?

Holy crap, I guess I smoked a lot. It has been 13 years since I started smoking "full time." 

I want to know how the ex-smokers on here cope. Yeah, I have patches, lozenges, and gum. I don't really have a method for administration other than that I've found I need something all the f11ck!ng time! 

That, and my feet itch. Maybe Shermans do have crack in them, wouldn't surprise me. 

Discuss.

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] NRR: Quiting Smoking (cigarettes)

References: <324455.5755.qm@web60824.mail.yahoo.com>
From: "Daniel Faustine" <DFaustine@procedesoftware.com>
To: "CHUCK G" <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>,
	"SFR" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Quiting Smoking (cigarettes)

I feel your pain Chuck.

I smoked a pack and a half a day for about 7 years. Quit cold turkey NYE
1999. I was serious though -- I put my last butt out on the back of my
hand as a reminder. (my grandfather succumbed to lung cancer in 1992 --
his poison was "Prince Albert in a can"). Quitting smoking was one of
the HARDEST things I have ever had to do. I gave it a kickstart by
locking myself up in my house for the first 3 weeks... but most normal
people won't have that luxury.

I'm sorry to say... but you're not even CLOSE to being out of the woods.
In the next 3 weeks, you will become irritable, shaky, and experience
PMS-style mood swings. I had an emotional breakdown 3 weeks in because I
was mortally afraid of a little dental work! Looking back on it now it
sounds totally stupid, but I wanted a smoke so bad I might have killed
someone.=20

It gets easier over time, of course. For me, after about 6 weeks they
started to noticeably subside... but the cravings never completely went
away. Even now, and more often than I'd like to admit, there are times
where I think to myself "damn I could use a smoke". Instead, I walk. I
turn on my PS2. I breathe deep. I jerk it. Or I simply try to think
about something else.=20

Best advice I can give is this: know thyself and thy stress triggers.
Instead of a smoke break, walk around the block once or twice. Try to
surround yourself with some cool people that do NOT smoke (I know that's
a lot easier said than done). Join a gym, and actually go... or be
prepared to gain some weight. When you feel the stress creeping up, take
a deep breath, hold it... and slowly exhale. It helps.

Good luck bro. If you make it past the two month mark you will be well
over the worst of it, and you'll be in the minority... and you'll feel a
lot better.

-D

I think you turn the corner when you begin to realize the benefits of  
not smoking, and actually feel better. The longer you go without  
smoking, the more inertia you'll have to stay quit. If you turn that  
corner...

I quit for 2 years, now I smoke about 5-10 a week. More when I party.  
I'd say that's still too much. The difference between 1 and 5 cigs is  
probably not that much to your lungs. The first one does most of the  
damage.

-andy

> "Detox: Day 7"
>
> Perhaps someone out there feels my pain!?!?!
>
> I would have to believe cigarettes are like crack. I read the  
> reason they're so addictive is because they can work as a stimulant  
> OR a depressant. That kind of makes sense to me because I smoked in  
> the morning to help me wake up, and took smoke "breaks" to chill  
> when I'm busy on something.
>
> In the morning? After a shag? After a meal? At the club? During a  
> long phone call? When I'm bored?
>

> started smoking "full time."

> f11ck!ng time!

> wouldn't surprise me.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Quiting Smoking (cigarettes)

I feel pretty lucky too because I've always been able to just quit,  
like I'll just lose interest and stop completely.  Ways I reduce  
smoking are I roll my own, I don't smoke in the house, I never smoke  
in the car, which are good things anyway because you don't want that  
smell around, and I only really smoke when I have time to actually  
enjoy the cigarette.  That leaves me time for about 1-2 a day, maybe  
3 or 4 if I'm thinking a lot.

Contrast that to one of my friends, who knows I don't allow smoking  
in the car, so whenever we go places and I'm driving, light up one  
the second we get out of the car, so have to wait before going in the  
building, and then have to wait for him to finish the other one  
before we get in the car.  To me, that's not enjoying, that's just  
sucking one down for the sake of getting a rush.  Why bother?

On Fri, Feb 15, 2008 at 10:43:05AM -0800, CHUCK G wrote:
> I want to know how the ex-smokers on here cope. Yeah, I have patches, lozenges, and gum. I don't really have a method for administration other than that I've found I need something all the f11ck!ng time! 

In a phrase, one craving at a time.  The urge never goes away, you just
get used to it.  3 days, 3 weeks, 3 months, 3 years, you still sometimes
get hit with a powerful urge.  Maybe you lie to yourself and decide on
"just one more," or maybe you manage to decide "nah, I can hold off for
now."

if your feet are itching too, go for a walk; kill 2 with 1. :)

X-Greylist: Sender DNS name whitelisted, not delayed by milter-greylist-2.0.2 (kzsu.stanford.edu [127.0.0.1]); Fri, 15 Feb 2008 15:35:29 -0800 (PST)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ Shadow & Cut Chemist: The Hard Sell (last night)

I find this interesting, as there are completely different reviews on 
another list.  I'll include one here:

I went to the same DJ Shadow/Cut Chemist tour a few days ago too and 
thought exactly the same thing. Those guys are such sick producers and 
certainly capable technically, it was incredible that with their looping 
pedals and 8 decks that they only conjured up extremely simple loops and 
the aforementioned mashups.  No transcendence whatsoever, not even 
danceable grooves.  Either go for one or the other.  Blow me away or 
make me shake my ass.  And, preferably, do both.  I really hate going to 
"techno" events that are basically digital-ass tech house for, like, 6 
hours in a row with no dynamics and Ableton Live ping pong delays and 
occasional bass dropouts.  Where did the darkness and the soul and the 
emotion and the groove and the percussion go?

Sorry, I got wound up again about minimal fucking "techno".

- C

This was in response to this review:

I went to go see DJ Shadow and Cut Chemist "The Hard Sell" a few days 
ago.

I left wondering how two DJs with such huge record collections and all 
the time in the world to program a set could come up with a set that was 
about as creative as hearing Joe Random DJ play mashups. Oh boy, that 
"Gilligan's Island" cover set to the music of Stairway To Heaven.. which 
someone at work sent me as a mp3 two years ago. Yawn. I think basically 
we're in the transitionary period where music globalizes.. and the old 
rules for DJs are changing..

Does that answer your question?

=darwin



On 14 February 2008, CHUCK G wrote:

> Yeah, can't forget the off-center 45, and trippy, off-center, rotating visuals to go with. The 45's invading the City was a pretty badass clip too.
>
> That little invisible circle on the wall in my office is still spinning! Off center!!!
>
>
>
> Ravi Pina <ravi@cow.org> wrote: It was over here[1] and was an absolutely amazing
> show.  Koala's set felt way too short even for an
> opener.  I've seen him a few other times and his
> shows are a lot of fun.
>
> The Shadow/Chemist sets were beyond original it is
> difficult to know where to begin.  It was nice they
> had a introduction "tutorial" of what exactly they
> were going to be doing.  I was sitting in the balcony
> and overheard a few people trying to explain what
> they were going to be seeing to their friends.  Some
> were right and others were... at the wrong show.
>
> One technique that is amazing is where they fabricated
> a off-center 45 turntable which created one of a kind
> sounds from played 45s.
>

HA!

Oddly, when I saw Cut Chemist at 1015 last year (or was it 2k6?) he was off 
the heezy....surprised to hear the two of them together weren't 
more...um....I dunno "more"? lol

Also funny to hear you go off on the minimal thing. I love some of it, but 
totally agree with hearing DJ's who don't layer and build it like minimal is 
meant to do. You can make minimal sets extremely emotive and grooving if you 
try hard enough.

giggles, hehe.

In the end, I guess you had to be there. . . Megan & I danced (where we could find room, as the venue was sold out).

Guess whoever wrote the first review has already mastered mixing & scratching 45's on 8 decks. . . And man, would I love to see THEIR vinyl collection.

The parallel they attempt to illustrate between The Hard Sell and a "techno" event, along with the use of Ableton, is tragic at best.

My (grumpy) .02,

chuck

J.C.:

Point well taken, as always. I'm not surprised at some of the criticism from the "stand-by-the-dj-with-your-arms-folded-for-the-whole-set" types, especially on a subjective level, however I do not recant my praise of the show.

There! That's the first time ever, in the history of ever, I used the word grate. And it feels grate. Who the hell came up with grate anyways? Sounds very second-generation. SFR modern history lesson please.

Obliged (and still pretty grumpy),

Chuck

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Quitting Smoking (cigarettes)

------=_NextPart_000_0138_01C86FF1.814AE5F0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I quit three years ago.  Before I quit I was healthy, happy and
well-exercised.  After I quit it was one serious medical problem after
another.  Seriously.  I still have a desire for cigs and I keep a pack in
the drawer just in case:-)

I used Wellbutrin and gum to quit. I liked the rush although some find that
drug disturbing.  To replace the nicotene stimulant effect I drink lots of
coffee.

Apollo

From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Quiting Smoking (cigarettes)

Those that know me personally know that I can smoke like a 
chimney at times. A few that know me better, know that I've been 
really trying to quit over the last year and a 1/2.

After a few failed attempts, I learned to go cold 
turkey. The patch gave me annoying nightmares, and in the end 
you're still paying money for something you're hooked on 
(patches, gum). My longest non-smoking run recently was about 5 
months, with a bunch of 2-5 week runs interspersed as well in the last 1.5 
years. Right now I'm going on 2 weeks again.

I know I'm not completely successful, but the success I do have 
is attributed to distraction and exercise. I find the more 
things I distract myself with, the less time I have to think 
about it, the less it becomes an issue.

Sometimes I hang out at this forum too: http://www.quitnet.com. 
It's a really oddball community but they're really nice 
and pretty active. That's a good distraction to start out with.

Good luck Chuck, we're in the same boat! We live close, hit me 
up :-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Sad day on SFR... ok, so let's post something
 different.

interestingly enough, this is a NRR thread.. about being anti NRR on SFR.

 in regards to pinkko, i'd rather be on the no posts at all side of 
things myself. it keeps me from trudging through a mountain of mail and 
replies like 'ha-ha i'm smart.'

if anybody is fiending for topics to post about, here's a few:

what's your party pick for this weekend?
what's your favorite record of the moment?
did you hear a murmering of that party at that underground space? 
(uberzone is playing somewhere soon btw)
where do you see the future of the rave scene?
what happened to 'the future' in the rave scene. specifically why don't 
we hear tracks telling us like eskimos & egypt did with their track 
"welcome to the future"
how do you feel about the reprise of italo disco coming back like an 
endearing yet, cheesy homo-erotic phoenix from the ashes?
or my favorite, hey let's throw a party just for the hell of it and its 
free and everyone can come.. its sunny out. byob and veggie dogs!!

shit like this is real shit. if the NRRs build up we'll become like the 
land of the lost ravers in the socal raves list. where nary a word 
called rave is ever heard. and maybe possibly SFR would be in danger of 
becoming irrelevant (if it already hasn't).

of course NRRs that benefit ravers are welcome. philip's job wanted 
posting is a good example.

ok i done my bit.

peace and love,
sean.

Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote: Those that know me personally know that I can smoke like a 
chimney at times. A few that know me better, know that I've been 
really trying to quit over the last year and a 1/2.

After a few failed attempts, I learned to go cold 
turkey. The patch gave me annoying nightmares, and in the end 
you're still paying money for something you're hooked on 
(patches, gum). My longest non-smoking run recently was about 5 
months, with a bunch of 2-5 week runs interspersed as well in the last 1.5 
years. Right now I'm going on 2 weeks again.

I know I'm not completely successful, but the success I do have 
is attributed to distraction and exercise. I find the more 
things I distract myself with, the less time I have to think 
about it, the less it becomes an issue.

Sometimes I hang out at this forum too: http://www.quitnet.com. 
It's a really oddball community but they're really nice 
and pretty active. That's a good distraction to start out with.

Good luck Chuck, we're in the same boat! We live close, hit me 
up :-)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Content-Disposition: inline

Yeah, quitting is a bitch and a half. My record is about a month, I smoke
about a pack a day. Exercise helps tremendously. It's a lot easier to not
smoke if you want your lungs to be okay for the mile you run in the
mornings.

On Feb 15, 2008 5:13 PM, Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote:

> Those that know me personally know that I can smoke like a
> chimney at times. A few that know me better, know that I've been
> really trying to quit over the last year and a 1/2.
>
> After a few failed attempts, I learned to go cold
> turkey. The patch gave me annoying nightmares, and in the end
> you're still paying money for something you're hooked on
> (patches, gum). My longest non-smoking run recently was about 5
> months, with a bunch of 2-5 week runs interspersed as well in the last 1.5
> years. Right now I'm going on 2 weeks again.
>
> I know I'm not completely successful, but the success I do have
> is attributed to distraction and exercise. I find the more
> things I distract myself with, the less time I have to think
> about it, the less it becomes an issue.
>
> Sometimes I hang out at this forum too: http://www.quitnet.com.
> It's a really oddball community but they're really nice
> and pretty active. That's a good distraction to start out with.
>
> Good luck Chuck, we're in the same boat! We live close, hit me
> up :-)
>
> -terry
>
> ------------------------------------------
> terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
> SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org
>

twice - that takes the cake.  3rd's Oxycontin.  That made me puke for 
3 hours straight, but at least I could see.

Sarilion wrote:
> Your brain is fried.  Those things aren't even related.
>
>
> sarilion
>
.
My brain is just fine, thank you very much.

If I'm reading you right, then you're saying that the RAVE Act II did 
nothing to suppress the growth of Rave Culture in the USA, that it just 
collapsed, and went away on its own accord?

Not because party promoters might scared that if their venue gets busted 
that they'd be looking at losing that night's gate, a $250K fine, and 
having to serve a sentence of 10 years in a Federal, (no time off for 
good behavior) Super-Max Gulag if they get convicted?

And Rave is really good for nothing else, and serves no other purpose, 
other than to be used as background music to sell Stupid Ugly Vehicles?

That's gotta be good news for Moby, and other artists, since they 
doesn't have to worry about lost revenue streams from all the shows they 
aren't doing because it's against the law.

And acts like Daft Punk should just be grateful that a Kanye deigns to 
use their shit, instead of them being bigger than he is?

Is that right?

If it isn't, then how is the Rave Act II any less draconian then some of 
the Federal/State/Local War on Drugs legislation that is out there?

>don't we hear tracks telling us like eskimos & egypt did with their
