Subject: [sfraves] Historical Achievement- First Psychedelic Research at Harvard since 1966!  (MAPS)

--Apple-Mail-2-27946229
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

On Saturday, February 23, 2008, after more than a decade of hard work,  
Dr. John Halpern conducted the first experimental session in his study  
of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy in twelve subjects with treatment- 
resistant anxiety associated with advanced-stage cancer (or PDF). Dr.  
Halpern is also conducting a major five-year NIDA-funded study into  
the neurocognitive risks of heavy use of Ecstasy, enhancing his  
ability to balance the risks and benefits of MDMA. This historic start  
of the MDMA/cancer anxiety study would not have been possible without  
the contributions of many people, including his co-investigators, the  
members of Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) at both the Lahey Clinic  
Medical Center and McLean Hospital, both institutions' administrators  
and staff, and federal regulatory officials at FDA and even DEA. The  
study's $250,000 budget  is funded by Mr. Peter Lewis through a direct  
grant to McLean Hospital. MAPS assisted Dr. Halpern in the protocol  
design and approval process.

This experimental session was the first time in 42 years that a  
psychedelic was administered to a research subject at Harvard Medical  
School. Dr. Walter Pahnke, who conducted the classic Good Friday  
experiment in 1962, reported on the conclusion of his psilocybin  
research at Harvard in an unpublished paper written in 1966 (PDF).

The renaissance in psychedelic research has begun. It is now time to  
prove what we have been claiming for decades, that psychedelic- 
assisted psychotherapy can be beneficial to some patients in carefully  
controlled clinical settings. The promising results from MAPS'  US  
MDMA/PTSD research, and the start of Dr. Halpern's MDMA/cancer anxiety  
study, suggest that the eventualapproval of psychedelic psychotherapy   
is becoming more than a dream.


Apollo
apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid  
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for  
your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of  
empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone,  
but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson



--Apple-Mail-2-27946229--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: This lady @ my work (Totally NRR, but funny)

Never a dull moment in sunny, Happy Campbell.

This morning a lady at my work called in from the SJ Police station saying that she had been arrested for, yes, running INTO a police car yesterday. 

Her words: "It was the car or the cop." 

I guess she's locked-up because she refused to take a urine/blood test (there was a *problem with the Breathalyzer). That, and well, the other "thing with the car."

Moral of the story: I only respect her more. I hope she doesn't get fired. Sorry, can't name names, but I thought the story was worth sharing.

Happy Monday!

- CKG

--0-1218961431-1203967874=:79521--

Bossman gone today; tuning in!!!




Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote: 
Please tune in to KZSU by listening to 90.1 in the Bay Area or pointing
your web browser to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu.

If you're interested in guest appearing on any of our shows
or having a mix featured contact us using our email addresses
or: electronicadjs@kzsu.stanford.edu

Big Love Show with Jack Wang - Mondays from 3PM-6PM PST
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

This week Jack is proud to host Qorser and Rhythmist from Dobox Productions.
The live PA is going off right now with techno, house, and other electronica.

Lock it in!!!

More infos:
http://doboxrecordings.com/db/
                                 

Eclecktronik Groove with Holt Sorenson - Mon Nite (Tues) from 12AM-3AM PST
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Holt will be mixing it up for you tonight. Insomniacs of the world
untie as the beats move you into the morning!

hsomusic.com
myspace.com/hsomusic

Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Thursday from 9AM-12PM PST
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

After 14 years, DJ J.C.'s techno/house/electronica showcase has
garnered much attention and devotion. Like most folks at Stanford's
radio station, he's a volunteer, proving that his motivation isn't
a paycheck; it's his passion to share his interest in one of music's
most eclectic genres. With his conversational style, inclusion of
producers and musicians from both the local & international scene,
and his stewardship of the station's 24-hour marathons during
Solstices and Equinoxes, it's no wonder that DJ J.C has made a
connection with listeners in a very crowded market. Catch his live
broadcasts or listen to the previous week's program at underheard.org.

J.C. will email this week if he has an update on any guests.

Thanks for your support!!!

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show on Mon Nite/Tues Morn. 12-3AM


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-TRAIN
active life meets night  life
  
 as we move into springtime, remember that dancing =  cardio, and techno burns calories! join us for an AIDS/LifeCycle fundraising  effort and a chance to meet fellow party people who enjoy an active lifestyle.  
  
 each of our DJs this evening will be dropping techy  beats and representing their chosen sport:
  
 FOREST GREEN
(ForestGreen.org, Cute Fang  Recordings, Cute Things With Fangs, Daly City Recs.)
  
 MEK
(Stilldream, Techno Truth) 
  
 MO CORLEONE
(www.aidslifecycle.org/2130)
  
 TATAR
(www.aidslifecycle.org/3258)
  
 Friday, April 4th
Catalyst Cocktails
312  Harriet Street
San Francisco, CA
10:00pm - 2:00am
  
 All door proceeds to benefit AIDS/LifeCycle riders (i'm one of 'em!)
$5 -  $10 suggested donation, but everyone is welcome!
  
 skiers, snowboarders, cyclists, runners, and gym  rats are especially encouraged to check out the show. find workout buddies,  rideshares for tahoe trips, training partners, and more!
  
 see ya there!


*bliss does not require ignorance*

From sfraves-return-145107-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 27 01:29:00 2008
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-145107-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 30390 invoked by uid 1103); 27 Feb 2008 01:28:59 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 30360 invoked from network); 27 Feb 2008 01:28:59 -0000
From: "Henry E Kielarowski" <djapollo2k@mac.com>
To: "'SFR'" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tue, 26 Feb 2008 17:28:56 -0800
Message-ID: <001201c878e0$1f6661f0$5e3325d0$@com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Microsoft Office Outlook 12.0
Thread-Index: Ach40p/U7np8MqJEQmWGyTOgZ4gjpAADUnbw
Content-Language: en-us
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP:: @narcho - a special VOID show tonight..





Tonight's show will be noticeably different. Yes noticeably. There will be
no mixing at all, and I'll be mostly dispensing with the psychedelically
tinged, spaced out rock and disco-fied sounds I so often spin on the show.
Instead, I'll be taking a far noisier nostalgia ride into one of the most
important yet brief periods of my life -

the era of the anarcho-punk scene.

The anarcho scene was a mostly British phenomenon from the early 80's,
spawned from the ashes of punk rock and led by bands like Crass, The Mob,
and The Poison Girls. It was heavily fuelled by the politics of @narchy,
situationism and a desire to bring about a more utopian world through
autonomous living and direct action.

It was also in many ways responsible for helping birth the modern indie
music scene with it's novel, experimental and totally DIY approach to music
creation, production, distribution and setting up record labels, which
completely ignored the established music industry of the time.
Though long dead, and not well documented, the effects of the anarcho scene
are still with us today, it's DIY approach very much carried over into the
rave and rock scenes of the 90's and beyond..

The playlist for tonight's show is limited, which means a shorter show, so
TUNE IN EARLY or you may miss it completely. I will however be padding the
show out with some chatter about the bands and music, along with some music
from other artists who shared the unconventional philosophical outlooks of
the anarcho scene, or had some influence on it - groups like Can, Public
Image, The Raincoats, Dead Kennedys etc. So in some ways tonight's show will
be similar to the post-punk shows I've done in the past..

Join Jeno at 9pm tonight, Tues Feb 26th..

go to http://www.90hz.org to listen and chat..


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

The Bay Area punk scene has been (and still is) one of my personal faves...=
I definitely see it as critical to the USA punk movement as much as DC, LA =
or NYC.=20

Another favorite old skool Bay Area punk band I love, was the Avengers...ci=
rca like '79 or so. Their self titled debut is fuckin' crucial.

Big ups the Bay's music scene in general though....I think a myriad of soun=
ds are really well represented here.=20

Incidentally, this show has been interesting tonight...at times a bit tedio=
us, but I still love to hear a huge one of my musical influences play stuff=
 that may have shaped or influenced them in some small way. Hotness.

>>> @narchy,
>>> situationism and a desire to bring about a more utopian world through
>>> autonomous living and direct action.
>>>

>>> indie

>>> to music
>>> creation, production, distribution and setting up record labels, which
>>> completely ignored the established music industry of the time.

>>> anarcho scene

>>> into the

For those that are to young to remember, there was a pretty hot punk scene 
in the SF bay area at that time centered around the Mabuhay Gardens, 
Berkeley Square, etc.  Don't know if he'll play any of the local bands that 
spawned around that time such as the Dead Kennedys, The Mutants, the Circle 
Jerks, and Flipper.

But here's some pictures from that time:

http://sanfrancisco.tribe.net/m/template/pub%2Ctribes%2CTribePhotoAlbum.vm?tribeid=4d633a65-14a4-48aa-a930-6d43fd1ba38e

I was never really a punk, but one of the people in this photo was my high 
school girlfriend...

http://sfbpunk.tribe.net/m/photos/217581fe-9737-4474-86fe-cf3fcef7fae5

Best,

Peter

> On Feb 26, 2008, at 5:28 PM, Henry E Kielarowski wrote:
>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> Tonight's show will be noticeably different. Yes noticeably. There
>> will be
>> no mixing at all, and I'll be mostly dispensing with the
>> psychedelically
>> tinged, spaced out rock and disco-fied sounds I so often spin on the
>> show.
>> Instead, I'll be taking a far noisier nostalgia ride into one of the
>> most
>> important yet brief periods of my life -
>>
>> the era of the anarcho-punk scene.
>>
>> The anarcho scene was a mostly British phenomenon from the early 80's,
>> spawned from the ashes of punk rock and led by bands like Crass, The
>> Mob,
>> and The Poison Girls. It was heavily fuelled by the politics of
>> @narchy,
>> situationism and a desire to bring about a more utopian world through
>> autonomous living and direct action.
>>
>> It was also in many ways responsible for helping birth the modern
>> indie
>> music scene with it's novel, experimental and totally DIY approach
>> to music
>> creation, production, distribution and setting up record labels, which
>> completely ignored the established music industry of the time.
>> Though long dead, and not well documented, the effects of the
>> anarcho scene
>> are still with us today, it's DIY approach very much carried over
>> into the
>> rave and rock scenes of the 90's and beyond..
>>
>> The playlist for tonight's show is limited, which means a shorter
>> show, so
>> TUNE IN EARLY or you may miss it completely. I will however be
>> padding the
>> show out with some chatter about the bands and music, along with
>> some music
>> from other artists who shared the unconventional philosophical
>> outlooks of
>> the anarcho scene, or had some influence on it - groups like Can,
>> Public
>> Image, The Raincoats, Dead Kennedys etc. So in some ways tonight's
>> show will
>> be similar to the post-punk shows I've done in the past..
>>
>> Join Jeno at 9pm tonight, Tues Feb 26th..
>>
>> go to http://www.90hz.org to listen and chat..
>>
>>

Another note about this quote, if you could call it that, I stayed up =20
kind of late, well not late in raver terms, but late in the sense that =20
I had to get up early and drive over the hill to an early class, and =20
copied parts of what was I think a really important 2 hour interview =20

you're thinking of voting for Hillary in 2008, you should listen to =20

Sorry for the lengthy post ... might I suggest a human rave chain from
SF to SJ ... they did it in Lithuania and soon after the wall fell.

What you all don't know about about Hillary ... you know why Bill
married her?  Her father, Hugh Rodham, was the head of the mob in
Chicago.  He had a partner named Dan Rostenkowsky.  And it just so
happened (he) happened to be part of the most powerful Ways and Means
Committee in Washington ... then they appointed Webb Hubbell to
Attorney General, because they knew anyone else they appointed, I'd
get ... but then I got Webb Hubbell and put him in prison ... I had
caught Vince and Hillary screwin ... at that time, my feud was with
Bill Clinton ... Vince thought that tape was fixin' to be aired in the
Washington Times ... I have no idea if he was murdered or not ... but
the autopsy was obvious ... he didn't die in Fort Marcy Park ... I
went to the Rose Law Firm and caught them with boxes marked V.F.
taking them to be burned ... there was no way Bill Clinton would have
been reelected, except for one person ... Bob Dole ... the thing you
need to be the most afraid of, and you should be afraid ... it was all
scheduled that Bill would run, they would wait, and then she would run
... I've been a part of destroying countries you have never even heard
of ... the Puppetmasters control everything ... how do you think the
Clintons come up with all this money?  And who do you think controls
the war in Iraq?  Malachi has asked Bush twice to leave ... we ain't
leavin' ... y'all think you're votin' for President ... you're not
gonna pick who's President ... others are ... but the way they're
gonna get us is ... they're taking American jobs ... there's a term in
social engineering called empowerment ... they want to disempower the
people, because if you have enough money you can control your future
... and they're strippin' us down ... and we don't have two years ...
this thing's over in two years, buddy.

There's one way to beat 'em.

... you'll know no difference between George Bush and the Clinton
Administration.  Does it not make sense to you that since the statue
of Saddam Hussein came down that the oil companies have made the
largest quarterly profits in the history of the world?  Nothing's
gonna change.  The only thing that will be different is Hillary will
be the boss.  We're gonna go back to the old Clinton days in Arkansas.
    You cross them, they'll kill you ... Bush don't care ... you cross
Hillary, you won't live to see tomorrow.

- Larry Nichols, Alex Jones Show, February 7, 2008,  approx 1 hr 40 min

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: More impeachable offenses?

By PETE YOST, Associated Press Writer
Wed Feb 27, 3:33 AM ET



WASHINGTON - When Special Counsel Patrick Fitzgerald wanted to find out what 
was going on inside Vice President Dick Cheney's office, the prosecutor in the 
CIA leak probe made a logical move. He dropped a grand jury subpoena on the 
White House for all the relevant e-mail.

One problem: Even though White House computer technicians hunted high and low, 
an entire week's worth of e-mail from Cheney's office was missing. The week was 
Sept. 30, 2003, to Oct. 6, 2003, the opening days of the Justice Department's 
probe into whether anyone at the White House leaked the identity of CIA 
operative Valerie Plame.

http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080227/ap_on_go_pr_wh/white_house_e_mail

I've been an avid support of MAPS since 2003-2004. They're doing incredible
work, I recommend everyone donate to them as soon as possible.

On Sat, Feb 23, 2008 at 6:42 PM, Apollo <djapollo2k@mac.com> wrote:

> On Saturday, February 23, 2008, after more than a decade of hard work,
> Dr. John Halpern conducted the first experimental session in his study
> of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy in twelve subjects with treatment-
> resistant anxiety associated with advanced-stage cancer (or PDF). Dr.
> Halpern is also conducting a major five-year NIDA-funded study into
> the neurocognitive risks of heavy use of Ecstasy, enhancing his
> ability to balance the risks and benefits of MDMA. This historic start
> of the MDMA/cancer anxiety study would not have been possible without
> the contributions of many people, including his co-investigators, the
> members of Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) at both the Lahey Clinic
> Medical Center and McLean Hospital, both institutions' administrators
> and staff, and federal regulatory officials at FDA and even DEA. The
> study's $250,000 budget  is funded by Mr. Peter Lewis through a direct
> grant to McLean Hospital. MAPS assisted Dr. Halpern in the protocol
> design and approval process.
>
> This experimental session was the first time in 42 years that a
> psychedelic was administered to a research subject at Harvard Medical
> School. Dr. Walter Pahnke, who conducted the classic Good Friday
> experiment in 1962, reported on the conclusion of his psilocybin
> research at Harvard in an unpublished paper written in 1966 (PDF).
>
> The renaissance in psychedelic research has begun. It is now time to
> prove what we have been claiming for decades, that psychedelic-
> assisted psychotherapy can be beneficial to some patients in carefully
> controlled clinical settings. The promising results from MAPS'  US
> MDMA/PTSD research, and the start of Dr. Halpern's MDMA/cancer anxiety
> study, suggest that the eventualapproval of psychedelic psychotherapy
> is becoming more than a dream.
>
>
> Apollo
> apollo@speakeasy.org
>
> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
> Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid
> them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for
> your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're
> fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho
>
> "Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of
> empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another
> person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and
> sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  -
> Fritz Williams
>
> "I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone,
> but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v915)
Date: Wed, 27 Feb 2008 18:30:02 -0800
References: <206041.93001.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.915)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Presidio parties (was Re: [sfraves] SRR?: Lock Bumping)

i was part of a crew that threw a rave at the Presidio.  it was a  
fundraiser for the SF National Organization for Women (NOW) education  
fund.  this was in 1997 or 1998.

we threw the party in the Letterman Gymnasium. there were 300+ people,  
a bouncy castle, and two systems.  the fire department showed up  
because an alarm went off, and we STILL went 'til 7 am!

one of the benefits of doing a party WITH PERMISSION in a federal  
facility is that you don't generally need permits. local po-po or the  
sheriff are usually the ones busting parties. the National Park Police  
don't give a crap, so long as you're totally obvious about it and have  
permission to be using the facility. but do an outdoor renegade, and  
they'll shut you down real quick.

-philip-

"Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
  >>we threw the party in the Letterman Gymnasium. there were 300+ people, 
a bouncy castle, and two systems. the fire department showed up 
because an alarm went off, and we STILL went 'til 7 am!
   
  Classic! Much props. 
   
   
   
   
  
"Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
  i was part of a crew that threw a rave at the Presidio. it was a 
fundraiser for the SF National Organization for Women (NOW) education 
fund. this was in 1997 or 1998.

we threw the party in the Letterman Gymnasium. there were 300+ people, 
a bouncy castle, and two systems. the fire department showed up 
because an alarm went off, and we STILL went 'til 7 am!

one of the benefits of doing a party WITH PERMISSION in a federal 
facility is that you don't generally need permits. local po-po or the 
sheriff are usually the ones busting parties. the National Park Police 
don't give a crap, so long as you're totally obvious about it and have 
permission to be using the facility. but do an outdoor renegade, and 
they'll shut you down real quick.

-philip-

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] :: Last Fridays @ Anu is THIS Friday, west coast Techno special appearances ::

Friday, 29 February 2008

RAY presents:

F A K T I O N : because san francisco needs another techno cult
with special guests:

DJ Developer -- Modularz Sound Division [ Los Angeles|the world ]
Endosine -- Drum Machine Museum [ San Francisco|Berlin ] // Live

Last Fridays at:
Anu-Bar
43 Sixth St., San Francisco, CA

DJ Developer is known throughout the US, Mexico and abroad for quick mixing
abilities and for leading LA's second wave of Techno.  In 2004 he shifted
his
focus to production.  Now in 2008 he demonstrates his mastery of both: He
launched the label "Modularz Sound Division" with Detroit legend Fanon
Flowers
(now living in Los Angeles) and is performing in public again, producing
shows
under the Modularz name, featuring various talented artists from LA and
elsewhere.

Join us for this San Francisco appearance before Developer begins the
European
leg of his tour in Spain and beyond.

Endosine: Literally translated, Endosine is the wave within. The modulating
force within all existence. Techno is everywhere, an element of the natural
and mechanized constructs around us. Connect to the wave within. Connect to
Endosine.

This will be Endosine's last US appearance before he flies off to Berlin for
an extended stay, working on production and advancing the standards of
Techno
and Electronica.

10 PM to 2 AM
Cost: $5 21+
Official Site: http://www.faktionsf.com/

Friday, 28 March 2008:

SAYAKA - BABD/Filter.SF [ Japan|San Francisco ]

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

I have once again taken up running, not so much for me to look sexy  
for you, but so I feel good, I think.  And I saw an 80 year old woman  
out there running this morning.  Maybe she knows something!

I want to bring up something Doug posted a few weeks ago about the  
debt owed to black people for slavery.  I didn't really read it, I  
think I skimmed over it, I probably should have.  I wish I had 48  
hours in a day, but frankly that probably wouldn't be enough time for  
the research I want to do.  But I would pose a question, at what point  
would we move on from the hard feelings while at the same time  
remembering the dangers of those times?

--

Do you take checks?

- Better Off Dead

ugh... seems like it's impossible to have a conversation about the mutaytor without someone dredging up the matty nash/to catch a predator dirt. i guess everyone loves a good load of dirty laundry. 

no, he's not involved with the band anymore. 

 yes, they still create and perform some exceptionally kick-ass music.

it's unfortunate that the entire outfit (over 30 members) was punished for the actions of one idiot, but that's business for you. here's an article from about a year ago where buck down explains some of the band's history, the issues surrounding the bust, next steps for the mutaytor, etc. 

http://www.glidemagazine.com/Articles/51944/Buck-Down-of-The-Mutaytor.html

happy learning :)

love,
mo

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: MOKSHA TRIBE: PHOENIX: 3-29-2008

Saturday March 29th, 2008
10PM to 6AM In celebration of the rebirth of MOKSHA TRIBE, we bring you...
PHOENIX

A universal symbol of the sun, mystical rebirth, resurrection and
immortality, this legendary red "fire bird" was believed to die in its
self-made flames periodically then rise again out of its own ashes. Linked
to the worship of the fiery sun and sun gods such as Mexico's
Quetzalcoatl, it was named "a god of Phoenecia" by the Phoenician. To
alchemists, it symbolized the the destruction and creation of new forms of
matter along the way to the ultimate transformation: physical and
spiritual

http://phoenix.mokshatribe.net

Two full rooms of music:

Fire Room
 - NomadicDJ (Moksha Tribe)
 - AndyW vs. Chris Jackson (Resource Records Tag team)
 - Forest Green (ForestGreen.org)
 - Dragn'fly (DJDragnFly.com, DJ4NORML)
 - Andy Kaotik (Audio Dream Control, Boston, MA)
 - ShezTek (Moksha Tribe)

Flight Room (in order of appearance)
 - Jose Padilla (Moksha Tribe)
 - Bam (Evil Breaks)
 - DJ DV8 (Moksha Tribe)
 - Marcine (Moksha Tribe)
 - Brian Behlendorf (Cloudfactory, FNF, Hyperreal)

Visuals by Viberation
Sound by SWAT
Lighting by Radiant Atmospheres
Convenient Bay Area underground location
You will be treated with love and respect

This event is dedicated to Apollo & Joey for the vision, the dream, & the
love they created.

ALL PROFITS FROM THIS EVENT WILL BE DONATED TO LARKIN STREET YOUTH SERVICES
www.larkinstreetyouth.org

Limited presale tickets are now available for $15.00 at
tickets.mokshatribe.net



------------------------------
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

Well it's 7:20 on the East Coast.

What gets you up in the morning?  I've been asked that question a lot =20
at various times in the last 15 years of my life.  It started, I =20
believe in my Equinox days.  Remember that company?  Shut down, kind =20
of like the rave scene, only in a more permanent way.  I know, there's =20
more to that story.  Possibly the next batch of hearing it came in =20
other success related things, the Franklin Day Planner seminars, =20
reading books like Covey and Orman.  Maybe not specifically, I'm =20
really not sure where.  Maybe I hear Alex Jones bellowing it through =20
his microphone once in a while.  And don't email me and say I'm sexist =20
and the microphone is some kind of phallic symbol.  Just save it.

By the way, there is this girl up at UCSC this week selling vagina =20
pops to raise money for charity and there are Vagina Monologues being =20
done I think at Porter.  1 for $3 and 2 for $5.

Anyway, this play I saw up at school last night (Subject B's =20
Confession), had me thinking about other things related to it, and =20
that's what woke me up this morning.  Who needs an alarm clock anymore?

OK that's it for now, have a nice day and please think about how =20
"change" is related to "We Are Change".  Due by Friday night (well =20
Saturday morning) at 2AM.

Do you know where your children are?  We do.

- Subject B's Confession

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2/29 not 3/29 --> Re: [sfraves] BSP: 3-29: Simple: Breaks all night!!!!



right.  party collision, that's why I can't go catch D and why I had to
plug Faktion again. =)

Sorry if we're confusing everyone!  There's like 6 parties tonight, but it's
all good.  Come visit all of us for drinks and stuff!  In and out ok for mine
if people pay the door (if they leave before we start charging and come back
the guy helping with the door may not remember em, $5 means a hand stamp), so
meet up on scenic 6th street, then you can all rideshare over to the UG loc
or something =)  Help keep local EDM alive a few bucks at a time!


So, TONIGHT, 29 Feb:
Osby: UG location
Ray: Anu, 43 6th st
Others: umm, I've lost track of all the parties tonight. :P

Osby: UG: Simple: Breaky stuff except for D's techno
(I'm expecting hard techno when I see D's name?)
Ray: Bar(Anu):  Faktion: Techno/minimal and live PA of techno-like genre.
(Endosine's kinda experimental, techno, electronica, I suck at describing)

Osby: 10p-5a or later?
Ray: 10p-2a for the cool music, but it's a bar so people can drink starting
whenever if 21+.

Did that help in the slightest?

Subject: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance

hey i thought that SFR was a place where we could tell each other what 
was happening and we couldn't step on each other's toes. let's communic8 
and give some support. also it pays to be proactive and promote your 
parties well in advance so people don't all equally lose money.. i'm all 
for competition and survival of the fittest but there are times when 
great parties get unnoticed because of another more conveniently located 
party is in the hood.

i think the SFR calendar  was devised to assist in calling these nights. 
does that cal. still effectively work? anybody still maintaining that? 
i'd consider signing up for it again if all the great bsps were there 
instead of here.

la la la..

disconnect sean

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 2/29 not 3/29 --> Re: [sfraves] BSP: 3-29: Simple: Breaks all night!!!!

God you ain't kidding, there IS a ton going on tonight.  Jump is also going
own at Shine with my old time inspirations, Ethan and Micron and Forest.
With my timeslot at Simple and the drive from Sac to SF, I'll probably not 
make either Faktion or Jump
but i'm gonna try to stop by each for a minute if the troops in tow can get
their shit togeter early enough.  Come to think of it, I probably caused
some confusion when I went on my rant about Forest's Bday.  I know she's
starting the celebrating at Shine and just meant if she came by Simple
afterwards, well that's where I'd be unleasing my fury of ass spanking.

Even with the confusion, I don't think any real toe-stepping occurred.  Life 
did seem less confusing when Karina was updating the SFR calendar ... any 
chance someone can pony up for that task again?

Oh and about expecting me to whip out some hard techno tonight, I dunno. I'm 
actually more of a general tech-whore than a "hard techno" dj and what I 
play really has to do with the occassion.  I'll probably slip out a more 
proper tech-heavy set when me & amber hit up Faktion in April (pre-plug, 
yes, it is!) but as for tonight, I might come out with anything from 
tech-funk to tech-breaks to heavy tech-house and sure, if I got a hyphy 
crowd the hard 4x4 might come out of my back pocket.. it just depends... but 
tech-y, I'm sure it will be.  But we'll have to see what actually comes out, 
once I get there.  Either way, a wild ride will be in order...

tonights.... gonna be a great night... all around..

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance



Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this month,
and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so some
overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
when the different scheduling strategies overlap.

I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part because
it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special Fridays,
leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part, parties
all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
each month for a party.

I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun ourselves,
and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)

Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
forum so we all know what we're all planning?

Ray

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance

The idea of promoters "claiming dates" is kind of preposterous to me. It's 
always annoyed me when I'd attempt to throw an event and hear people bitch 
about it "competing" with other promoters events.

I mean...if you don't want me throwing an event that competes, why don't you 
book me so I have something else going on that night? No booking for your 
party? Expect some healthy competition! There is an entire city with SCADS 
of people who listen to EDM here to appease, there is no good reason for 
people not to do whatever the fuck they want w/o regard for other people's 
events.

>
>
> Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this month,
> and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so some
> overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
> undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
> for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
> trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
> when the different scheduling strategies overlap.
>
> I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part because
> it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special Fridays,
> leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part, 
> parties
> all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
> good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
> start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
> window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
> each month for a party.
>
> I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
> give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
> least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun ourselves,
> and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
> overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)
>
> Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
> claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
> committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
> set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
> forum so we all know what we're all planning?
>
> Ray

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance

i don't really think "claiming dates" is necessary.  the point of the 
calendar was always to serve as a single source where people could go and 
see what was going on in a single night.  there have always been multiple 
events and there always will be.  so no pissing on any date is necessary - 
and if i remember correctly, you could post the details of your event as far 
in advance as you wanted (as long as those details are complete and 
finalized) and as soon as the week before...  other last minutes events were 
always posted the last minute, but it's not 1999 anymore folks , so I bet 
that'd be at a minimum...

it's not about a competition.  like i said, it's 1999 anymore boys.

even if i'm booked at other events, i don't see other events going on the 
same night as competition, but then again, I bring a wider out of town heads 
on account and don't won't accept gigs that appeal to the same crowd at more 
than one evnent, so i can do 2 parties (or even 3) different events in the 
bay these days and i've seen them all sell out...

it's all about doing your own thing and just being as careful as you can to 
avoid events on single nights that might draw the same crowd and follow a 
similar theme.

i think everyone tonight will do well.

so see y'all tonight!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance

Yea, ratify on all of that.

I guess maybe the "competition" thing seems ot happen in the lovely world o' 
breakbeats more than any other scene. I have literally had people tell me 
not to throw an event on a certain night because other crewss might see it 
as direct competiton. And again I say...well, if you aren't gonna book me 
for your event, then don't be fuggin' surprised when I throw my own. Not 
that I do a lot of event throwing, I am far too poor for that - but it does 
occasionally happen, and when I do, the last thing I wanna deal with is 
whiny promoters bitching about me taking from their crowd. (I never realized 
people owned any particular crowd anyway - sheesh)

This is probably why I just try and help other people out with  their events 
now anyway...less stress for me and I still get to be part of the process. 
Helping out can be equally as reqarding.

>i don't really think "claiming dates" is necessary.  the point of the 
>calendar was always to serve as a single source where people could go and 
>see what was going on in a single night.  there have always been multiple 
>events and there always will be.  so no pissing on any date is necessary - 
>and if i remember correctly, you could post the details of your event as 
>far in advance as you wanted (as long as those details are complete and 
>finalized) and as soon as the week before...  other last minutes events 
>were always posted the last minute, but it's not 1999 anymore folks , so I 
>bet that'd be at a minimum...
>
> it's not about a competition.  like i said, it's 1999 anymore boys.
>
> even if i'm booked at other events, i don't see other events going on the 
> same night as competition, but then again, I bring a wider out of town 
> heads on account and don't won't accept gigs that appeal to the same crowd 
> at more than one evnent, so i can do 2 parties (or even 3) different 
> events in the bay these days and i've seen them all sell out...
>
> it's all about doing your own thing and just being as careful as you can 
> to avoid events on single nights that might draw the same crowd and follow 
> a similar theme.
>
> i think everyone tonight will do well.

> so see y'all tonight!

>>>
>>>
>>> Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this 
>>> month,
>>> and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so some
>>> overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
>>> undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
>>> for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
>>> trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
>>> when the different scheduling strategies overlap.
>>>
>>> I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part 
>>> because
>>> it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special 
>>> Fridays,
>>> leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part, 
>>> parties
>>> all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
>>> good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
>>> start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
>>> window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
>>> each month for a party.
>>>
>>> I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
>>> give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
>>> least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun 
>>> ourselves,
>>> and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
>>> overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)
>>>
>>> Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
>>> claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
>>> committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
>>> set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
>>> forum so we all know what we're all planning?
>>>
>>> Ray

On Fri, 29 Feb 2008, DJ Disconnect wrote:

> i think the SFR calendar  was devised to assist in calling these nights. does 
> that cal. still effectively work? anybody still maintaining that? i'd 
> consider signing up for it again if all the great bsps were there instead of 
> here.

The SFR calendar is dead. However, Brian 
and I have been tossing around 2 ideas:

1. A wiki, like media-wiki, we would set it up and people would 
just add/edit events, like...a wiki!

2. I have a user-editable event CMS that my company's developed, 
we use it for some of our resort clients, I was gonna adapt it, 
slap it on sfraves.org, and start handing our individual logins 
for people to add/edit events.
here's an example:
http://www.montbleuresort.com/events.php?section=All+Events

Any thoughts?
I suppose we could just try both, lemee get that database 
started and if anyone's interested in helping, being an event 
admin let me know.

-terry

the guy helping with the door may not remember em, $5 means a hand stamp), so
meet up on scenic 6th street, then you can all rideshare over to the UG loc
or something =)  Help keep local EDM alive a few bucks at a time!


So, TONIGHT, 29 Feb:
Osby: UG location
Ray: Anu, 43 6th st
Others: umm, I've lost track of all the parties tonight. :P

Osby: UG: Simple: Breaky stuff except for D's techno
(I'm expecting hard techno when I see D's name?)
Ray: Bar(Anu):  Faktion: Techno/minimal and live PA of techno-like genre.
(Endosine's kinda experimental, techno, electronica, I suck at describing)

Osby: 10p-5a or later?
Ray: 10p-2a for the cool music, but it's a bar so people can drink starting
whenever if 21+.

Did that help in the slightest?

i'm just thankful that i live in a corner of the planet where "too many parties" is a real concern. i love having choices, and i also really enjoy bouncing from killer event to killer event when i can swing it. 

i do my best to show respect and common courtesy when planning a party, but the sheer volume of events makes it impossible to keep up with everything.  the way i see it, there are more than enough bouncy dancing freaks to go around. this town could certainly have worse problems than an abundance of stellar music.

love,
mo

Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote: Yea, ratify on all of that.

I guess maybe the "competition" thing seems ot happen in the lovely world o' 
breakbeats more than any other scene. I have literally had people tell me 
not to throw an event on a certain night because other crewss might see it 
as direct competiton. And again I say...well, if you aren't gonna book me 
for your event, then don't be fuggin' surprised when I throw my own. Not 
that I do a lot of event throwing, I am far too poor for that - but it does 
occasionally happen, and when I do, the last thing I wanna deal with is 
whiny promoters bitching about me taking from their crowd. (I never realized 
people owned any particular crowd anyway - sheesh)

This is probably why I just try and help other people out with  their events 
now anyway...less stress for me and I still get to be part of the process. 
Helping out can be equally as reqarding.

>i don't really think "claiming dates" is necessary.  the point of the 
>calendar was always to serve as a single source where people could go and 
>see what was going on in a single night.  there have always been multiple 
>events and there always will be.  so no pissing on any date is necessary - 
>and if i remember correctly, you could post the details of your event as 
>far in advance as you wanted (as long as those details are complete and 
>finalized) and as soon as the week before...  other last minutes events 
>were always posted the last minute, but it's not 1999 anymore folks , so I 
>bet that'd be at a minimum...
>
> it's not about a competition.  like i said, it's 1999 anymore boys.
>
> even if i'm booked at other events, i don't see other events going on the 
> same night as competition, but then again, I bring a wider out of town 
> heads on account and don't won't accept gigs that appeal to the same crowd 
> at more than one evnent, so i can do 2 parties (or even 3) different 
> events in the bay these days and i've seen them all sell out...
>
> it's all about doing your own thing and just being as careful as you can 
> to avoid events on single nights that might draw the same crowd and follow 
> a similar theme.

> i think everyone tonight will do well.

>>>
>>>
>>> Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this 
>>> month,
>>> and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so some
>>> overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
>>> undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
>>> for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
>>> trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
>>> when the different scheduling strategies overlap.
>>>
>>> I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part 
>>> because
>>> it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special 
>>> Fridays,
>>> leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part, 
>>> parties
>>> all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
>>> good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
>>> start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
>>> window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
>>> each month for a party.
>>>
>>> I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
>>> give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
>>> least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun 
>>> ourselves,
>>> and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
>>> overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)
>>>
>>> Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
>>> claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
>>> committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
>>> set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
>>> forum so we all know what we're all planning?
>>>
>>> Ray

Saturday, March 1st, 2008


[ K O N T R O L ]


minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup



featuring from New York City:


DEREK PLASLAIKO  ( Spectral Sound . The Bunker )

Derek Plaslaiko doesn't make records, but he sure as hell
knows how to play 'em.  One of a select few to have made
a name for himself based on DJ skills alone, Derek's
dedication and immense musical knowledge, coupled with his
anything-goes attitude make every set a memorable dance
floor experience.  Once a prominent figure on the Detroit
party scene, he relocated to NYC a few years back and was
soon crowned "Best Techno DJ" by the Village Voice.  We
simply call him "The Man", and are excited to welcome him
back for an extended encore performance.



and San Francisco's own:


CLAUDE VONSTROKE  ( Mothership . Dirtybird )

The last time our friend Barclay Crenshaw played for us,
just a couple short years ago in August '05, it was one of
the first times his pseudonym Claude VonStroke had
appeared in print on a flyer.  My how times change!  Now a
bona fide international superstar synonymous with the new
sound of SF, the inimitable 'Stroker returns to [KONTROL]
to lay down a specially crafted techno set you won't hear
anywhere else.



with [KONTROL] residents:


CRAIG KUNA  ( Platform . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO  ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
NIKOLA BAYTALA  ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )
SAMMY D  ( Dirtybird . Utensil )


________________________________________________


The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

________________________________________________


Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

Flyer:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K33/K33H.jpg

Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K33/K33P.jpg


________________________________________________


DEREK PLASLAIKO

Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper int=
o
the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
trends, forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that make
the staunchest of chin-stroking, note-taking trainspotters lose their shit
on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.

Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. H=
e
quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties=
.
He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  Wit=
h
a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during tha=
t
time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to hea=
d
east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs a=
t
the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lam=
b
monthly parties. More recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
"Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.

The last time Derek played for [KONTROL] in February '07, he so thouroughly
impressed both the crowd and our resident DJs that we have been drooling
over the day we would have him back, and we're happy to report that day has
come. This time Derek comes to us as part of the "Death Is Nothing To Fear"
Spectral Residencies, on his first major US tour.

---> LINKS:

Derek's Website: (w/ lots of free sets for download)
http://plaslaiko.net

Derek on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko


---> AUDIO:

Derek's brand new Resident Advisor podcast!
http://www.residentadvisor.net/podcast-episode.aspx?id=3D92

Live @ The Bunker, 2008 (Spectral Tour Kickoff - 5 hour set!)
http://feeds.feedburner.com/TheBunkerPodcast

Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia, 2006  (2 hours - 111MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelp=
hia_07.15.06.mp3


---> VIDEO:

Live @ The Bunker, 2007 (Detroit Takeover night)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D6fvYgXJiNdM

Derek @ Mutek Igloofest 2008
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Dsk8b1UbBQlY

CLAUDE VONSTROKE

"I would like to come over=85what are you having for dinner?" asks the cree=
py
character in Claude VonStroke's first hit record, "Deep Throat."  After
selling through 10 pressings in 2005, "Deep Throat" quickly put VonStroke o=
n
the map as an up and coming artist.  The success of the single was followed
up by "Who's Afraid of Detroit?," another international hit championed by
Richie Hawtin who called it the "Best Track of 2006" in DJ magazine.  Soon
after he released his full length debut album, "Beware of the Bird" to
excellent reviews, further establishing him as an original talent in the
world of underground dance music. Since then, Claude has done remixes for a
very diverse group of top artists ranging all the way from indie-rock band
The Rapture, to electro legends Newcleus, to minimalists like Matt Tolfrey
and Jeff Samuel.

Claude VonStroke is better known to locals as Barclay Crenshaw, the owner o=
f
San Francisco's quirky tech-funk label, dirtybird.  The label consists of
Crenshaw (VonStroke,) friends and fellow producers Justin Martin, Christian
Martin, and Worthy, and a diverse assortment of top remixers from around th=
e
globe including John Tejada, Audion, Diplo, 3 Channels, Dj Assault, and
Kevin Saunderson.

The idea for dirtybird began in 2003 when Crenshaw was producing an intense
5 hour DVD about electronic music called, "Intellect." The project was a
labor of love, taking almost 2 years to complete and starring over 35 top
producers and legendary DJs such as Derrick May, Swayzak, Derrick Carter,
Deep Dish, Magda, Theo Parish, and many more.  The main goal of the
"Intellect" project was to make an informative DVD that could help DJs
advance their careers in electronic music. The result was Crenshaw himself
starting dirtybird records and a production career under the alias Claude
VonStroke.

Since 2005, dirtybird has managed to solidify a reputation for releasing
oddball classic techno and house tracks, and in the process has become one
of the hottest labels on the planet. The outdoor dirtybird parties in San
Francisco's scenic Golden Gate Park have also become a legendary summer
destination point for both locals and international travelers.

In addition to production and label management, Claude VonStroke has an
intense regimen for preparation and a great ear for song selection. His DJ
sets are always inspiring and surprising. You will never hear a set of
monotonous music because Claude always takes time to find the special cuts
that make for a completely original experience that is not to be missed.

In 2008, Claude is hard at work on his second album, in addition to
fostering his latest project, Mothership Records.  Mothership was started i=
n
2007 as VonStroke's outlet for deep and experimental techno. The first
record on Mothership became a summer classic and sold 7,000 vinyl records
and sat at #1 on the Beatport minimal techno chart for 8 weeks. Proceeds
from the label go towards children's music education in Claude's hometown o=
f
Detroit, Michigan.

Claude's special set for [KONTROL] will feature a deeper, darker techno sid=
e
of this fun-loving bear-shaped man!


---> LINKS:

Claude's Websites:
http://www.mothershipmusic.com
http://www.dirtybirdrecords.com

Claude's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Claude%20VonStroke

Claude on MySpace:
www.myspace.com/claudevonstroke


---> AUDIO:

***(NOTE: this whole CD, which shows off Claude's deeper, more
techno-oriented side, is made available in high quality and
FREE, as the company originally releasing it is now defunct!)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/CVS_At_The_Controls_CD2.mp3

http://www.dirtybirdrecords.com/audio/mixes/VONSTROKE_MIXMAG_CD.mp3

https://www.beatport.com/en-US/html/content/artist/detail/5430/claude_vonst=
roke

>>>> Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this
>>>> month,
>>>> and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so 
>>>> some
>>>> overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
>>>> undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
>>>> for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
>>>> trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
>>>> when the different scheduling strategies overlap.
>>>>
>>>> I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part
>>>> because
>>>> it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special
>>>> Fridays,
>>>> leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part,
>>>> parties
>>>> all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
>>>> good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
>>>> start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
>>>> window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
>>>> each month for a party.
>>>>
>>>> I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
>>>> give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
>>>> least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun
>>>> ourselves,
>>>> and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
>>>> overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)
>>>>
>>>> Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
>>>> claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
>>>> committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
>>>> set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
>>>> forum so we all know what we're all planning?

Saturday, March 1st, 2008


[ K O N T R O L ]


minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup



featuring from New York City:


DEREK PLASLAIKO  ( Spectral Sound . The Bunker )

Derek Plaslaiko doesn't make records, but he sure as hell
knows how to play 'em.  One of a select few to have made
a name for himself based on DJ skills alone, Derek's
dedication and immense musical knowledge, coupled with his
anything-goes attitude make every set a memorable dance
floor experience.  Once a prominent figure on the Detroit
party scene, he relocated to NYC a few years back and was
soon crowned "Best Techno DJ" by the Village Voice.  We
simply call him "The Man", and are excited to welcome him
back for an extended encore performance.



and San Francisco's own:


CLAUDE VONSTROKE  ( Mothership . Dirtybird )

The last time our friend Barclay Crenshaw played for us,
just a couple short years ago in August '05, it was one of
the first times his pseudonym Claude VonStroke had
appeared in print on a flyer.  My how times change!  Now a
bona fide international superstar synonymous with the new
sound of SF, the inimitable 'Stroker returns to [KONTROL]
to lay down a specially crafted techno set you won't hear
anywhere else.



with [KONTROL] residents:


CRAIG KUNA  ( Platform . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO  ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
NIKOLA BAYTALA  ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )
SAMMY D  ( Dirtybird . Utensil )

________________________________________________


DEREK PLASLAIKO

Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper into
the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
trends, forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that make
the staunchest of chin-stroking, note-taking trainspotters lose their shit
on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.

Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. He
quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties.
He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  With
a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during that
time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to head
east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs at
the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lamb
monthly parties. More recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
"Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.

The last time Derek played for [KONTROL] in February '07, he so thouroughly
impressed both the crowd and our resident DJs that we have been drooling
over the day we would have him back, and we're happy to report that day has
come. This time Derek comes to us as part of the "Death Is Nothing To Fear"
Spectral Residencies, on his first major US tour.

---> LINKS:

Derek's Website: (w/ lots of free sets for download)
http://plaslaiko.net

Derek on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko


---> AUDIO:

http://www.residentadvisor.net/podcast-episode.aspx?id=92

Live @ The Bunker, 2008 (Spectral Tour Kickoff - 5 hour set!)
http://feeds.feedburner.com/TheBunkerPodcast

Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia, 2006  (2 hours - 111MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelphia_07.15.06.mp3


---> VIDEO:

Live @ The Bunker, 2007 (Detroit Takeover night)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6fvYgXJiNdM

Derek @ Mutek Igloofest 2008
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sk8b1UbBQlY


________________________________________________


CLAUDE VONSTROKE

"I would like to come overwhat are you having for dinner?" asks the creepy
character in Claude VonStroke's first hit record, "Deep Throat."  After
selling through 10 pressings in 2005, "Deep Throat" quickly put VonStroke on
the map as an up and coming artist.  The success of the single was followed
up by "Who's Afraid of Detroit?," another international hit championed by
Richie Hawtin who called it the "Best Track of 2006" in DJ magazine.  Soon
after he released his full length debut album, "Beware of the Bird" to
excellent reviews, further establishing him as an original talent in the
world of underground dance music. Since then, Claude has done remixes for a
very diverse group of top artists ranging all the way from indie-rock band
The Rapture, to electro legends Newcleus, to minimalists like Matt Tolfrey
and Jeff Samuel.

Claude VonStroke is better known to locals as Barclay Crenshaw, the owner of
San Francisco's quirky tech-funk label, dirtybird.  The label consists of
Crenshaw (VonStroke,) friends and fellow producers Justin Martin, Christian
Martin, and Worthy, and a diverse assortment of top remixers from around the
globe including John Tejada, Audion, Diplo, 3 Channels, Dj Assault, and
Kevin Saunderson.

The idea for dirtybird began in 2003 when Crenshaw was producing an intense
5 hour DVD about electronic music called, "Intellect." The project was a
labor of love, taking almost 2 years to complete and starring over 35 top
producers and legendary DJs such as Derrick May, Swayzak, Derrick Carter,
Deep Dish, Magda, Theo Parish, and many more.  The main goal of the
"Intellect" project was to make an informative DVD that could help DJs
advance their careers in electronic music. The result was Crenshaw himself
starting dirtybird records and a production career under the alias Claude
VonStroke.

Since 2005, dirtybird has managed to solidify a reputation for releasing
oddball classic techno and house tracks, and in the process has become one
of the hottest labels on the planet. The outdoor dirtybird parties in San
Francisco's scenic Golden Gate Park have also become a legendary summer
destination point for both locals and international travelers.

In addition to production and label management, Claude VonStroke has an
intense regimen for preparation and a great ear for song selection. His DJ
sets are always inspiring and surprising. You will never hear a set of
monotonous music because Claude always takes time to find the special cuts
that make for a completely original experience that is not to be missed.

In 2008, Claude is hard at work on his second album, in addition to
fostering his latest project, Mothership Records.  Mothership was started in
2007 as VonStroke's outlet for deep and experimental techno. The first
record on Mothership became a summer classic and sold 7,000 vinyl records
and sat at #1 on the Beatport minimal techno chart for 8 weeks. Proceeds
from the label go towards children's music education in Claude's hometown of
Detroit, Michigan.

Claude's special set for [KONTROL] will feature a deeper, darker techno side
of this fun-loving bear-shaped man!


---> LINKS:

http://www.mothershipmusic.com
http://www.dirtybirdrecords.com

Claude's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Claude%20VonStroke

www.myspace.com/claudevonstroke

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 3/29 and comprehensive collision insurance



Werd.  Like I said, it's all good, everyone loves Osby, Jump looks awesome,
I'm of course happy with the talent I've got lined up for Faktion, they're
all good parties, the only thing that bugs me is that I can't go to em all
myself. =)

I do want to avoid poaching on folks I like, but as long as we're bringing
a different focus, I don't simple date overlap as the same.  It's a little
weird when we all go into last-week promotion and finally realize it, but
I really doubt there are all that many folks who'd feel forced to choose
between parties.  There is a group of people I see at different parties
often, so maybe some of them have the "too many good choices" situation,
but overall, when I meet people, most of them don't go to all that many
parties and don't seem all that aware that they've got so many choices.

So, the real pressure is on us promoters to reach a bigger audience than
we're finding.  If there are really only 100 techno fans in the bay area
to fight over there's little point anyway.  OTOH, if there are only 100
*active* clubbers right now, and a whole lotta folks who are still waiting
for Dieter to announce that "Now is the time on Sprockets when we dance,"
then we all just need to figure out a better way to promote and get people
out of their homes.  That sounds like a great thing for us all to discuss.

Ray

> realized people owned any particular crowd anyway - sheesh)
>

> events now anyway...less stress for me and I still get to be part of the 
> process. Helping out can be equally as reqarding.

> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Greg Bird" <bird415@gmail.com>

> VonStroke!

> 
> Saturday, March 1st, 2008
> 
> 
> [ K O N T R O L ]
> 

> minimal techno + avant-house
> every 1st Saturday @ The Endup
> 
> 
> 
> featuring from New York City:
> 
> 
> DEREK PLASLAIKO  ( Spectral Sound . The Bunker )
> 
> Derek Plaslaiko doesn't make records, but he sure as hell
> knows how to play 'em.  One of a select few to have made
> a name for himself based on DJ skills alone, Derek's
> dedication and immense musical knowledge, coupled with his
> anything-goes attitude make every set a memorable dance
> floor experience.  Once a prominent figure on the Detroit
> party scene, he relocated to NYC a few years back and was
> soon crowned "Best Techno DJ" by the Village Voice.  We
> simply call him "The Man", and are excited to welcome him
> back for an extended encore performance.
> 
> 
> 
> and San Francisco's own:
> 
> 
> CLAUDE VONSTROKE  ( Mothership . Dirtybird )
> 
> The last time our friend Barclay Crenshaw played for us,
> just a couple short years ago in August '05, it was one of
> the first times his pseudonym Claude VonStroke had
> appeared in print on a flyer.  My how times change!  Now a
> bona fide international superstar synonymous with the new
> sound of SF, the inimitable 'Stroker returns to [KONTROL]
> to lay down a specially crafted techno set you won't hear
> anywhere else.
> 
> 
> 
> with [KONTROL] residents:
> 
> 
> CRAIG KUNA  ( Platform . ESDJCO )
> ALLAND BYALLO  ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
> NIKOLA BAYTALA  ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )
> SAMMY D  ( Dirtybird . Utensil )

> 401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
> 10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
> http://www.theendup.com
> 
> FREE until 11pm!
> 
> ________________________________________________
> 
> 
> Full bios, pics and FREE music:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com
> 
> [KONTROL] on MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf
> 
> Flyer:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K33/K33H.jpg
> 
> Poster:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K33/K33P.jpg
> 
> 
> ________________________________________________
> 
> 
> DEREK PLASLAIKO
> 
> Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
> record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper into
> the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
> trends, forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that make
> the staunchest of chin-stroking, note-taking trainspotters lose their shit
> on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.
> 
> Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
> equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
> Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
> the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. He
> quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
> the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties.
> He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
> clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
> a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  With
> a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
> Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
> the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
> Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during that
> time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
> of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.
> 
> In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
> Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
> Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to head
> east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
> Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs at
> the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lamb
> monthly parties. More recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
> "Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.
> 
> The last time Derek played for [KONTROL] in February '07, he so thouroughly
> impressed both the crowd and our resident DJs that we have been drooling
> over the day we would have him back, and we're happy to report that day has
> come. This time Derek comes to us as part of the "Death Is Nothing To Fear"
> Spectral Residencies, on his first major US tour.
> 
> ---> LINKS:
> 
> Derek's Website: (w/ lots of free sets for download)
> http://plaslaiko.net
> 
> Derek on MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko
> 
> 
> ---> AUDIO:
> 
> Derek's brand new Resident Advisor podcast!
> http://www.residentadvisor.net/podcast-episode.aspx?id=92
> 
> Live @ The Bunker, 2008 (Spectral Tour Kickoff - 5 hour set!)
> http://feeds.feedburner.com/TheBunkerPodcast
> 
> Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia, 2006  (2 hours - 111MB)
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelphia_07.15.06.mp3
> 
> 
> ---> VIDEO:
> 
> Live @ The Bunker, 2007 (Detroit Takeover night)
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6fvYgXJiNdM
> 
> Derek @ Mutek Igloofest 2008
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sk8b1UbBQlY
> 
> 
> ________________________________________________
> 
> 
> CLAUDE VONSTROKE
> 
> "I would like to come overâ¦what are you having for dinner?" asks the 
> creepy
> character in Claude VonStroke's first hit record, "Deep Throat."  After
> selling through 10 pressings in 2005, "Deep Throat" quickly put VonStroke on
> the map as an up and coming artist.  The success of the single was followed
> up by "Who's Afraid of Detroit?," another international hit championed by
> Richie Hawtin who called it the "Best Track of 2006" in DJ magazine.  Soon
> after he released his full length debut album, "Beware of the Bird" to
> excellent reviews, further establishing him as an original talent in the
> world of underground dance music. Since then, Claude has done remixes for a
> very diverse group of top artists ranging all the way from indie-rock band
> The Rapture, to electro legends Newcleus, to minimalists like Matt Tolfrey
> and Jeff Samuel.
> 
> Claude VonStroke is better known to locals as Barclay Crenshaw, the owner of
> San Francisco's quirky tech-funk label, dirtybird.  The label consists of
> Crenshaw (VonStroke,) friends and fellow producers Justin Martin, Christian
> Martin, and Worthy, and a diverse assortment of top remixers from around the
> globe including John Tejada, Audion, Diplo, 3 Channels, Dj Assault, and
> Kevin Saunderson.
> 
> The idea for dirtybird began in 2003 when Crenshaw was producing an intense
> 5 hour DVD about electronic music called, "Intellect." The project was a
> labor of love, taking almost 2 years to complete and starring over 35 top
> producers and legendary DJs such as Derrick May, Swayzak, Derrick Carter,
> Deep Dish, Magda, Theo Parish, and many more.  The main goal of the
> "Intellect" project was to make an informative DVD that could help DJs
> advance their careers in electronic music. The result was Crenshaw himself
> starting dirtybird records and a production career under the alias Claude
> VonStroke.
> 
> Since 2005, dirtybird has managed to solidify a reputation for releasing
> oddball classic techno and house tracks, and in the process has become one
> of the hottest labels on the planet. The outdoor dirtybird parties in San
> Francisco's scenic Golden Gate Park have also become a legendary summer
> destination point for both locals and international travelers.
> 
> In addition to production and label management, Claude VonStroke has an
> intense regimen for preparation and a great ear for song selection. His DJ
> sets are always inspiring and surprising. You will never hear a set of
> monotonous music because Claude always takes time to find the special cuts
> that make for a completely original experience that is not to be missed.
> 
> In 2008, Claude is hard at work on his second album, in addition to
> fostering his latest project, Mothership Records.  Mothership was started in
> 2007 as VonStroke's outlet for deep and experimental techno. The first
> record on Mothership became a summer classic and sold 7,000 vinyl records
> and sat at #1 on the Beatport minimal techno chart for 8 weeks. Proceeds
> from the label go towards children's music education in Claude's hometown of
> Detroit, Michigan.
> 
> Claude's special set for [KONTROL] will feature a deeper, darker techno side
> of this fun-loving bear-shaped man!
> 
>

Dragn'fly wrote:
> i don't really think "claiming dates" is necessary.  the point of the
> calendar was always to serve as a single source where people could go and
> see what was going on in a single night.  there have always been multiple
> events and there always will be.  so no pissing on any date is necessary -
> and if i remember correctly, you could post the details of your event as
> far
> in advance as you wanted (as long as those details are complete and
> finalized) and as soon as the week before...  other last minutes events
> were
> always posted the last minute, but it's not 1999 anymore folks , so I bet
> that'd be at a minimum...
>
> it's not about a competition.  like i said, it's 1999 anymore boys.
>
> even if i'm booked at other events, i don't see other events going on the
> same night as competition, but then again, I bring a wider out of town
> heads
> on account and don't won't accept gigs that appeal to the same crowd at
> more
> than one evnent, so i can do 2 parties (or even 3) different events in the
> bay these days and i've seen them all sell out...
>
> it's all about doing your own thing and just being as careful as you can
> to
> avoid events on single nights that might draw the same crowd and follow a
> similar theme.

> i think everyone tonight will do well.

>>>
>>>
>>> Well, we try not to, but there were 5 fridays and 4 saturdays this
>>> month,
>>> and there's a lot more than 9 of us throwing parties these days, so
>>> some
>>> overlap is unavoidable.  There are different musical foci, there are
>>> undergrounds and clubs, most of which simply adds up to more choice
>>> for music lovers.  I would think that most of us aren't specifically
>>> trying to compete against our own friends here, there are just times
>>> when the different scheduling strategies overlap.
>>>
>>> I took over last fridays at Anu when Filter left it in large part
>>> because
>>> it's a mostly open night, but there are still going to be special
>>> Fridays,
>>> leap years, in 2010 NYE will be a Friday, etc.   For the most part,
>>> parties
>>> all book starting about 2 months ahead, though I'm trying to get mine a
>>> good ammount further out now, and regardless it's hard on all of us to
>>> start booking a night and finish and announce, all in a small enough
>>> window to not collide, especially given the small number of good days
>>> each month for a party.
>>>
>>> I think it's less about survival of the fittest than it is trying to
>>> give people choices and trying to figure out how to hurt ourselves the
>>> least while doing it.  We're all presumably in this to have fun
>>> ourselves,
>>> and most of us seem to like going to each others parties when we don't
>>> overlap.  Back in business school they used to call it coopetition. =)
>>>
>>> Calendar sounds great, but still raises the question of when do we
>>> claim dates, when we start booking or when we have a party fully
>>> committed?  First come first served on the calendar, or a minimum
>>> set of required shit-togetherness to qualify?  Or just an open info
>>> forum so we all know what we're all planning?
>>>
>>> Ray
>>>
>>>
>>>

On 29 February 2008, mo corleone wrote:

> i'm just thankful that i live in a corner of the planet where "too 
> many parties" is a real concern. i love having choices, and i also 
> really enjoy bouncing from killer event to killer event when i can 
> swing it.
>
> i do my best to show respect and common courtesy when planning a 
> party, but the sheer volume of events makes it impossible to keep up 
> with everything.  the way i see it, there are more than enough bouncy 
> dancing freaks to go around. this town could certainly have worse 
> problems than an abundance of stellar music.

IOW, be careful what you wish for.

>
> love,
> mo
